[He]628-i paused again . [She]629-she was perfectly silent . [She]629-she trembled a little -- wondering what [she]629-she was going to hear . It must be something dreadful , [she]629-she thought,--something for which [she]629-she was unprepared,--something that might , perhaps , like a sudden change in the currents of the air , create darkness where there had been sunshine , storm instead of calm . [His]628-i grip on [her]629-she hand was strong enough to hurt [her]629-she , but [she]629-she was not conscious of it . [She]629-she only wished [he]628-i would tell [her]629-she the worst at once and quickly . The worst,--for [she]629-she instinctively felt there was no best .

" It was eighteen years ago this very haymaking time , "[628-i] [he]628-i went on , with a dreamy retrospective air as though [he]628-i were talking to himself,--"The last load had been taken in . Supper was over . [The men]438-the men had gone home,--Priscilla was clearing [the great hall]550-the great hall , when there came on a sudden storm -- just a flash of lightning -- [I]628-i can see it now , striking a blue fork across the windows -- a clap of thunder -- and then a regular downpour of rain . Heavy rain , too,--buckets - full -- for it washed [the yard]2737-the yard out and almost swamped [the garden]415-the garden . [I]628-i did n't think much about it,--the hay was hauled in dry , and that was all [my]628-i concern . [I]628-i stood under [a shed in [the yard]2737-the yard]2967-a shed in the yard and watched the rain falling in straight sheets out of a sky black as pitch -- [I]628-i could scarcely see [my]628-i own hand if [I]628-i stretched it out before [me]628-i , the night was so dark . All at once [I]628-i heard the quick gallop of a horse 's hoofs some way off,--then the sound seemed to die away,--but presently [I]628-i heard the hoofs coming at a slow steady pace down [[our]2969-our muddy old by - road]2970-our muddy old by - road -- [no one]2691-no one can gallop THAT , in any weather . " Why am [I]646-you called [Innocent]152-innocent ? "[646-you]

" [You]646-you were never baptised . "[646-you]

" Never baptised ! "[646-you] [She]646-you echoed the words despairingly,--and then was silent for a minute 's space . " Could [you]647-he not have done that much for [me]646-you ? "[646-you] [she]646-you asked , plaintively , at last--"Would it have been impossible ? "[646-you]

[He]647-he was vaguely ashamed . [Her]646-you eyes , pure as [a young child]648-a young child 's , were fixed upon [him]647-he in appealing sorrow . [He]647-he began to feel that [he]647-he had done [her]646-you a grievous wrong , though [he]647-he had never entirely realised it till now . [He]647-he answered [her]646-you with some hesitation and an effort at excuse .

" Not impossible -- no,--maybe [I]647-he could have baptised [you]646-you [myself]647-he if [I]647-he had thought about it . ' Tis but a sprinkle of water and ' In the Name of [the Father]3053-the father , [Son]3054-son , and [Holy Ghost]134-holy ghost . ' But somehow [I]647-he never worried [my]647-he head -- for as long as [you]646-you were [a baby]3055-a baby [I]647-he looked for [the man who brought [you]646-you day after day , and in [my]647-he own mind left all that sort of business for [him]3056-the man who brought you day after day , and in my own mind left all that sort of business for him to attend to to attend to]3056-the man who brought you day after day , and in my own mind left all that sort of business for him to attend to -- and when [he]3056-the man who brought you day after day , and in my own mind left all that sort of business for him to attend to did n't come and [you]646-you grew older , it fairly slipped [my]647-he remembrance altogether . [I]647-he 'm not fond of [the Church]3057-the church or [its]3057-the church ways,--and [you]646-you 've done as well without baptism as with it , surely . [Innocent]152-innocent is a good name for [you]646-you , and fits [your]646-you case . For [you]646-you 're innocent of the faults of [[your]646-you parents]3058-your parents whatever [they]3058-your parents were , and [you]646-you 're innocent of [my]647-he blunders . [You]646-you 're free to make [your]646-you own life pleasant if [you]646-you 'll only put a bright face on it and make the best of an awkward business . "[647-he]

[She]649-i was silent , standing before [him]650-him like [a little statuesque figure of desolation]651-a little statuesque figure of desolation .

" As for the tale [I]650-him told [the neighbours]3025-the neighbours , "[650-him] [he]650-him went on--"it was the best thing [I]649-i could think of . If [I]649-i had said [you]646-you were [a child]634-a child [I]649-i had taken in to adopt , [not one of [them]3025-the neighbours]3061-not one of them would have believed [me]649-i ; ' twas a case of telling one lie or t'other , the real truth being so queer and out of the common , so [I]649-i chose the easiest . And it 's been all right with [you]646-you , [[my]649-i girl]3062-my girl , whichever way [you]646-you put it . There may be [a few stuck - up young huzzies in [the village]2885-the village that are n't friendly to [you]646-you]3063-a few stuck - up young huzzies in the village that are n't friendly to you , but [you]646-you may take it that it 's more out of jealousy of [Robin]126-robin 's liking for [you]646-you than anything else . [Robin]126-robin loves [you]646-you -- [you]646-you know [he]126-robin does ; and all [you]646-you 've got to do is to make [him]126-robin happy . Marry [him]126-robin , for [the farm]2744-the farm will be [his]126-robin when [I]649-i 'm dead , and it 'll give [me]649-i a bit of comfort to feel that [you]646-you 're settled down with [him]126-robin in [the old home]3066-the old home . For then [I]649-i know it 'll go on just the same -- just the same-- "[649-i]

[His]652-i words trailed off brokenly . [His]652-i head sank on [his]652-i chest , and some slow tears made their difficult way out of [his]652-i eyes and dropped on [his]652-i silver beard .

[She]653-you watched [him]652-i with a certain grave compassion , but [she]653-you did not at once go , as [she]653-you would usually have done , to put [her]653-you arms round [his]652-i neck and console [him]652-i . [She]653-you seemed to [herself]653-you removed miles away from [him]652-i and from everything [she]653-you had ever known . Just then there was a noise of rough but cheery voices outside shouting " good - night "[653-you] to [each other]654-each other , and [she]653-you said in a quiet tone :

" [The men]438-the men are away now . Is there anything [you]652-i want before [I]653-you go to bed ? "[653-you]

With a sudden access of energy , which contrasted strangely with [his]652-i former feebleness , [he]652-i rose and confronted [her]653-you .

" No , there 's nothing [I]652-i want ! "[652-i] [he]652-i said , in vehement tones--"Nothing but peace and quietness ! [I]652-i 've told [you]653-you [your]653-you story , and [you]653-you take it ill . But recollect , [girl]3068-girl , that if [you]653-you consider any shame has been put on [you]653-you , [I]652-i 've put equal shame on [myself]652-i for [your]653-you sake -- [I]652-i , [Hugo]87-uncle hugo Jocelyn,--against whom never a word has been said but this,--which is a lie -- that [[my]652-i child]3006-my child , [mine!--was]3006-my child born out of wedlock ! [I]652-i suffered this against [myself]652-i solely for [your]653-you sake -- [I]652-i , who never wronged [a woman in [my]652-i life!--I]3070-a woman in my life!--i , who never loved but [one woman]3071-one woman , who died before [I]652-i had the chance to marry her!--and [I]652-i say and [I]652-i swear [I]652-i have sacrificed something of [my]652-i name and reputation to [you]653-you ! So that [you]653-you need not make trouble because [you]653-you also share in the sacrifice . [Robin]126-robin thinks [you]653-you 're [[my]652-i child]3006-my child , and therefore [his]126-robin cousin,--and [he]126-robin counts nothing against [you]653-you , for [he]126-robin knows that what [the world]2693-the world would count against [you]653-you must be [my]652-i fault and would be [my]652-i fault , if the lie [I]652-i started against [myself]652-i was true . Marry [Robin]126-robin , [I]652-i tell [you!--and]3074-you!--and if [you]653-you care to make [me]652-i happy , marry [him]126-robin before [I]652-i die . Then [you]653-you 're safe out of all harm 's way . If [you]653-you DON'T marry [him--]126-robin "[652-i]

[Her]655-her breath came and went quickly -- [she]655-her folded [her]655-her hands across [her]655-her bosom , trying to still the loud and rapid beating of [her]655-her heart , but [her]655-her eyes were very bright and steadfast .

" Yes ? What then ? "[655-her] [she]655-her asked , calmly .

" Then [you]655-her must take the consequences , "[656-he] [he]656-he said . " [The farm]2744-the farm and all [I]656-he have is left to [Robin,--he]135-robin,--he 's [[my]656-he dead sister 's son]3076-my dead sister 's son and [my]656-he nearest living kin-- "[656-he]

" [I]655-her know that , "[655-her] [she]655-her said , simply , " and [I]655-her 'm glad [he]656-he has everything . It 's right that it should be so . [I]655-her shall not be in [his]656-he way . [You]656-he may be quite sure of that . But [I]655-her shall not marry [him]656-he . "[655-her]

" [You]655-her 'll not marry [him]656-he ? "[656-he] [he]656-he repeated , and seemed about to give vent to a torrent of invective when [she]655-her extended [her]655-her hands clasped together appealingly .

" [Dad]85-dad , do n't be angry!--it only hurts [you]85-dad and it does no good ! Just before supper [you]656-he reminded [me]657-you of what [they]3077-they say in [Church]2815-church that ' the sins of [the fathers]2816-the fathers should be visited on [the children]2817-the children , even unto [the third and fourth generation]2818-the third and fourth generation . ' [I]657-you will not visit the sin of [[my]657-you father]2856-my father and [mother]3083-mother on [anyone]2832-anyone . If [you]656-he will give [me]657-you a little time [I]657-you shall be able to understand everything more clearly , and perhaps bear it better . [I]657-you want to be quite by [myself]657-you . [I]657-you must try to see [myself]657-you as [I]657-you am,--unbaptised , nameless , forsaken ! And if there is anything to be done with [this wretched little self of [mine]657-you]3085-this wretched little self of mine , it is [I]657-you that must do it . With [God]80-god 's help ! "[657-you] [She]657-you sighed , and [her]657-you lips moved softly again in the last words , " With [God]80-god 's help ! "[657-you]

[He]658-he said nothing , and [she]657-you waited a moment as if expecting [him]658-he to speak . Then [she]657-you moved to the table where [she]657-you had been sitting and folded up [her]657-you needlework .

" Shall [I]657-you get [you]658-he some wine , [Dad]85-dad ? "[657-you] [she]657-you asked presently in a quiet voice .

" No ! "[658-he] [he]658-he replied , curtly--"Priscilla can get it . "[657-you]

" Then good - night ! "[658-he]

Still standing erect [he]658-he turned [his]658-he head and looked at [her]657-you .

" Are [you]657-you going ? "[658-he] [he]658-he said . " Without [your]657-you usual kiss?--your usual tenderness ? Why should [you]657-you change to [me]659-his ? [[Your]657-you own father]3086-your own father -- if [he]3086-your own father was [[your]657-you father]2854-your father -- deserted you,--and [I]659-his have been , [a father to [you]657-you in [his]3086-your own father place]3088-a father to you in his place , wronging [my]659-his own honourable name for [your]657-you sake ; am [I]659-his to blame for this ? Be reasonable ! The laws of [man]567-man are one thing and the laws of [God]80-god are another,--and [we]3090-we have to make the best [we]3090-we can of [ourselves]3090-we between the two . There 's many a piece of wicked injustice in [the world]2693-the world , but nothing more wicked than to set shame or blame on [a child that 's born without permit of law or blessing of priest]3092-a child that 's born without permit of law or blessing of priest . For it 's not [the child]2985-the child 's fault,--it 's brought into [the world]2693-the world without [its]2985-the child own consent,--and yet [the world]2693-the world fastens a slur upon it ! That 's downright brutal and senseless!--for if there is any blame attached to the matter it should be fastened on [the parents]3096-the parents , and not on [the child]2985-the child . And that 's what [I]659-his thought when [you]657-you were left on [my]659-his hands -- [I]659-his took the blame of [you]657-you on [myself]659-his , and [I]659-his was careful that [you]657-you should be treated with every kindness and respect -- mind [you]657-you that ! Respect ! There 's not [a man on the place that does n't doff [his]659-his cap to [you]657-you]3098-a man on the place that does n't doff his cap to you ; and [you]657-you 've been as [[my]659-his own daughter]3099-my own daughter always . [You]657-you ca n't deny it ! And more than that"--here[659-his] [his]659-his strong voice faltered--"I've loved [you!--yes]657-you - [I've]659-his loved [you]657-you , [little Innocent--]136-little innocent-- "[659-his]

[She]660-her looked up in [his]659-his face and saw it quivering with suppressed emotion , and the strange cold sense of aloofness that had numbed [her]660-her senses suddenly gave way like snow melting in the spring . In a moment [she]660-her was in [his]659-his arms , weeping out [her]660-her pent - up tears on [his]659-his breast , and [he]659-his , stroking [her]660-her soft hair , soothed [her]660-her with every tender and gentle word [he]659-his could think of .

" There , there ! "[659-his] [he]659-his murmured , fondly . " [Thou]3100-thou must look at it in this way , [dear child]3016-dear child ! That if [God]80-god deprived [thee]3016-dear child of [one father]3102-one father [he]659-his gave [thee]3016-dear child another in [his]659-his place ! Make the best of that gift before it be taken from [thee]3016-dear child ! "[659-his]

CHAPTER IV

There are still [a few old houses left in [rural England which are as yet happily unmolested by the destroying ravages of modern improvement]662-rural england which are as yet happily unmolested by the destroying ravages of modern improvement]661-a few old houses left in rural england which are as yet happily unmolested by the destroying ravages of modern improvement , and [Briar Farm]4-briar farm was one of these . History and romance alike had their share in [its]4-briar farm annals , and [its]4-briar farm title - deeds went back to the autumnal days of 1581 , when [the Duke of Anjou]663-the duke of anjou came over from [France]12-france to [England]9-england with a royal train of [noblemen]664-noblemen and [gentlemen]665-gentlemen in the hope to espouse [the greatest monarch of all time]666-the greatest monarch of all time , " [the most renowned and victorious "[666-the greatest monarch of all time] Queen Elizabeth]3103-the most renowned and victorious " queen elizabeth , whose reign has clearly demonstrated to [the world]2693-the world how much more ably [a clever woman]668-a clever woman can rule [a country]669-a country than [a clever man]670-a clever man , if [she]668-a clever woman is left to [her]668-a clever woman own instinctive wisdom and prescience . [No king]671-no king has ever been wiser or more diplomatic than [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , and [no king]671-no king has left a more brilliant renown . As [the coldest of [male historians]674-male historians]673-the coldest of male historians is bound to admit , " [her]82-elizabeth singular powers of government were founded equally on [her]82-elizabeth temper and on [her]82-elizabeth capacity . Endowed with a great command over [herself]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth soon obtained [an uncontrolled ascendant over [[her]82-elizabeth people]3105-her people]3104-an uncontrolled ascendant over her people . [Few sovereigns of [England]9-england]3106-few sovereigns of england succeeded to the throne under more difficult circumstances , and [none]3107-none ever conducted the government with such uniform success and felicity . "[674-male historians] Had [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth been weak , [the Duke of Anjou]663-the duke of anjou might have realised [his]663-the duke of anjou ambitious dream , with the unhappiest results for [England]9-england ; and that [he]663-the duke of anjou fortunately failed was entirely due to [her]82-elizabeth sagacity and [her]82-elizabeth quick perception of [his]663-the duke of anjou irresolute and feeble character . In the sumptuous train attendant upon this " [Petit Grenouille]137-petit grenouille , "[663-the duke of anjou] as [he]663-the duke of anjou styled [himself]663-the duke of anjou in one of [his]663-the duke of anjou babyish epistles to [[England]9-england 's sovereign majesty]676-england 's sovereign majesty , there was [a certain knight]677-a certain knight more inclined to the study of letters than to the breaking of lances,--the [Sieur Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis , who being much about [the court]678-the court in the wake of [[his]138-the sieur amadis somewhat capricious and hot - tempered master]679-his somewhat capricious and hot - tempered master , came , unfortunately for [his]138-the sieur amadis own peace of mind , into occasional personal contact with [one of the most bewitching young women of [her]82-elizabeth time]680-one of the most bewitching young women of her time , [the Lady Penelope Devereux]139-the lady penelope devereux , afterwards [Lady Rich]140-dick , [she]680-one of the most bewitching young women of her time in whom , according to [a contemporary writer]681-a contemporary writer , " lodged all attractive graces and beauty , wit and sweetness of behaviour which might render [her]680-one of the most bewitching young women of her time [the mistress of all eyes and hearts]3108-the mistress of all eyes and hearts . "[680-one of the most bewitching young women of her time] Surrounded as [she]680-one of the most bewitching young women of her time was by [many suitors]682-many suitors , [his]663-the duke of anjou passion was hopeless from the first , and that [he]663-the duke of anjou found it so was evident from the fact that [he]663-the duke of anjou suddenly disappeared from [the court]678-the court and from [[his]663-the duke of anjou master]684-his master 's retinue , and was never heard of by [the great world]685-the great world again . Yet [he]663-the duke of anjou was not far away . [He]663-the duke of anjou had not the resolution to leave [England]9-england , [the land which enshrined [the lady]687-the lady of [his]663-the duke of anjou love,--and [he]663-the duke of anjou had lost all inclination to return to [France]12-france]686-the land which enshrined the lady of his love,--and he had lost all inclination to return to france . [He]663-the duke of anjou therefore retired into [the depths of [the sweet English country]689-the sweet english country]688-the depths of the sweet english country , among the then unspoilt forests and woodlands , and there happening to find [a small manor - house]690-a small manor - house for immediate sale , surrounded by a considerable quantity of land , [he]663-the duke of anjou purchased [it]690-a small manor - house for the ready cash [he]663-the duke of anjou had about [him]663-the duke of anjou and settled down in [it]690-a small manor - house for the remainder of [his]663-the duke of anjou life . Little by little , such social ambitions as [he]663-the duke of anjou had ever possessed left [him]663-the duke of anjou , and with every passing year [he]663-the duke of anjou grew more and more attached to the simplicity and seclusion of [his]663-the duke of anjou surroundings . [He]663-the duke of anjou had leisure for the indulgence of [his]663-the duke of anjou delight in books , and [he]663-the duke of anjou was able to give the rein to [his]663-the duke of anjou passion for poetry , though it is nowhere recorded that [he]663-the duke of anjou ever published the numerous essays , sonnets and rhymed pieces which , written in the picturesque caligraphy of the period , and roughly bound by [himself]663-the duke of anjou in sheepskin , occupied a couple of shelves in [[his]663-the duke of anjou library]691-his library . [He]663-the duke of anjou entered with animation and interest into the pleasures of farming and other agricultural pursuits , and by - and - bye as time went on and [the former idol of [his]663-the duke of anjou dreams]692-the former idol of his dreams descended from [her]692-the former idol of his dreams fair estate of virtue and scandalised [the world]2693-the world by [her]692-the former idol of his dreams liaison with [Lord Mountjoy]141-lord mountjoy , [he]663-the duke of anjou appears to have gradually resigned the illusions of [his]663-the duke of anjou first love , for [he]663-the duke of anjou married [a simple village girl]694-a simple village girl , remarkable , so it was said , for [her]694-a simple village girl beauty , but more so for [her]694-a simple village girl skill in making butter and cheese . [She]694-a simple village girl could neither read nor write , however , and the traditions concerning [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis relate that [he]663-the duke of anjou took a singular pleasure in teaching [her]694-a simple village girl these accomplishments , as well as in training [her]694-a simple village girl to sing and to accompany [herself]694-a simple village girl upon the lute in a very pretty manner . [She]694-a simple village girl made [him]663-the duke of anjou [an excellent wife]695-an excellent wife , and gave [him]663-the duke of anjou no less than [six children]696-six children , [three boys]697-three boys and [three girls]698-three girls , all of whom were brought up at [home]2674-home under the supervision of [[their]696-six children father]700-their father and [mother]3083-mother , and encouraged to excel in country pursuits and to understand the art of profitable farming . It was in [their]702-their days that [Briar Farm]4-briar farm entered upon [its]4-briar farm long career of prosperity , which still continued . [The Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis died in [his]138-the sieur amadis seventieth year , and by [his]138-the sieur amadis own wish , expressed in [his]138-the sieur amadis " Last Will and Testament , "[138-the sieur amadis] was buried in [a sequestered spot on [[his]138-the sieur amadis own lands]704-his own lands]703-a sequestered spot on his own lands , under a stone slab which [he]138-the sieur amadis had [himself]138-the sieur amadis fashioned , carving upon it [his]138-the sieur amadis recumbent figure in the costume of [a knight]705-a knight , a cross upon [his]138-the sieur amadis breast and a broken sword at [his]138-the sieur amadis side . [[His]138-the sieur amadis wife]706-his wife , though several years younger than [himself]138-the sieur amadis , only lived a twelve - month after [him]138-the sieur amadis and was interred by [his]138-the sieur amadis side . [Their]707-their resting - place was now walled off , planted thickly with flowers , and held sacred by [every succeeding heir to [the farm]2744-the farm]708-every succeeding heir to the farm as [the burial - place of [the first Jocelyns]711-the first jocelyns]710-the burial - place of the first jocelyns . Steadily and in order , [the families springing from the parent tree of [the French knight Amadis]713-the french knight amadis]712-the families springing from the parent tree of the french knight amadis had occupied [Briar Farm]4-briar farm in unbroken succession , and through three centuries [the property]714-the property had been kept intact , none of [its]714-the property possessions being dispersed and none of [[its]714-the property land]715-its land being sold . [The house]2762-the house was practically in the same sound condition as when [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis fitted and furnished [it]2762-the house for [his]138-the sieur amadis own occupation,--there was the same pewter , the same solid furniture , the same fine tapestry , preserved by the careful mending of many hundreds of needles worked by hands long ago mingled with the dust of the grave , and , strange as it may seem to [those who are only acquainted with the flimsy manufactures of to - day]717-those who are only acquainted with the flimsy manufactures of to - day , the same stout hand - wrought linen , which , mended and replenished each year , lasted so long because never washed by modern methods , but always by hand in clear cold running water . There were presses full of this linen , deliriously scented with lavender , and there were also the spinning - wheels that had spun the flax and the hand - looms on which the threads had been woven . These were witnesses to the days when [women]718-women , instead of gadding abroad , were happy to be at [home]2674-home -- when the winter evenings seemed short and bright because as [they]718-women sat spinning by the blazing log fire [they]718-women were cheerful in [their]718-women occupation , singing songs and telling stories and having so much to do that there was no time to indulge in the morbid analysis of life and the things of life which in [our]720-our present shiftless day perplex and confuse idle and unhealthy brains .

And now after more than three centuries , [the direct male line of [Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis]721-the direct male line of amadis de jocelin had culminated in [Hugo]87-uncle hugo , commonly called [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn , who , on account of some secret love disappointment , the details of which [he]87-uncle hugo had never told to [anyone]2832-anyone , had remained unmarried . Till the appearance on the scene of [the child]2985-the child , [Innocent]152-innocent , who was by [the village folk]724-the village folk accepted and believed to be [the illegitimate offspring of this ill - starred love]725-the illegitimate offspring of this ill - starred love , it was tacitly understood that [Robin Clifford]84-robin , [[his]138-the sieur amadis nephew]726-his nephew , and [the only son of [[his]138-the sieur amadis twin sister]728-his twin sister]727-the only son of his twin sister , would be [the heir to [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]729-the heir to briar farm ; but when it was seen how much [the old man]426-the old man seemed to cling to [Innocent]152-innocent , and to rely upon [her]152-innocent ever tender care of [him]426-the old man , the question arose as to whether there might not be [an heiress]731-an heiress after all , instead of [an heir]732-an heir . And [the rustic wiseacres]733-the rustic wiseacres gossiped , as is [their]733-the rustic wiseacres wo nt , watching with no small degree of interest the turn of events which had lately taken place in the frank and open admiration and affection displayed by [Robin]84-robin for [[his]138-the sieur amadis illegitimate cousin]734-his illegitimate cousin , as it was thought [she]734-his illegitimate cousin was , and as [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn had tacitly allowed it to be understood . If [the two young people]735-the two young people married , [everybody]736-everybody agreed it would be the right thing , and the best possible outlook for the continued prosperity of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm . For after all , it was [the farm]2744-the farm that had to be chiefly considered , so [they]736-everybody [opined,--the farm]738-opined,--the farm was [an historic and valuable property]739-an historic and valuable property as well as an excellent paying concern . The great point to be attained was that it should go on as it had always gone on from the days of [the Sieur Amadis,--and]142-the sieur amadis,--and that it should be kept in the possession of [the same family]740-the same family . This at any rate was known to be the cherished wish of [old Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn , though [he]143-hugo jocelyn was not given to any very free expression of [his]143-hugo jocelyn feelings . [He]143-hugo jocelyn knew that [[his]143-hugo jocelyn neighbours]617-his neighbours envied [him]143-hugo jocelyn , watched [him]143-hugo jocelyn and commented on [his]143-hugo jocelyn actions,--he knew also that the tale [he]143-hugo jocelyn had told [them]617-his neighbours concerning [Innocent]152-innocent had to a great extent whispered away [his]143-hugo jocelyn own good name and fastened a social slur upon the girl,--yet [he]143-hugo jocelyn could not , according to [his]143-hugo jocelyn own views , have seen any other way out of the difficulty . [The human world]742-the human world is always wicked - tongued ; and it is common knowledge that [any man]2694-any man or woman introducing [an " adopted "[747-she] child]744-an " adopted " child into [a family]745-a family is at once accused , whether [he]746-he or [she]747-she be conscious of the accusation or not , of passing off [[his]2694-any man own bastard]748-his own bastard under the " adoption "[747-she] pretext . [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn was fairly certain that [none of [[his]143-hugo jocelyn neighbours]617-his neighbours]749-none of his neighbours would credit the romantic episode of [the man on horseback]751-the man on horseback arriving in a storm and leaving [a nameless child]752-a nameless child on [his]751-the man on horseback hands . The story was quite true,--but truth is always precisely what [people]2701-people refuse to believe .

The night on which [Innocent]152-innocent had learned [her]152-innocent own history for the first time was a night of consummate beauty in [the natural world]754-the natural world . When all the gates and doors of [the farm]2744-the farm and [[its]2744-the farm outbuildings]756-its outbuildings had been bolted and barred for the night , the moon , almost full , rose in a cloudless heaven and shed pearl - white showers of radiance all over [the newly - mown and clean - swept fields]757-the newly - mown and clean - swept fields , outlining the points of [the old house gables]758-the old house gables and touching with luminous silver the roses that clambered up the walls . One wide latticed window was open to the full inflowing of the scented air , and within [its]759-its embrasure sat [a lonely little figure in a loose white garment with hair tumbling carelessly over its shoulders and eyes that were wet with tears]760-a lonely little figure in a loose white garment with hair tumbling carelessly over its shoulders and eyes that were wet with tears . The clanging chime of the old clock below stairs had struck eleven some ten minutes since , and after the echo of its bell had died away there had followed a heavy and intense silence . The window looked not upon [the garden]415-the garden , but out upon [the fields]2706-the fields and a suggestive line of dark foliage edging them softly in the distance,--away down there , under a huge myriad - branched oak , slept [the old knight [Sieur Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis and [[his]138-the sieur amadis English rustic wife]764-his english rustic wife]763-the old knight sieur amadis de jocelin and his english rustic wife , [the founders of [the Briar Farm family]766-the briar farm family]765-the founders of the briar farm family . [The little figure in the dark embrasure of the window]767-the little figure in the dark embrasure of the window clasped [its]767-the little figure in the dark embrasure of the window white hands and turned [its]767-the little figure in the dark embrasure of the window weeping eyes towards [that ancient burial - place]768-that ancient burial - place , and the moon - rays shone upon [its]767-the little figure in the dark embrasure of the window fair face with a silvery glimmer , giving [it]767-the little figure in the dark embrasure of the window an almost spectral pallor . " Why was [I]771-i ever born ? "[771-i] sighed a trembling voice--"Oh , dear [God]80-god ! Why did [you]80-god let [it]3109-it be ? "[771-i]

The vacant air , [the vacant fields]769-the vacant fields looked blankly irresponsive . [They]763-the old knight sieur amadis de jocelin and his english rustic wife had no sympathy to give,--they never have . To great Mother Nature it is not important how or why [a child]634-a child is born , though [she]771-i occasionally decides that it shall be of the greatest importance how and why [the child]2985-the child shall live . What does it matter to the forces of creative life whether it is brought into [the world]2693-the world " basely , "[771-i] as the phrase goes , or honourably ? [The child]2985-the child exists,--it is a human entity -- [a being full of potential good or evil,--and]775-a being full of potential good or evil,--and after a certain period of growth it stands alone , and [its parents]776-its parents have less to do with it than [they]776-its parents imagine . It makes [its]2985-the child own circumstances and shapes [its]2985-the child own career , and in many cases the less it is interfered with the better . But [Innocent]152-innocent could not reason out [her]152-innocent position in any cold - blooded or logical way . [She]152-innocent was too young and too unhappy . Everything that [she]152-innocent had taken pride in was swept from [her]152-innocent at once . Only that very morning [she]152-innocent had made one of [her]152-innocent many pilgrimages down to the venerable oak beneath whose trailing branches [the Sieur Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis lay , covered by the broad stone slab on which [he]138-the sieur amadis had carved [his]138-the sieur amadis own likeness , and [she]152-innocent had put a little knot of the " Glory "[152-innocent] roses between [his]138-the sieur amadis mailed hands which were folded over the cross on [his]138-the sieur amadis breast , and [she]152-innocent had said to [the silent effigy]777-the silent effigy :

" It is the last day of the haymaking , [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ! [You]777-the silent effigy would be glad to see the big crop going in if [you]777-the silent effigy were [here]2907-here ! "[152-innocent]

[She]152-innocent was accustomed to talk to [the old stone knight]778-the old stone knight in this fanciful way,--she had done so all [her]152-innocent life ever since [she]152-innocent could remember . [She]152-innocent had taken an intense pride in thinking of [him]778-the old stone knight as [[her]152-innocent ancestor]779-her ancestor ; [she]152-innocent had been glad to trace [her]152-innocent lineage back over three centuries to [the love - lorn French noble who had come to [England]9-england in the train of the Due d'Anjou]780-the love - lorn french noble who had come to england in the train of the due d'anjou -- and now -- now [she]152-innocent knew [she]152-innocent had no connection at all with [him,--that]781-him,--that [she]152-innocent was [an unnamed , unbaptised nobody]782-an unnamed , unbaptised nobody -- [an unclaimed waif of humanity whom [no one]2691-no one wanted]783-an unclaimed waif of humanity whom no one wanted ! [No one in all [the world]2693-the world]785-no one in all the world -- except [Robin]84-robin ! [He]778-the old stone knight wanted her;--but perhaps when [he]778-the old stone knight knew [her]152-innocent true history [his]778-the old stone knight love would grow cold . [She]152-innocent wondered whether it would be so . If it were [she]152-innocent would not mind very much . Indeed it would be best , for [she]152-innocent felt [she]152-innocent could never marry [him]778-the old stone knight .

" No , not if [I]152-innocent loved [him]778-the old stone knight with all [my]152-innocent heart ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , passionately--"Not without a name!--not till [I]152-innocent have made a name for [myself]152-innocent , if only that were possible ! "[152-innocent]

[She]152-innocent left the window and walked restlessly about [[her]152-innocent room]787-her room , [a room that [she]152-innocent loved very greatly because [it]788-a room that she loved very greatly because it had been the study of the sieur amadis had been the study of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis]788-a room that she loved very greatly because it had been the study of the sieur amadis . [It]787-her room was [a wonderful room]789-a wonderful room , oak - panelled from floor to ceiling , and there was no doubt about [its]787-her room history,--the [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis [himself]138-the sieur amadis had taken care of that . For on every panel [he]138-the sieur amadis had carved with [his]138-the sieur amadis own hand a verse , a prayer , or an aphorism , so that the walls were a kind of open notebook inscribed with [his]138-the sieur amadis own personal memoranda . Over the wide chimney [his]138-the sieur amadis coat - of - arms was painted , the colours having faded into tender hues like those of autumn leaves , and the motto underneath was " Mon coeur [me]152-innocent soutien . "[152-innocent] Then followed the inscription :

" [Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis , [Knight of [France]12-france]3111-knight of france , Who here seekynge Forgetfulness did here fynde Peace . "[152-innocent]

Every night of [her]152-innocent life since [she]152-innocent could read [Innocent]152-innocent had stood in front of these armorial bearings in [her]152-innocent little white night - gown and had conned over these words . [She]152-innocent had taken the memory and tradition of [Amadis]138-the sieur amadis to [her]152-innocent heart and soul . [He]138-the sieur amadis was [[HER]152-innocent ancestor,--hers]790-her ancestor,--hers , [she]152-innocent had always said;--she had almost learned [her]152-innocent letters from the inscriptions [he]138-the sieur amadis had carved , and through these [she]152-innocent could read old English and a considerable amount of old French besides . When [she]152-innocent was about twelve years old [she]152-innocent and [Robin Clifford]84-robin , playing about together in [this room]791-this room , happened to knock against one panel that gave forth a hollow reverberant sound , and moved by curiosity [they]792-they tried whether [they]792-they could open it . After some abortive efforts [Robin]84-robin 's fingers closed by chance on a hidden spring , which being thus pressed caused the panel to fly open , disclosing a narrow secret stair . Full of burning excitement [the two children]793-the two children ran up it , and to [their]793-the two children delight found [themselves]793-the two children in [a small square musty chamber in which were two enormous old dower - chests , locked]794-a small square musty chamber in which were two enormous old dower - chests , locked . [Their]793-the two children locks were no bar to the agility of [Robin]84-robin , who , fetching a hammer , forced the old hasps asunder and threw back the lids . The coffers were full of books and manuscripts written on vellum , a veritable sixteenth - century treasure - trove . [They]793-the two children hastened to report the find to [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn , who , though never greatly taken with books or anything concerning [them]793-the two children , was sufficiently interested to go with [the eager children]795-the eager children and look at the discovery [they]792-they had made . But as [he]138-the sieur amadis could make nothing of either books or manuscripts [himself]138-the sieur amadis , [he]138-the sieur amadis gave over the whole collection to [Innocent]152-innocent , saying that as they were found in [[her]152-innocent part of [the house]2762-the house]796-her part of the house [she]152-innocent might keep them . [No one]2691-no one -- not even [Robin]84-robin -- knew how much [she]152-innocent had loved and studied these old books , or how patiently [she]152-innocent had spelt out the manuscripts ; and [no one]2691-no one could have guessed what a wide knowledge of literature [she]152-innocent had gained or what fine taste [she]152-innocent had developed from [her]152-innocent silent communications with the parted spirit of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis and [his]138-the sieur amadis poetical remains . [She]152-innocent had even arranged [[her]152-innocent room]787-her room as [she]152-innocent thought [he]138-the sieur amadis might have liked [it]787-her room , in severe yet perfect taste . It was now [[her]152-innocent study]801-her study as it had been his,--the heavy oak table had a great pewter inkstand upon it and a few loose sheets of paper with two or three quill pens ready to hand,--some quaint old vellum - bound volumes and a brown earthenware bowl full of " Glory "[152-innocent] roses were set just where they could catch the morning sunshine through the lattice window . One side of [the room]531-the room was lined with loaded bookshelves , and at [its]803-its furthest end a wide arch of roughly hewn oak disclosed [a smaller apartment where [she]152-innocent slept]804-a smaller apartment where she slept . Here there was [a quaint little four - poster bedstead]805-a quaint little four - poster bedstead , hung with quite priceless Jacobean tapestry , and a still more rare and beautiful work of art -- an early Italian mirror , full length and framed in silver , a curio worth many hundreds of pounds . In this mirror [Innocent]152-innocent had surveyed [herself]152-innocent with more or less disfavour since [her]152-innocent infancy . It was a mirror that had always been there -- a mirror in which [the wife of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis]806-the wife of the sieur amadis must have often gazed upon [her]806-the wife of the sieur amadis own reflection , and in which , after [her]152-innocent , [all the wives and daughters of [the succeeding Jocelyns]808-the succeeding jocelyns]807-all the wives and daughters of the succeeding jocelyns had seen [their]807-all the wives and daughters of the succeeding jocelyns charms presented to [their]807-all the wives and daughters of the succeeding jocelyns own admiration . The two old dower - chests which had been found in [the upper chamber]809-the upper chamber were placed on either side of the mirror , and held all the simple home - made garments which were [Innocent]152-innocent 's only wear . A special joy of [hers]152-innocent lay in the fact that [she]152-innocent knew the management of the secret sliding panel , and that [she]152-innocent could at [her]152-innocent own pleasure slip up [the mysterious stairway]810-the mysterious stairway with a book and be thus removed from all [the household]564-the household in a solitude which to [her]152-innocent was ideal . To - night as [she]152-innocent wandered up and down [[her]152-innocent room]787-her room like [a little distraught ghost]813-a little distraught ghost , all the happy and romantic associations of [the home [she]152-innocent had loved and cherished for so many years]814-the home she had loved and cherished for so many years seemed cut down like a sheaf of fair blossoms by [a careless reaper,--a sordid and miserable taint]815-a careless reaper,--a sordid and miserable taint was on [her]152-innocent life , and [she]152-innocent shuddered with mingled fear and grief as [she]152-innocent realised that [she]152-innocent had not even the simple privilege of ordinary baptism . [She]152-innocent was [a nameless waif]816-a nameless waif , dependent on the charity of [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn . True , [the old man]426-the old man had grown to love [her]152-innocent and [she]152-innocent had loved [him]426-the old man -- ah!--let the many tender prayers offered up for [him]426-the old man in [this very room]818-this very room bear witness before the throne of [God]80-god to [her]152-innocent devotion to [[her]152-innocent " father]3112-her " father "[152-innocent] as [she]152-innocent had thought [him]426-the old man ! And now -- if what [the doctors]2791-the doctors said was true -- if [he]426-the old man was soon to die -- what would become of [her]152-innocent ? [She]152-innocent wrung [her]152-innocent little hands in unconscious agony .

" What shall [I]152-innocent do ? "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent murmured , sobbingly--"I have no claim on [him]426-the old man , or on anyone in [the world]2693-the world ! [Dear God]80-god , what shall [I]152-innocent do ? "[152-innocent]

[Her]152-innocent restless walk up and down took [her]152-innocent into [[her]152-innocent sleeping - chamber]820-her sleeping - chamber , and there [she]152-innocent lit a candle and looked at [herself]152-innocent in the old Italian mirror . [A little woe - begone creature]821-a little woe - begone creature gazed sorrowfully back at [her]152-innocent from its shining surface , with brimming eyes and quivering lips , and hair all tossed loosely away from a small sad face as pale as a watery moon , and [she]152-innocent drew back from [her]152-innocent own reflection with a gesture of repugnance .

" [I]152-innocent am no use to [anybody]3114-anybody in any way , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , despairingly--"I am not even good - looking . And [Robin]84-robin -- poor foolish Robin!--called [me]152-innocent ' lovely ' this afternoon ! [He]84-robin has no eyes ! "[152-innocent]

Then a sudden thought flew across [her]152-innocent brain of [Ned Landon]112-landon . [The tall powerful - looking brute]822-the tall powerful - looking brute loved [her]152-innocent , [she]152-innocent knew . Every look of [his]112-landon told [her]152-innocent that [his]112-landon very soul pursued [her]152-innocent with a reckless and relentless passion . [She]152-innocent hated [him,--she]112-landon trembled even now as [she]152-innocent pictured [his]112-landon dark face and burning eyes;--he had annoyed and worried [her]152-innocent in a thousand ways -- ways that were not sufficiently open in [their]823-their offence to be openly complained of , though had [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn 's state of health given [her]152-innocent less cause for anxiety [she]152-innocent might have said something to [him]112-landon which would perhaps have opened [his]112-landon eyes to the situation . But not now,--not now could [she]152-innocent appeal to [anyone]2832-anyone for protection from amorous insult . For who was [she]152-innocent -- what was [she]152-innocent that [she]152-innocent should resent it ? [She]152-innocent was [nothing!--a mere stray child whose parents [nobody]2675-nobody knew,--without [any lawful guardian]827-any lawful guardian to uphold [her]152-innocent rights or assert [her]152-innocent position]825-nothing!--a mere stray child whose parents nobody knew,--without any lawful guardian to uphold her rights or assert her position . No wonder [old Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn had called [her]152-innocent " wilding"--she[120-farmer jocelyn] was indeed a " wilding "[120-farmer jocelyn] or weed,--growing up unwanted in [the garden of the world]828-the garden of the world , destined to be pulled out of the soil where [she]152-innocent had nourished and thrown contemptuously aside . A wretched sense of utter helplessness stole over [her,--of]829-her,--of incapacity , weakness and loneliness . [She]152-innocent tried to think,--to see [her]152-innocent way through the strange fog of untoward circumstance that had so suddenly enshrouded [her]152-innocent . What would happen when [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn died ? For one thing [she]152-innocent would have to quit [Briar Farm]4-briar farm . [She]152-innocent could not stay in [it]4-briar farm when [Robin Clifford]84-robin was [its master]830-its master . [He]84-robin would marry , of course ; [he]84-robin would be sure to marry ; and there would be no place for [her]152-innocent in [[his]84-robin home]831-his home . [She]152-innocent would have to earn [her]152-innocent bread ; and the only way to do that would be to go out to service . [She]152-innocent had a good store of useful domestic knowledge,--she could bake and brew , and wash and scour ; [she]152-innocent knew how to rear poultry and keep bees ; [she]152-innocent could spin and knit and embroider ; indeed [her]152-innocent list of household accomplishments would have startled [any girl fresh out of a modern [Government school]833-government school , where things that are useful in life are frequently forgotten , and things that are not by any means necessary are taught as though they were imperative]832-any girl fresh out of a modern government school , where things that are useful in life are frequently forgotten , and things that are not by any means necessary are taught as though they were imperative . One other accomplishment [she]152-innocent had,--one that [she]152-innocent hardly whispered to [herself]152-innocent -- [she]152-innocent could write,--write what [she]152-innocent [herself]152-innocent called " nonsense . "[152-innocent] Scores of little poems and essays and stories were locked away in [a small old bureau in a corner of the room,--confessions and expressions of pent - up feeling which , but for this outlet , would have troubled [her]152-innocent brain and hindered [her]152-innocent rest]834-a small old bureau in a corner of the room,--confessions and expressions of pent - up feeling which , but for this outlet , would have troubled her brain and hindered her rest . They were mostly , as [she]152-innocent frankly admitted to [her]152-innocent own conscience , in the " style "[138-the sieur amadis] of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis , and were inspired by [his]138-the sieur amadis poetic suggestions . [She]152-innocent had no fond or exaggerated idea of their merit,--they were the result of solitary hours and long silences in which [she]152-innocent had felt [she]152-innocent must speak to someone,--exchange thoughts with [someone,--or]835-someone,--or suffer an almost intolerable restraint . That " [someone]3115-someone "[152-innocent] was for [her]152-innocent [the long dead knight who had come to [England]9-england in the train of [the Duc d'Anjou]837-the duc d'anjou]836-the long dead knight who had come to england in the train of the duc d'anjou . To [him]138-the sieur amadis [she]152-innocent spoke,--to [him]138-the sieur amadis [she]152-innocent told all [her]152-innocent troubles -- but to [no one else]838-no one else did [she]152-innocent ever breathe [her]152-innocent thoughts , or disclose a line of what [she]152-innocent had written . [She]152-innocent had often wondered whether , if [she]152-innocent sent these struggling literary efforts to a magazine or newspaper , they would be accepted and printed . But [she]152-innocent never made the trial , for the reason that such newspaper literature as found its way into [Briar Farm]4-briar farm filled [her]152-innocent with amazement , repulsion and disgust . There was nothing in any modern magazine that at all resembled the delicate , pointed and picturesque phraseology of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ! Strange , coarse slang - words were used,--and the news of the day was slung together in loose ungrammatical sentences and chopped - up paragraphs of clumsy construction , lacking all pith and eloquence . So , repelled by the horror of twentieth - century " style , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent had hidden [her]152-innocent manuscripts deeper than ever in the old bureau , under little silk sachets of dried rose - leaves and lavender , as though they were love - letters or old lace . And when sometimes [she]152-innocent shut [herself]152-innocent up and read them over [she]152-innocent felt like one of [Hamlet]144-hamlet 's " [guilty creatures sitting at a play]3116-guilty creatures sitting at a play . "[152-innocent] [Her]152-innocent literary attempts seemed to reproach [her]152-innocent for their inadequacy , and when [she]152-innocent made some fresh addition to [her]152-innocent store of written thoughts , [her]152-innocent crimes seemed to [herself]152-innocent doubled and weighted . [She]152-innocent would often sit musing , with a little frown puckering [her]152-innocent brow , wondering why [she]152-innocent should be moved to write at all , yet wholly unable to resist the impulse .

To - night , however , [she]152-innocent scarcely remembered these outbreaks of [her]152-innocent dreaming fancy,--the sordid , hard , matter - of - fact side of life alone presented itself to [her]152-innocent depressed imagination . [She]152-innocent pictured [herself]152-innocent going into service -- as what ? [Kitchen - maid]839-kitchen - maid , [probably,--she]840-probably,--she was not tall enough for [a house - parlourmaid]841-a house - parlourmaid . [House - parlourmaids]842-house - parlourmaids were bound to be effective,--even dignified,--in height and appearance . [She]152-innocent had seen one of [these superior beings in [church]2815-church on Sundays]843-these superior beings in church on sundays -- [a slim , stately young woman with waved hair and a hat as fashionable as that worn by [[her]152-innocent mistress]846-her mistress , [[the Squire]847-the squire 's lady]848-the squire 's lady]845-a slim , stately young woman with waved hair and a hat as fashionable as that worn by her mistress , the squire 's lady . With a deepening sense of humiliation , [Innocent]152-innocent felt that [her]152-innocent very limitation of inches was against [her]152-innocent . Could [she]152-innocent be [a nursery - governess]849-a nursery - governess ? Hardly ; for though [she]152-innocent liked [good - tempered , well - behaved children]850-good - tempered , well - behaved children , [she]152-innocent could not even pretend to endure [them]850-good - tempered , well - behaved children when [they]850-good - tempered , well - behaved children were otherwise . [Screaming , spiteful , quarrelsome children]851-screaming , spiteful , quarrelsome children were to [her]152-innocent less interesting than barking puppies or [squealing pigs;--besides]852-squealing pigs;--besides , [she]152-innocent knew [she]152-innocent could not be [an efficient teacher of so much as one accomplishment]853-an efficient teacher of so much as one accomplishment . Music , for instance ; what had [she]152-innocent learned of music ? [She]152-innocent could play on an ancient spinet which was one of the chief treasures of [the " best parlour "[852-squealing pigs;--besides] of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]854-the " best parlour " of briar farm , and [she]152-innocent could sing old ballads very sweetly and plaintively,--but of " technique "[152-innocent] and " style "[152-innocent] and all the latter - day methods of musical acquirement and proficiency [she]152-innocent was absolutely ignorant . Foreign languages were a dead letter to [her]152-innocent -- except old French . [She]152-innocent could understand that ; and [Villon]145-villon 's famous verses , " Ou sont les neiges d'antan ? "[145-villon] were as familiar to [her]152-innocent as [Herrick]146-herrick 's " Come , [[my]145-villon Corinna]3117-my corinna , let [us]3118-us go a - maying . "[145-villon] But , on the whole , [she]152-innocent was strangely and poorly equipped for the battle of life . [Her]152-innocent knowledge of baking , brewing , and general housewifery would have stood [her]152-innocent in good stead on [some Colonial]855-some colonial settlement,--but [she]152-innocent had scarcely heard of [these far - away refuges for [the destitute]857-the destitute]856-these far - away refuges for the destitute , as [she]152-innocent so seldom read the newspapers . [Old Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn looked upon the cheap daily press as " the curse of [the country]2876-the country , "[143-hugo jocelyn] and never willingly allowed a newspaper to come into [the living - rooms of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]858-the living - rooms of briar farm . [They]859-them were relegated entirely to [the kitchen]518-the kitchen and [outhouses]861-outhouses , where [the farm labourers]862-the farm labourers smoked over [them]859-them and discussed [them]859-them to [their]862-the farm labourers hearts ' content , seldom venturing , however , to bring any item of so - called " news "[863-their master] to [[their]859-them master]863-their master 's consideration . If [they]859-them ever chanced to do so , [he]863-their master would generally turn round upon [them]859-them with a few cutting observations , such as,--

" How do [you]3120-you know it 's true ? [Who gives the news]3121-who gives the news ? Where 's the authority ? And what do [I]863-their master care if [some human brute]3122-some human brute has murdered [[his]3122-some human brute wife]706-his wife and blown out [his]3122-some human brute own brains ? Am [I]863-their master going to be any the better for reading such a tale ? And if [one Government]3124-one government is in or t'other out , what does it matter to [me]863-their master , or to any of [you]3120-you , so long as [you]3120-you can work and pay [your]3120-you way ? The newspapers are always trying to persuade [us]3125-us to meddle in [other folks]3126-other folks 's business;--I say , take care of [your]3120-you own affairs!--serve [God]80-god and obey the laws of [the country]2876-the country , and there wo n't be much going wrong with [you]3120-you ! If [you]3120-you must read , read a decent book -- something that will last -- not a printed sheet full of advertisements that 's fresh one day and torn up for waste paper the next ! "[863-their master]

Under the sway of these prejudiced and arbitrary opinions , it was not possible for [Innocent]152-innocent to have much knowledge of [the world]2693-the world that lay outside [Briar Farm]4-briar farm . Sometimes [she]152-innocent found [Priscilla]121-priscilla reading an old magazine or looking at a picture - paper , and [she]152-innocent would borrow these and take them up to [[her]152-innocent own room]865-her own room surreptitiously for an hour or so , but [she]152-innocent was always more or less pained and puzzled by their contents . " [Innocent]152-innocent ! "[121-priscilla]
