CHAPTER XI

That night [Innocent]152-innocent made an end of all [her]152-innocent hesitation . Resolutely [she]152-innocent put away every thought that could deter [her]152-innocent from the step [she]152-innocent was now resolved to take . [Poor old Priscilla]121-priscilla little imagined the underlying cause of the lingering tenderness with which [the girl]414-the girl kissed [her]414-the girl " good - night , "[152-innocent] looking back with more than [her]152-innocent usual sweetness as [she]152-innocent went along [the corridor]1085-the corridor to [[her]152-innocent own little room]1308-her own little room . Once there , [she]152-innocent locked and bolted the door fast , and then set to work gathering a few little things together and putting them in a large but light - weight satchel , such as [she]152-innocent had often used to carry some of the choicest apples from [the orchard]3313-the orchard when they were being gathered in . [Her]152-innocent first care was for [her]152-innocent manuscript,--the long - treasured scribble , kept so secretly and so often considered with hope and fear , and wonder and doubting -- then [she]152-innocent took one or two of the more cherished volumes which had formerly been the property of the " [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis "[152-innocent] and packed them with it . Choosing only the most necessary garments from [[her]152-innocent little store]1362-her little store , [she]152-innocent soon filled [her]152-innocent extemporary travelling - bag , and then sat down to write a letter to [Robin]126-robin . It was brief and explicit .

" [DEAR]85-dad ROBIN,"--it[152-innocent] ran--"I have left [this beloved home]4089-this beloved home . It is impossible for [me]152-innocent to stay . [Dad]85-dad left [me]152-innocent some money in bank - notes in that sealed letter -- so [I]152-innocent want for nothing . Do not be anxious or unhappy -- but marry soon and forget [me]152-innocent . [I]152-innocent know [you]126-robin will always be good to [Priscilla]121-priscilla -- tell [her]121-priscilla [I]152-innocent am not ungrateful to [her]121-priscilla for all [her]121-priscilla care of [me]152-innocent . [I]152-innocent love [her]121-priscilla dearly . But [I]152-innocent am placed in [the world]2693-the world unfortunately , and [I]152-innocent must do something that will help [me]152-innocent out of the shame of being a burden on [others]2689-others and an object of pity or contempt . If [you]126-robin will keep the old books [Dad]85-dad gave [me]152-innocent , and still call them [mine]152-innocent , [you]126-robin will be doing [me]152-innocent a great kindness . And will [you]126-robin take care of [Cupid?--he]234-cupid?--he is quite a clever bird and knows [[his]234-cupid?--he friends]4092-his friends . [He]234-cupid?--he will come to [you]126-robin or [Priscilla]121-priscilla as easily as [he]234-cupid?--he comes to [me]152-innocent . Good - bye , [[you]126-robin dear , [kind boy]4094-kind boy]4093-you dear , kind boy ! [I]152-innocent love [you]126-robin very much , but not as [you]126-robin want [me]152-innocent to love you,--and [I]152-innocent should only make [you]126-robin miserable if [I]152-innocent stayed [here]2907-here and married [you]126-robin . God bless [you]126-robin ! "[152-innocent] INNOCENT . "[152-innocent]

[She]1363-i put this in an envelope and addressed [it,--then]235-it,--then making sure that everything was ready , [she]1363-i took a few sovereigns from the little pile of housekeeping money which [Priscilla]121-priscilla always brought to [her]1363-i to count over every week and compare with the household expenses .

" [I]1363-i can return these when [I]1363-i change one of [Dad]85-dad 's bank - notes , "[1363-i] [she]1363-i said to herself--"but [I]1363-i must have something smaller to pay [my]1363-i way with just now than a hundred pounds . "[1363-i]

Indeed the notes [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn had left for [her]1363-i might have given [her]1363-i some little trouble and embarrassment , but [she]1363-i did not pause to consider difficulties . When [a human creature resolves to dare and to do]1364-a human creature resolves to dare and to do , no impediment , real or imaginary , is allowed to stand long in the way . An impulse pushes the soul forward , be it ever so reluctantly -- the impulse is sometimes from heaven and sometimes from hell -- but as long as it is active and peremptory , it is obeyed blindly and to the full .

[This little ignorant and unworldly girl]1365-this little ignorant and unworldly girl passed the rest of the night in tidying [the beloved room]1366-the beloved room where [she]1365-this little ignorant and unworldly girl had spent so many happy hours , and setting everything in order,--talking in whispers between whiles to the ghostly presence of the " [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis "[1368-she] as to [a friend who knew [her]1365-this little ignorant and unworldly girl difficult plight and guessed [her]1365-this little ignorant and unworldly girl intentions]1367-a friend who knew her difficult plight and guessed her intentions .

" [You]1367-a friend who knew her difficult plight and guessed her intentions see , "[1363-i] [she]1363-i said , softly , " there is no way out of it . It is not as if [I]1363-i were [anybody]3114-anybody -- [I]1363-i am [nobody]2675-nobody ! [I]1363-i was never wanted in [the world]2693-the world at all . [I]1363-i have no name . [I]1363-i have never been baptised . And though [I]1363-i know now that [I]1363-i have [a mother]4099-a mother , [I]1363-i feel that [she]4099-a mother is nothing to [me]1363-i . [I]1363-i can hardly believe [she]4099-a mother is [[my]1363-i mother]3020-my mother . [She]4099-a mother is [a lady of fashion with a secret]4101-a lady of fashion with a secret -- and _ [I]1363-i _ am the secret ! [I]1363-i ought to be put away and buried and forgotten!--that would be safest for [her]4099-a mother , and perhaps best for [me]1363-i ! But [I]1363-i should like to live long enough to make [her]4099-a mother wish [she]4099-a mother had been true to [[my]1363-i father]2856-my father and had owned [me]1363-i as [[his]2856-my father child]4103-his child ! Ah , such dreams ! Will they ever come true ! "[1363-i]

[She]1368-she paused , looking up by the dim candle - light at the arms of the " [Sieur Amadis"--who]138-the sieur amadis[1368-she] " Here seekinge Forgetfulnesse did here fynde Peace"--and[1368-she] at the motto " Mon coeur [me]1368-she soutien . "[1368-she]

" Poor ' [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ! ' "[1368-she] [she]1368-she murmured--"He sought forgetfulness!--shall [I]1368-she ever do the same ? How strange it will be not to WISH to remember!--surely one must be very old , or sad , to find gladness in forgetting ! "[1368-she]

A faint little thrill of dread ran through [her]1368-she slight frame -- thoughts began to oppress [her]1368-she and shake [her]1368-she courage -- [she]1368-she resolutely put them away and bent [herself]1368-she to the practical side of action . Re - attiring [herself]1368-she in the plain black dress and hat which [Priscilla]121-priscilla had got for [her]121-priscilla mourning garb , [she]1368-she waited patiently for the first peep of daylight -- a daylight which was little more than darkness -- and then , taking [her]1368-she satchel , [she]1368-she crept softly out of [[her]1368-she room]787-her room , never once looking back . There was nothing to stay [her]1368-she progress , for [the great mastiff Hero]1370-the great mastiff hero , since [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn 's death , had taken to such dismal howling that it had been found necessary to keep [him]1370-the great mastiff hero away from [the house]2762-the house in , [a far - off shed where [his]1370-the great mastiff hero melancholy plaints could not be heard]1372-a far - off shed where his melancholy plaints could not be heard . Treading with light , soundless footsteps down the stairs , [she]1368-she reached the front - door,--unbarred and unlocked [it]1373-it without any noise , and as softly closed it behind [her,--then]1374-her,--then [she]1368-she stood in the open , shivering slightly in the sweet coldness of the coming dawn , and inhaling the fragrance of awakening unseen flowers . [She]1368-she knew of a gap in the hedge by means of which [she]1368-she could leave [the garden]415-the garden without opening [the big farm]1376-the big farm - gate which moved on rather creaking hinges -- and [she]1368-she took this way over a couple of rough stepping - stones . Once out on [the old by - road]369-the old by - road [she]1368-she paused . [Briar Farm]4-briar farm looked like [a house]1378-a house in a dream -- there was not enough daylight yet to show [its]4-briar farm gables distinctly , and [it]4-briar farm was more like the shadowy suggestion of [a building]1379-a building than any actual substance . Yet there was something solemn and impressive in [its]4-briar farm scarcely defined outline -- to [the girl]414-the girl 's sensitive imagination it was like the darkened and disappearing vision of [her]414-the girl youth and happiness,--a curtain falling , as it were , between the past and the future like a drop - scene in a play .

" Good - bye , [Briar Farm]4-briar farm ! "[1368-she] [she]1368-she whispered , kissing [her]1368-she hand to the quaintly peaked roof just dimly perceptible--"Good - bye , dear , [beloved [home]2674-home]4104-beloved home ! [I]1368-she shall never forget [you]4104-beloved home ! [I]1368-she shall never see anything like [you]4104-beloved home ! Good - bye , peace and safety!--good - bye ! "[1368-she]

The tears rushed to [her]1368-she eyes , and for the moment blinded [her,--then]1381-her,--then , overcoming this weakness , [she]1368-she set [herself]1368-she to walk quickly and steadily away . Up [the old by - road]369-the old by - road , through the darkness of the overhanging trees , here and there crossed by pale wandering gleams of fitful light from the nearing dawn , [she]1368-she moved swiftly , treading with noiseless footsteps as though [she]1368-she thought [the unseen spirits of wood and field]1383-the unseen spirits of wood and field might hear and interrupt [her]1368-she progress -- and in a few minutes [she]1368-she found [herself]1368-she upon [the broad highway]1384-the broad highway branching right and left and leading in either direction to [the wider world]1385-the wider world . [Briar Farm]4-briar farm had disappeared behind the trees,--it was as though [no such place]1386-no such place existed , so deeply was it hidden .

[She]1368-she stopped , considering . [She]1368-she was not sure which was the way to [the nearest railway - station]1387-the nearest railway - station some eight miles distant . [She]1368-she was prepared to walk [it]1388-it , but feared to take [the wrong road]1389-the wrong road , for [she]1368-she instinctively felt that if [she]1368-she had to endure any unexpected delay , [some one from [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]1390-some one from briar farm would be sent to trace [her]1368-she and find out where [she]1368-she went . While [she]1368-she thus hesitated , [she]1368-she heard the heavy rumbling of [slow cart - wheels]1391-slow cart - wheels , and waited to see what [sort of vehicle]1392-sort of vehicle might be approaching . It was a large waggon drawn by two ponderous horses and driven by [a man who , dimly perceived by the light of the lantern fastened in front of]1393-a man who , dimly perceived by the light of the lantern fastened in front of [him]1393-a man who , dimly perceived by the light of the lantern fastened in front of , appeared to be asleep . [Innocent]152-innocent hailed [him]1393-a man who , dimly perceived by the light of the lantern fastened in front of -- and after one or two efforts succeeded at last in rousing [his]1393-a man who , dimly perceived by the light of the lantern fastened in front of attention .

" Which is the way to [the railway - station]4106-the railway - station ? "[1368-she] [she]1368-she asked .

[The man]481-the man blinked drowsily at [her]1368-she .

" [Railway - station]4107-railway - station , is it ? [I]481-the man be a - goin' [there]2972-there now to fetch a load o ' nitrates . Are [ye]481-the man wantin ' to git ? "[481-the man]

" Wantin ' to git "[481-the man] was a country phrase to which [Innocent]152-innocent was well accustomed . [She]1368-she answered , gently--

" Yes . [I]1368-she should be so glad if [you]481-the man 'd give [me]1368-she a lift -- [I'll]1368-she pay [you]481-the man for it . [I]1368-she have to catch [the first train]4109-the first train to [London]3-london . "[1368-she]

" [Lunnon]32-lunnon ? Quiet , [ye]481-the man rascals!"--this[481-the man] to the sturdy horses who were dragging away at [their]1395-their shafts in stolid determination to move on--"Lunnon 's a good way off ! [Ever bin]4110-ever bin [there]2972-there ? "[1368-she]

" [I]414-the girl have [no mother]3145-no mother , "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl said .

" Eh , eh ! That 's bad -- that 's bad ! Yet for all that there 's [bad mothers]4118-bad mothers wot 's worse than none . Git on wi ' ye!"--this[1368-she] in a stentorian voice to the horses , accompanied by a sounding crack of the whip . " Git on ! "[1368-she]

The big strong creatures tugged at the shafts and obeyed , [their]1398-their hoofs making a noisy clatter in the silence of the dawn . The daylight was beginning to declare itself more openly , and away to the east , just above a line of dark trees , the sky showed pale suggestions of amber and of rose . [Innocent]152-innocent sat very silent ; [she]152-innocent was almost afraid of the coming light lest by chance [the man beside [her]152-innocent]450-the man beside her should ever have seen [her]152-innocent before and recognise [her]152-innocent . [His]1397-e sleep having been broken , [he]1397-e was disposed to be garrulous .

" Ever bin by [train]4119-train afore ? "[1397-e] [he]1397-e asked .

" No . "[1397-e]

" No ! Eh , that 's mighty cur'ous . A'most [everyone]511-everyone goes somewhere by [train]4119-train nowadays -- there 's such a sight o ' cheap ' scursions . [I]1397-e know [a man]2681-a man wot got up [i]1397-e ' the middle o ' night , ' [e]1397-e did , an ' more fool ' [e!--an]4123-e!--an ' off ' [e]1397-e goes by [train]4119-train down to [seaside]4125-seaside for the day--'e'd never seen [the sea]4126-the sea before an ' it giv ' ' [i]1397-e m such a scare as ' [e]1397-e ai n't got over it yet . ' [e]1397-e was main scared with ' is cheap ' scursion ! "[1397-e]

" [I]152-innocent 've never seen [the sea]4126-the sea , "[152-innocent] said [Innocent]152-innocent then , in a low clear tone--"but [I]152-innocent 've read about it -- and [I]152-innocent think [I]152-innocent know what it is like . It is always changing,--it is full of beautiful colours , blue and green , and grey and violet -- and it has great waves edged with white foam!--oh yes!--the [poets]3427-poets write about it , and [I]152-innocent have often seen it in [my]152-innocent dreams . "[152-innocent]

The dawning light in the sky deepened -- and [the waggoner]1400-the waggoner turned [his]1400-the waggoner head to look more closely at [[his]1400-the waggoner girl - companion]1401-his girl - companion .

" [Ye]1401-his girl - companion talks mighty strange ! "[1400-the waggoner] [he]1400-the waggoner said--"a'most as if ye'd been eddicated up to it . " [I]152-innocent do n't read the papers"--and[152-innocent] [Innocent]152-innocent smiled a little as in the widening light [she]152-innocent began to see [the stolid , stupid , but good - natured face of the man--"I]4131-the stolid , stupid , but good - natured face of the man--"i do n't understand [them]4126-the sea . " [You]1400-the waggoner may have heard wrong , "[152-innocent] said [Innocent]152-innocent , gathering more courage as [she]152-innocent realised that the light was now quite clear enough for [him]1400-the waggoner to see [her]152-innocent features distinctly and that it was evident [he]1400-the waggoner did not know her--"London is such [a large place]4137-a large place that there must be all sorts in [it]4137-a large place -- good as well as bad -- [they]4126-the sea ca n't all be greedy for money . " Oh , there 's plenty o ' work done there"--and[1400-the waggoner] [the waggoner]1400-the waggoner flicked [his]1400-the waggoner long whip against the sturdy flanks of [his]1400-the waggoner labouring horses--"I ai n't denyin ' that . "[1400-the waggoner]

" [I]152-innocent 'm a little tired of [the country]2876-the country , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent answered--"I'd like a change . "[1400-the waggoner]

' Ave [ye]1400-the waggoner ever ' era tell of [a place called [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]4142-a place called briar farm ? "[1400-the waggoner]

[She]152-innocent controlled the nervous start of [her]152-innocent body , and replied quietly--

" [I]152-innocent think [I]152-innocent have . A very old place . "[152-innocent]

" Ah ! Old ? [I]1400-the waggoner believe [ye]1400-the waggoner ! "[1400-the waggoner]

[She]152-innocent was silent , affecting not to be interested . [The waggoner]1400-the waggoner went on--

" That 's the sort o ' place to seek service in ! Safe an ' clean an ' ' onest as the sunshine -- good work an ' good pay -- a deal better than a place in [Lunnon]32-lunnon . An ' country air , [my]1400-the waggoner gel!--country air!--nuthin ' like it ! "[1400-the waggoner]

A sudden blaze of gold lit up the trees -- the sun was rising -- full day was disclosed , and the last filmy curtains of the night were withdrawn , showing a heavenly blue sky flecked lightly with wandering trails of white cloud like swansdown . [He]1400-the waggoner pointed eastward with [his]1400-the waggoner long whip .

" Look at that ! "[1400-the waggoner] [he]1400-the waggoner said--"Fine , is n't it ! No roofs and chimneys -- just [the woods]2789-the woods and [fields]4148-fields ! Nuthin' like it anywhere ! "[1400-the waggoner]

[Innocent]152-innocent drew a long breath -- the air was indeed sweet and keen -- new life seemed given to [the world]2693-the world with its exhilarating freshness . But [she]152-innocent made no reply to the enthusiastic comments of [[her]152-innocent companion]488-her companion . Thoughts were in [her]152-innocent brain too deep for speech . Not here , not here , in this quiet pastoral scene could [she]152-innocent learn the way to wrest the golden circlet of fame from the hands of [the silent gods!--it]1406-the silent gods!--it must be in the turmoil and rush of endeavour -- the swift pursuit of [the flying Apollo]1407-the flying apollo ! And -- as [the slow waggon]1408-the slow waggon jogged along -- [she]152-innocent felt [herself]152-innocent drawn , as it were , by a magnet -- on -- on -- [on!--on]238-on!--on towards a veiled mystery which waited for [her]152-innocent -- a mystery which [she]152-innocent alone could solve .

Presently [they]1409-they came within sight of several rows of [ugly wooden sheds with galvanised iron roofs and short black chimneys]1410-ugly wooden sheds with galvanised iron roofs and short black chimneys .

" A'most there now , "[238-on!--on] said the waggoner--"'Ere 's a bit o ' [Lunnon]32-lunnon a'ready!--dirt an ' muck and muddle ! Where [man]567-man do make a mess o ' things ' e makes a mess all round ! Spoils everything ' [e]567-man can lay ' is ' ands on ! "[238-on!--on]

The approaches to [the railway]1411-the railway were certainly not attractive -- [no railway]1412-no railway approaches ever are . Perhaps they appear more than usually hideous when built amid [a fair green country]1413-a fair green country , where for miles and miles one sees nothing but flowering hedgerows and soft pastures shaded by the graceful foliage of sheltering trees . Then the shining , slippery iron of the railway running like a knife through [the verdant bosom of [the land]2904-the land]1414-the verdant bosom of the land almost hurts the eyes , and the accessories of [station - sheds]1416-station - sheds , [coal - trucks]1417-coal - trucks , and the like , affront the taste like an ill - done foreground in an otherwise pleasing picture . A slight sense of depression and foreboding came like a cloud over the mind of poor [little lonely Innocent]152-innocent , as [she]152-innocent alighted at [the station]1418-the station at last , and with uplifted wistful eyes tendered a sovereign to [the waggoner]1400-the waggoner .

" Please take as much of it as [you]481-the man think right , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said--"It was very kind of [you]481-the man to let [me]1400-the waggoner ride with [you]481-the man . "[1400-the waggoner]

[The man]481-the man stared , whistled , and thought . Feeling in the depth of a capacious pocket [he]481-the man drew out a handful of silver and counted it over carefully .

" ' Ere y'are ! "[481-the man] [he]481-the man said , handing it all over with the exception of one half - crown--"Ye'll want all [yer]481-the man change in [Lunnon]32-lunnon an ' more . " Oh no , no ! "[152-innocent] and [Innocent]152-innocent looked distressed--"Perhaps it 's too little -- [I]152-innocent hope [you]481-the man are not wronging [yourself]481-the man ? "[152-innocent]

[The waggoner]1400-the waggoner laughed , kindly enough .

" Do n't [ye]152-innocent mind [ME]481-the man ! "[481-the man] [he]481-the man said--"I'M all right ! Good - day t'ye ! Hope [you]481-the man 'll find [an easy place]4151-an easy place ! "[1400-the waggoner]

[She]152-innocent smiled and thanked [him,--then]152-innocent entered [the station]1418-the station and , finding [the ticket - office]1423-the ticket - office just open , paid a third - class fare to [London]3-london . A sudden thrill of nervousness came over [her]152-innocent . [She]152-innocent spoke to [the booking - clerk]1424-the booking - clerk , peering wistfully at [him]1424-the booking - clerk through [his]1424-the booking - clerk little ticket - aperture .

" [I]152-innocent have never been in [a train]4152-a train before ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , in a small , anxious voice .

[The clerk]1425-the clerk smiled , and yawned expansively . [He]1424-the booking - clerk was [a young man who considered [himself]1424-the booking - clerk [a " gentleman]4153-a " gentleman , "[1424-the booking - clerk] and among [his]1424-the booking - clerk own particular set]1426-a young man who considered himself a " gentleman , " and among his own particular set passed for being a wit .

" Really ! "[1424-the booking - clerk] [he]1424-the booking - clerk drawled--"Quite a new experience for [you]1427-the young clerk ! A little country mouse , is it ? "[152-innocent]

" [I]152-innocent do n't know what [you]1427-the young clerk mean , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , coldly -- and moved away .

[The young clerk]1427-the young clerk fingered [his]1427-the young clerk embryo moustache dubiously -- conscious of a blunder in manners . [This girl]643-this girl was [a lady]1429-a lady -- not [a mere country wench]1430-a mere country wench to joke with . [He]1427-the young clerk felt rather uncomfortable -- and presently leaving [[his]1427-the young clerk office]1431-his office , went out on the platform where [she]643-this girl was walking up and down , and slightly lifted [his]1427-the young clerk cap .

" [I]1427-the young clerk beg [your]643-this girl pardon ! "[1427-the young clerk] [he]1427-the young clerk said , [his]1427-the young clerk face reddening a little--"If [you]643-this girl are travelling alone [you]643-this girl would like to get into [a carriage]4154-a carriage with [other people]3474-other people , would n't [you]643-this girl ? "[1427-the young clerk]

" Oh yes ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent answered , eagerly--"If [you]1427-the young clerk would be so kind-- "[152-innocent]

[He]1427-the young clerk made no answer , as just then , with a rush and crash and clatter , and deafening shriek of the engine - whistle , [the train]1432-the train came thundering in . There was opening and shutting of doors , much banging and confusion , and before [she]152-innocent very well knew where [she]152-innocent was , [Innocent]152-innocent found [herself]152-innocent in a compartment with [three other persons]1433-three other persons -- [one benevolent - looking old gentleman with white hair who was seated opposite to [her]152-innocent , and [a man]2681-a man and [woman]3519-woman , evidently [husband]1437-husband and [wife]1438-wife]1434-one benevolent - looking old gentleman with white hair who was seated opposite to her , and a man and woman , evidently husband and wife . Another shriek and roar , and [the train]1432-the train started -- as it began to race along , [Innocent]152-innocent closed [her]152-innocent eyes with a sickening sensation of faintness and terror -- then , opening them , saw hedges , [fields]4148-fields , trees and [ponds]1441-ponds all flying past [her]152-innocent like scud in the wind , and sat watching in stupefied wonderment -- one little hand grasping the satchel that held all [her]152-innocent worldly possessions -- the other hanging limply at [her]152-innocent side . Now and then [she]152-innocent looked at [[her]152-innocent companions]1442-her companions -- [the husband]1443-the husband and [wife]1438-wife sat opposite [each other]654-each other and spoke occasionally in monosyllables -- [the old gentleman on the seat]1446-the old gentleman on the seat facing [herself]152-innocent was reading a paper which showed its title--"The Morning Post . "[1446-the old gentleman on the seat] Sometimes [he]1446-the old gentleman on the seat looked at [her]152-innocent over the top of the paper , but for the most part [he]1446-the old gentleman on the seat appeared absorbed in the printed page . On , on , on , [the train]1432-the train rushed at a pace which to [her]152-innocent seemed maddening and full of danger -- [she]152-innocent felt sick and giddy -- would it never stop , [she]152-innocent thought?--and a deep sense of relief came over [her]152-innocent when , with a scream from the engine - whistle loud enough to tear the drum of a sensitive ear , the whole shaking , rattling concern came to an abrupt standstill at [a station]1448-a station . Then [she]152-innocent mustered up courage to speak .

" Please , would [you]1449-the old gentleman tell [me--]152-innocent "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent began , faintly .

[The old gentleman]1449-the old gentleman laid down [his]1449-the old gentleman " Morning Post "[1449-the old gentleman] and surveyed [her]152-innocent encouragingly .

" Yes ? What is it ? "[1449-the old gentleman]

" Will it be long before [we]4156-we get to [London]3-london ? "[1449-the old gentleman]

" About three hours . "[1449-the old gentleman]

" Three hours ! "[1449-the old gentleman]

[She]152-innocent gave a deep and weary sigh . Three hours ! Hardly till then had [she]152-innocent realised how far [she]152-innocent was from [Briar Farm]4-briar farm -- or how entirely [she]152-innocent had cut [herself]152-innocent off from all the familiar surroundings of [her]152-innocent childhood 's home , [[her]152-innocent girlhood]1450-her girlhood 's life . [She]152-innocent leaned back in [her]152-innocent seat , and one or two tears escaped from under [her]152-innocent drooping eyelids and trickled slowly down [her]152-innocent cheeks . [The train]1432-the train started off again , rushing at what [she]152-innocent thought an awful speed,--she imagined [herself]152-innocent as being torn away from the peaceful past and hurled into a stormy future . Yet it was [her]152-innocent own doing -- whatever chanced to [her]152-innocent now [she]152-innocent would have [no one]2691-no one but [herself]152-innocent to blame . The events of the past few days had crushed and beaten [her]152-innocent so with blows,--the old adage " Misfortunes never come singly "[152-innocent] had been fulfilled for [her]152-innocent with cruel and unlooked - for plenitude . There is a turning - point in every human life -- or rather several turning - points -- and at each one are gathered certain threads of destiny which may either be involved in a tangle or woven distinctly as a clue -- but which in any case lead to change in the formerly accepted order of things . [We]1453-our may thank [the gods]1454-the gods that this is so -- otherwise in the jog - trot of a carefully treasured conservatism and sameness of daily existence [we]1453-our should become the easy prey of adventurers , who , discovering [our]1453-our desire for the changelessness of a convenient and comfortable routine , would mulct [us]1453-our of all individuality . [[Our]1453-our very servants]1455-our very servants would become [[our]1453-our masters]1456-our masters , and would take advantage of [our]1453-our easy - going ways to domineer over [us]1453-our , as in the case of [" lone ladies "[1455-our very servants] who are often half afraid to claim obedience from [the domestics [they]1455-our very servants keep and pay]1457-the domestics they keep and pay . Ignorant of the ways of [the world]2693-the world and full of such dreams as [the world]2693-the world considers madness]4157-" lone ladies " who are often half afraid to claim obedience from the domestics they keep and pay . ignorant of the ways of the world and full of such dreams as the world considers madness , [Innocent]152-innocent had acted on a powerful inward impetus which pushed [her]152-innocent spirit towards liberty and independence -- but of any difficulties or dangers [she]152-innocent might have to encounter [she]152-innocent never thought . [She]152-innocent had the blind confidence of [a child that runs along heedless of falling]1460-a child that runs along heedless of falling , being instinctively sure that some hand will be stretched out to save it should it run into positive danger .

Mastering the weakness of tears , [she]152-innocent furtively dried [her]152-innocent eyes and endeavoured not to think at all -- not to dwell on the memory of [her]152-innocent " Dad "[121-priscilla] whom [she]152-innocent had loved so tenderly , and all the sweet surroundings of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm which already seemed so far away . [Robin]126-robin would be sorry [she]152-innocent had gone -- indeed [he]126-robin would be very miserable for a time -- [she]152-innocent was certain of that!--and [Priscilla]121-priscilla ! yes , [Priscilla]121-priscilla had loved [her]121-priscilla as [her]121-priscilla own child,--here [her]152-innocent thoughts began running riot again , and [she]152-innocent moved impatiently . Just then [the old gentleman with the " Morning Post "]4158-the old gentleman with the " morning post "[4158-the old gentleman with the " morning post "] folded it neatly and , bending forward , offered it to [her]152-innocent .

" Would [you]152-innocent like to see the paper ? "[1461-he] [he]1461-he asked , politely .

The warm colour flushed [her]152-innocent cheeks -- [she]152-innocent accepted it shyly .

" Thank [you]1461-he very much ! It was what is called " a respectable address"--and[1491-her kind fellow - traveller] [he]1491-her kind fellow - traveller was glad [the child]2985-the child knew where [she]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english was going . In another moment [the taxi]1494-the taxi was off,--a parting smile brightened the wistful expression of [her]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english young face , and [she]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english waved [her]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english little hand to [him]1491-her kind fellow - traveller . And then [she]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english was whirled away among the seething crowd of [vehicles]1495-vehicles and lost to sight . [Old John Harrington]241-harrington stood for a moment on [the railway - platform]1496-the railway - platform , lost in thought .

" [A sweet little soul]4198-a sweet little soul ! "[1491-her kind fellow - traveller] [he]1491-her kind fellow - traveller mused--"I wonder what will become of [her]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english ! [I]1497-i must see [her]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english again some day . [She]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english reminds [me]1497-i of -- let [me]1497-i see!--who does [she]1479-a little country girl making her first journey to london who admitted reading " old french " and elizabethan english remind [me]1497-i of ? By [Jove]242-jove , [I]1497-i have it ! [Pierce Armitage!--haven't]227-armitage seen [him]1497-i for twenty years at least -- and [this girl]643-this girl 's face has a look of [his]1497-i -- just the same eyes and intense expression . [Poor old Armitage!--he]243-poor old armitage!--he promised to be [a great artist]4200-a great artist once , but [he]1497-i 's gone to the dogs by this time , [I]1497-i suppose . [Curious]244-curious , curious that [I]1497-i should remember [him]1497-i just now ! "[1497-i]

And [he]1497-i went [his]1497-i way , thinking and wondering , while [Innocent]152-innocent went [hers]152-innocent , without any thought at all , in a blind and simple faith that [God]80-god would take care of [her]152-innocent .

CHAPTER XII

To be whirled along through [the crowded streets of [London]3-london]1498-the crowded streets of london in [a taxi - cab]1490-a taxi - cab for the first time in one 's life must needs be a somewhat disconcerting , even alarming experience , and [Innocent]152-innocent was the poor little prey of so many nervous fears during [her]152-innocent journey to [Kensington]33-kensington in this fashion , that [she]152-innocent could think of nothing and realise nothing except that at any moment it seemed likely [she]152-innocent would be killed . With wide - open , terrified eyes , [she]152-innocent watched [the huge motor - omnibuses]1500-the huge motor - omnibuses almost bearing down upon [the vehicle in which [she]152-innocent sat]1501-the vehicle in which she sat , and shivered at the narrow margin of space [the driver]1502-the driver seemed to allow for any sort of escape from instant collision and utter disaster . [She]152-innocent only began to breathe naturally again when , turning away out of the greater press of traffic , [the cab]1503-the cab began to run at a smoother and less noisy pace , till presently , in less time than [she]152-innocent could have imagined possible , it drew up at a modestly retreating little door under [an arched porch]1504-an arched porch in [a quiet little square]1505-a quiet little square , where there were some brave and pretty trees doing their best to be green , despite [London]3-london soot and smoke . [Innocent]152-innocent stepped out , and seeing a bell - handle pulled it timidly . The summons was answered by [a very neat maid - servant]1506-a very neat maid - servant , who looked at [her]152-innocent in primly polite enquiry .

" Is [Mrs.--or Miss ' Lavinia]245-mrs.--or miss ' lavinia ' at [home]2674-home ? "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent murmured . " [I]152-innocent saw [her]245-mrs.--or miss ' lavinia advertisement in the ' Morning Post . ' "[152-innocent]

[The servant]1507-the servant 's face changed from primness to propitiation .

" Oh yes , [miss]2677-miss ! Please step in ! [I]1507-the servant 'll tell [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh . "[1507-the servant]

" Thank [you]1152-the maid . [I]1507-the servant 'll pay [the driver]1502-the driver . "[1507-the servant]

[She]152-innocent thereupon paid for [the cab]1503-the cab and dismissed it , and then followed [the maid]1152-the maid into [a very small but prettily arranged hall]1510-a very small but prettily arranged hall , and from thence into [a charming little drawing - room]1511-a charming little drawing - room , with French windows set open , showing [a tiny garden beyond]1512-a tiny garden beyond -- a little green lawn , smooth as velvet , and a few miniature flower - beds gay with well - kept blossoms .

" Would [you]2677-miss please take a seat , [miss]2677-miss ? "[1152-the maid] and [the maid]1152-the maid placed a chair . " [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh is [upstairs]974-upstairs , but [she]239-miss leigh 'll be down directly . "[1152-the maid]

[She]152-innocent left [the room]531-the room , closing the door softly behind [her]152-innocent .

[Innocent]152-innocent sat still , satchel in hand , looking wistfully about [her]152-innocent . [The room]531-the room appealed to [her]152-innocent taste in its extreme simplicity -- and it instinctively suggested to [her]152-innocent mind resigned poverty making the best of itself . There were one or two old miniatures on little velvet stands set on the mantelpiece -- these were beautiful , and of value ; some engravings of famous pictures adorned the walls , all well chosen ; the quaint china bowl on the centre table was full of roses carefully arranged -- and there was a very ancient harpsichord in one corner which apparently served only as a stand for the portrait of [a man]2681-a man 's strikingly handsome face , near which was placed a vase containing a stem of Madonna lilies . [Innocent]152-innocent found [herself]152-innocent looking at this portrait now and again -- there was something familiar in its expression which had a curious fascination for [her]152-innocent . But [her]152-innocent thoughts revolved chiefly round a difficulty which had just presented itself -- [she]152-innocent had no real name . What name could [she]152-innocent take to be known by for the moment ? [She]152-innocent would not call [herself]152-innocent " [Jocelyn"--she]246-jocelyn"--she[152-innocent] felt [she]152-innocent had no right to do so . " [Ena]247-ena armitage "[152-innocent] might pass muster for an abbreviation of " [Innocent"--she]248-innocent"--she[152-innocent] decided to make use of that as a Christian name -- but a surname that would be appropriately fitted to [her]152-innocent ultimate intentions [she]152-innocent could not at once select . Then [she]152-innocent suddenly thought of [the man who had been [[her]152-innocent father]1518-her father and had brought [her]152-innocent as [a helpless babe]1519-a helpless babe to [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]1517-the man who had been her father and had brought her as a helpless babe to briar farm . [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage was [his]1517-the man who had been her father and had brought her as a helpless babe to briar farm name -- and [he]1517-the man who had been her father and had brought her as a helpless babe to briar farm was dead . Surely [she]152-innocent might call [herself]152-innocent [Armitage]227-armitage ? While [she]152-innocent was still puzzling [her]152-innocent mind over the question the door opened and [a little old lady]1520-a little old lady entered -- [a soft - eyed , pale , pretty old lady]1521-a soft - eyed , pale , pretty old lady , as dainty and delicate as [the fairy - godmother of a child]1522-the fairy - godmother of a child 's dream , with white hair bunched on either side of [her]1520-a little old lady face , and a wistful , rather plaintive expression of mingled hope and enquiry .

" [I]1520-a little old lady 'm sorry to keep [you]152-innocent waiting , "[1520-a little old lady] [she]1520-a little old lady began -- then paused in a kind of embarrassment . [The two]1523-the two looked at [each other]654-each other . [Innocent]152-innocent spoke , a little shyly :

" [I]1520-a little old lady saw [your]152-innocent advertisement in the ' Morning Post , ' "[1520-a little old lady] [she]1520-a little old lady said , " and [I]1520-a little old lady thought perhaps -- [I]1520-a little old lady thought that [I]1520-a little old lady might come to [you]152-innocent as [a paying guest]4206-a paying guest . [I]1520-a little old lady have to live in [London]3-london , and [I]1520-a little old lady shall be very busy studying all day , so [I]1520-a little old lady should not give [you]152-innocent much trouble . "[1520-a little old lady]

" Pray do not mention it ! "[1525-the old lady] said [the old lady]1525-the old lady , with a quaint air of old - fashioned courtesy . " Trouble would not be considered ! But [you]152-innocent are [a much younger person than [I]1525-the old lady expected or wished to accommodate]4207-a much younger person than i expected or wished to accommodate . "[1525-the old lady]

" [You]1525-the old lady said in the advertisement that it would be suitable for [a person studying art , or for a scholarship]4208-a person studying art , or for a scholarship , "[152-innocent] put in [Innocent]152-innocent , quickly . " And [I]152-innocent am studying for literature . "[152-innocent]

" Are [you]152-innocent indeed ? "[1525-the old lady] and [the old lady]1525-the old lady waved a little hand in courteous deprecation of all unnecessary explanation -- a hand which [Innocent]152-innocent noticed had a delicate lace mitten on it and one or two sparkling rings . " Well , let [us]4209-us sit down together and talk it over . [I]1525-the old lady have [two spare rooms]4210-two spare rooms -- [a bedroom]4211-a bedroom and [a sitting - room]4212-a sitting - room -- [they]4210-two spare rooms are small but very comfortable , and for these [I]1525-the old lady have been told [I]1525-the old lady should ask three guineas a week , including board . [I]1525-the old lady feel it a little difficult"--and[1525-the old lady] [the old lady]1525-the old lady heaved a sigh--"I have never done this kind of thing before -- [I]1525-the old lady do n't know what [[my]1525-the old lady poor father]4213-my poor father , [Major Leigh]249-major leigh , would have said -- [he]4213-my poor father was [a very proud man]4214-a very proud man -- very proud-- ! "[1525-the old lady]

While [she]1525-the old lady thus talked , [Innocent]152-innocent had been making a rapid calculation in [her]152-innocent own mind . Three guineas a week ! It was more than [she]152-innocent had meant to pay , but [she]152-innocent was instinctively wise enough to realise the advantage of safety and shelter in [this charming little home of]1528-this charming little home of [one who was evidently [a lady]1429-a lady , gentle , kindly , and well - mannered]1529-one who was evidently a lady , gentle , kindly , and well - mannered . [She]152-innocent had plenty of money to go on with -- and in the future [she]152-innocent hoped to make more . So [she]152-innocent spoke out bravely .

" [I]152-innocent will pay the three guineas a week gladly , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said . " May [I]152-innocent see [the rooms]4215-the rooms ? "[152-innocent]

[The old lady]1525-the old lady meanwhile had been studying [her]152-innocent with great intentness , and now asked abruptly--

" Are [you]152-innocent [an English girl]4216-an english girl ? "[1525-the old lady]

[Innocent]152-innocent flushed a sudden rosy red .

" Yes . [I]152-innocent was brought up in [the country]2876-the country , but all [[my]152-innocent people]4218-my people are dead now . "[152-innocent]

[She]152-innocent could hardly breathe -- the threatening tears half choked [her]152-innocent . " [You]239-miss leigh have paid for [[your]239-miss leigh accommodation]4258-your accommodation , and [you]239-miss leigh must have perfect liberty to do as [you]239-miss leigh like , as long as [you]239-miss leigh keep to [my]239-miss leigh regular hours for meals and bed - time . As [she]239-miss leigh spoke [she]239-miss leigh bent forward and on a sudden impulse drew [the girl]414-the girl to [her]239-miss leigh and kissed [her]414-the girl . [Poor lonely Innocent]152-innocent thrilled through all [her]152-innocent being to the touch of instinctive tenderness , and [her]152-innocent heart beat quickly as [she]152-innocent saw the portrait on the harpsichord -- [[her]152-innocent father]1518-her father 's pictured face -- apparently looking at [her]152-innocent with a smile .

" Oh , [you]1553-the gentle old lady are very good to [me]152-innocent ! " [I]152-innocent feel as if [I]152-innocent had known [you]1553-the gentle old lady for years ! [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's eyes grew bright and tender .

" Yes ! "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh answered . " [We]4261-we were [boy]3492-boy and [girl]3068-girl together -- and once -- once [we]4261-we were very fond of [each other]654-each other . [Poor Innocent]253-innocent , who had left [Briar Farm]4-briar farm at dawn without any thought of food , and had travelled to [London]3-london almost unconscious of either hunger or fatigue , was beginning to feel the lack of nourishment , and [she]253-innocent gratefully accepted the suggestion .

" [I]239-miss leigh lunch at two o'clock , "[239-miss leigh] continued [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh . " But it 's only a little past twelve now , and if [you]1553-the gentle old lady have come a long way from [the country]2876-the country [you]1553-the gentle old lady must be tired . [She]253-innocent went to give the order , and [Innocent]253-innocent , left to [herself]253-innocent for a moment , moved softly up to [[her]253-innocent father]1518-her father 's picture and gazed upon it with all [her]253-innocent soul in [her]253-innocent eyes . It was a wonderful face -- a face expressive of the highest thought and intelligence -- the face of [a thinker]1555-a thinker or [a poet]978-a poet , though the finely moulded mouth and chin had nothing of the weakness which sometimes marks [a mere dreamer of dreams]1557-a mere dreamer of dreams . Timidly glancing about [her]253-innocent to make sure [she]253-innocent was not observed , [she]253-innocent kissed the portrait , the cold glass which covered it meeting [her]253-innocent warm caressing lips with a repelling chill . [He]1518-her father was dead -- [this father whom [she]253-innocent could never claim!--dead as [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn , who had taken [that father]1559-that father 's place in [her]253-innocent life]1558-this father whom she could never claim!--dead as hugo jocelyn , who had taken that father 's place in her life . [She]253-innocent was alone in [the world]2693-the world , with [neither [father]1562-father nor [" knight of old "]4267-" knight of old "[1562-father] to protect or defend [her]253-innocent]1561-neither father nor " knight of old " to protect or defend her , and on [herself]253-innocent alone depended [her]253-innocent future . [She]253-innocent turned away and left [the room]531-the room , looking a fragile , sad , unobtrusive little creature , with nothing about [her]253-innocent to suggest either beauty or power . Yet the mind in that delicate body had a strength of which [she]253-innocent was unconscious , and [she]253-innocent was already bending it instinctively and intellectually like a bow ready for the first shot -- with an arrow which was destined to go straight to its mark .

Meanwhile on [Briar Farm]4-briar farm there had fallen a cloud of utter desolation . The day was fair and brilliant with summer sunshine , the birds sang , the roses bloomed , the doves flew to and fro on the gabled roof , and [Innocent]253-innocent 's pet " Cupid "[253-innocent] waited in vain on the corner of [her]253-innocent window - sill for the usual summons that called it to [her]253-innocent hand,--but a strange darkness and silence like a whelming wave submerged the very light from the eyes of those who suddenly found [themselves]1564-themselves deprived of a beloved presence -- a personality unobtrusively sweet , which had bestowed on [the old house]1565-the old house a charm and grace far greater than had been fully recognised . [The " base - born "[152-innocent] Innocent]152-innocent , nameless , and unbaptised , and therefore shadowed by the stupid scandal of commonplace convention , had given the " [home]2674-home "[253-innocent] its homelike quality -- [her]253-innocent pretty idealistic fancies about [the old sixteenth - century knight]1566-the old sixteenth - century knight " [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis "[253-innocent] had invested [the place]883-the place with a touch of romance and poetry which it would hardly have possessed with - out [her]253-innocent -- [her]253-innocent gentle ways , [her]253-innocent care of the flowers and the animals , and the never - wearying delight [she]253-innocent had taken in the household affairs -- all [her]253-innocent part in the daily life of [the farm]2744-the farm had been as necessary to happiness as the mastership of [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn [himself]143-hugo jocelyn -- and without [her]253-innocent nothing seemed the same . [Poor Priscilla]255-priscilla went about [her]255-priscilla work , crying silently , and [Robin Clifford]84-robin paced restlessly up and down the smooth grass in front of [the old house]1565-the old house with [Innocent]152-innocent 's farewell letter in [his]84-robin hand , reading it again and again . [He]84-robin had returned early from [the market town where [he]84-robin had stayed the night]1570-the market town where he had stayed the night , eager to explain to [her]253-innocent all the details of the business [he]84-robin had gone through with [the lawyer to whom [[his]84-robin Uncle]514-his uncle [Hugo]143-hugo jocelyn had entrusted [his]84-robin affairs]1571-the lawyer to whom his uncle hugo had entrusted his affairs , and to tell [her]253-innocent how admirably everything had been arranged for the prosperous continuance of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm on the old traditional methods of labour by which [it]4-briar farm had always been worked to advantage . [Hugo Jocelyn]143-hugo jocelyn had indeed shown plenty of sound wisdom and foresight in all [his]143-hugo jocelyn plans save one -- and that one was [his]143-hugo jocelyn fixed idea of [Innocent]152-innocent 's marriage with [[his]143-hugo jocelyn nephew]726-his nephew . It had evidently never occurred to [him]84-robin that [a girl]403-a girl could have a will of [her]403-a girl own in such a momentous affair -- much less that [she]403-a girl could or would be so unwise as to refuse [a good husband]1575-a good husband and a settled home when both were at hand for [her]403-a girl acceptance . [Robin]84-robin [himself]84-robin , despite [her]253-innocent rejection of [him]84-robin , had still hoped and believed that when the first shock of [[his]84-robin uncle]514-his uncle 's death had lessened , [he]84-robin might by patience and unwearying tenderness move [her]253-innocent heart to softer yielding , and [he]84-robin had meant to plead [his]84-robin cause with [her]253-innocent for the sake of [the famous old house itself]1577-the famous old house itself , so that [she]253-innocent might become [its mistress]1578-its mistress and help [him]84-robin to prove [a worthy descendant of [[its]1577-the famous old house itself long line of [owners]1581-owners]1580-its long line of owners]1579-a worthy descendant of its long line of owners . But now ! All hope was at an end -- [she]253-innocent had taken the law into [her]253-innocent own hands and gone -- [no one]2691-no one knew whither . [Priscilla]255-priscilla was the last who had seen [her]253-innocent -- [Priscilla]255-priscilla could only explain , with many tears , that when [she]255-priscilla had gone to call [her]253-innocent to breakfast [she]255-priscilla had found [[her]253-innocent room]787-her room vacant , [her]253-innocent bed unslept in , and the letter for [Robin]84-robin on the table -- and that letter disclosed little or nothing of [her]253-innocent intentions .

[He]126-robin did not follow [her]1587-her , but acting on the sudden impulse of [his]126-robin mind [he]126-robin entered [the house]2762-the house and went up to [[Innocent]152-innocent 's deserted room]1590-innocent 's deserted room . [He]126-robin opened the door hesitatingly,--the little study , in [its]1590-innocent 's deserted room severe simplicity and neatness , looked desolate -- like an empty shrine from which [the worshipped figure]1591-the worshipped figure had been taken . [He]126-robin trod softly across the floor , hushing [his]126-robin footsteps , as though [some one]3392-some one slept whom [he]126-robin feared to wake , and [his]126-robin eyes wandered from one familiar object to another till they rested on the shelves where the old vellum - bound books , which [Innocent]152-innocent had loved and studied so much , were ranged in orderly rows . Taking one or two of them out [he]126-robin glanced at [their]1593-they title - pages;--he knew that most of them were rare and curious , though [his]126-robin Oxford training had not impressed [him]126-robin with as great a love of things literary as it might or should have done . But [he]126-robin realised that these strange black - letter and manuscript volumes were of unique value , and that their contents , so difficult to decipher , were responsible for the formation of [Innocent]152-innocent 's guileless and romantic spirit , colouring [her]152-innocent outlook on life with a glamour of rainbow brilliancy which , though beautiful , was unreal . One quaint little book [he]126-robin opened had for [its]1590-innocent 's deserted room title--"Ye Whole Art of Love , Setting Forth [ye]4323-ye Noble Manner of [Noble Knights who woulde serve [their]4324-noble knights who woulde serve their ladies Ladies]4324-noble knights who woulde serve their ladies Faithfullie in Death as in [Lyfe"--this]38-lyfe"--this[126-robin] bore the date of 1590 . [He]126-robin sighed as [he]126-robin put it back in its place .

" Ah , well , "[126-robin] [he]126-robin said , half aloud , " these books are [hers]152-innocent , and [I]126-robin 'll keep them for [her]152-innocent -- but [I]126-robin believe [they]1593-they 've done [her]152-innocent a lot of mischief , and [I]126-robin do n't love them ! [They]1593-they 've made [her]152-innocent see [the world]2693-the world as it is not -- and life as it never will be ! And [she]152-innocent has got strange fancies into [her]152-innocent head -- fancies which [she]152-innocent will run after like [a child]634-a child chasing pretty butterflies -- and when the butterflies are caught , [they]634-a child die , much to [the child]2985-the child 's surprise and sorrow ! [[My]126-robin poor little Innocent]4328-my poor little innocent ! [She]152-innocent has gone out alone into [the world]2693-the world , and [the world]2693-the world will break [her]152-innocent heart ! Oh dearest little love , come back to [me]126-robin ! "[126-robin]

[He]1594-his sat down in [her]1595-her vacant chair and covered [his]1594-his face with [his]1594-his hands , giving [himself]1594-his up to the relief of unwitnessed tears . Above [his]1594-his head shone the worn glitter of the old armoured device of the " [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis "[126-robin] with its motto--"Mon coeur me soutien"--and[1594-his] only [a psychist]1596-a psychist could have thought or imagined it possible that the spirit of [the old French knight of Tudor times]1597-the old french knight of tudor times might still be working through clouds of circumstance and weaving the web of the future from the torn threads of the past . And when [Robin]126-robin had regained [his]126-robin self - possession and had left [the room]531-the room , there was yet a Presence in [its]531-the room very emptiness,--the silent assertion of an influence which if it had been given voice and speech might have said--"Do what [you]4331-your consider is [your]4331-your own will and intention , but _ [I]1600-the gossips _ am still [[your]4331-your Master!--and]4332-your master!--and all [your]4331-your thoughts and wishes are but the reflex of [MY]1600-the gossips desire ! "[1600-the gossips]

It was soon known in [the village]2885-the village that [Innocent]152-innocent had left [Briar Farm--"run]40-briar farm--"run away , "[1600-the gossips] [the gossips]1600-the gossips said , eager to learn more . But [they]1600-the gossips could get no information out of [Robin Clifford]84-robin or [Priscilla Priday]121-priscilla , and [the labourers on [the farm]2744-the farm]1601-the labourers on the farm knew nothing . The farm work was going on as usual -- that was all [they]1601-the labourers on the farm cared about . [Mr. Clifford]111-mr. clifford was very silent -- [Miss Priday]121-priscilla very busy . However , all anxiety and suspense came to an end very speedily so far as [Innocent]152-innocent 's safety was concerned , for in a few days letters arrived from [her]152-innocent -- both for [Robin]84-robin and [Priscilla]121-priscilla -- kind , sweetly - expressed letters full of the tenderest affection .

" Do not be at all sorry or worried about [me]152-innocent , [dear good Priscilla]121-priscilla ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent wrote . " [I]152-innocent know [I]152-innocent am doing right to be away from [Briar Farm]4-briar farm for a time -- and [I]152-innocent am quite well and happy . [I]152-innocent have been very fortunate in finding [rooms]4333-rooms with [a lady who is very kind to [me]152-innocent]4334-a lady who is very kind to me , and as soon as [I]152-innocent feel [I]152-innocent can do so [I]152-innocent will let [you]121-priscilla know [my]152-innocent address . But [I]152-innocent do n't want anyone from [home]2674-home to come and see [me]152-innocent -- not yet!--not for a very long time ! It would only make [me]152-innocent sad -- and it would make [you]121-priscilla sad too ! But be quite sure it will not be long before [you]121-priscilla see [me]152-innocent again . "[152-innocent]

[Her]1603-her letter to [Robin]84-robin was longer and full of restrained feeling :

" [I]84-robin know [you]84-robin are very unhappy , [you]84-robin kind , [loving boy]4336-loving boy , "[84-robin] it ran . " [You]84-robin have lost [me]152-innocent altogether -- yes , that is true -- but do not mind , it is better so , and [you]84-robin will love [some other girl]4337-some other girl much more than [me]152-innocent some day . [I]152-innocent should have been a mistake in [your]84-robin life had [I]152-innocent stayed with [you]84-robin . [You]84-robin will see [me]152-innocent again -- and [you]84-robin will then understand why [I]152-innocent left [Briar Farm]4-briar farm . [I]152-innocent could not wrong the memory of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis , and if [I]152-innocent married [you]84-robin [I]152-innocent should be doing a wicked thing to bring [myself]152-innocent , who am base - born , into [his]138-the sieur amadis lineage . Surely [you]84-robin do understand how [I]152-innocent feel ? [I]152-innocent am quite safe -- in [a good home]4338-a good home , with [a lady who takes care of [me]152-innocent]4339-a lady who takes care of me -- and as soon as [I]152-innocent can [I]152-innocent will let [you]84-robin know exactly where [I]152-innocent am -- then if [you]84-robin ever come to [London]3-london [I]152-innocent will see [you]84-robin . But [your]84-robin work is on [Briar Farm]4-briar farm -- [[that dear]4340-that dear and beloved home!--and [you]84-robin]4341-that dear and beloved home!--and you will keep up [its]4-briar farm old tradition and make [everybody]736-everybody happy around [you]84-robin . Will [you]84-robin not ? Yes ! [I]152-innocent am sure [you]84-robin will ! [You]84-robin MUST , if ever [you]84-robin loved [me]152-innocent . "[152-innocent] [INNOCENT]152-innocent . "[152-innocent]

With this letter [his]1604-i last hope died within [him]1604-i . [She]1605-her would never be [his]1604-i -- never , never ! Some dim future beckoned [her]1605-her in which [he]1604-i had no part -- and [he]1604-i confronted the fact as [a brave soldier fronts the guns]1606-a brave soldier fronts the guns , with grim endurance , aware , yet not afraid of death .

" If ever [I]1604-i loved [her]1605-her ! "[1604-i] [he]1604-i thought . " If ever [I]1604-i cease to love [her]1605-her then [I]1604-i shall be as stone - cold [a man]2681-a man as [her]1605-her fetish of [a French knight]4344-a french knight , [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ! [Ah]4345-ah , [[my]1604-i little Innocent]4346-my little innocent , in time to come [you]4346-my little innocent may understand what love is -- perhaps to [your]4346-my little innocent sorrow!--you may need [a strong defender]4347-a strong defender -- and [I]1604-i shall be ready ! Sooner or later -- now or years hence -- if [you]4346-my little innocent call [me]1604-i , [I]1604-i shall answer . [I]1604-i would find strength to rise from [my]1604-i death - bed and go to [you]4346-my little innocent if [you]4346-my little innocent wanted [me]1604-i ! For [I]1604-i love [you]4346-my little innocent , [[my]1604-i little love]3207-my little love ! [I]1604-i love [you]4346-my little innocent , and nothing can change [me]1604-i . Only once in a life - time can [a man]2681-a man love [any woman]4350-any woman as [I]1604-i love [you]4346-my little innocent ! "[1604-i]

And with a deep vow of fidelity sworn to [his]1607-his secret soul [he]1607-his sat alone , watching the shadows of evening steal over the landscape -- falling , falling slowly , like a gradually descending curtain upon all visible things , till [Briar Farm]4-briar farm stood spectral in the gloom like the ghost of its own departed days , and lights twinkled in the lattice windows like little eyes glittering in the dark . Then silently bidding farewell to all [his]1607-his former dreams of happiness , [he]1607-his set [himself]1607-his to face " the burden and heat of the day"--that[1607-his] long , long day of life so difficult to live , when deprived of love !

BOOK TWO : [HIS]1607-his FACT

BOOK TWO

CHAPTER I

In [London]3-london , [the greatest metropolis of [the world]2693-the world]1608-the greatest metropolis of the world , the smallest affairs are often discussed with more keenness than things of national importance,--and it is by no means uncommon to find society more interested in the doings of [some particular man]1610-some particular man or [woman]3519-woman than in the latest and most money - milking scheme of Government finance . In this way it happened that about a year after [Innocent]152-innocent had , like [a small boat]1612-a small boat in a storm , broken loose from [her]152-innocent moorings and drifted out to [the wide sea]1613-the wide sea , [everybody who was anybody]1614-everybody who was anybody became suddenly thrilled with curiosity concerning the unknown personality of [an Author]1615-an author . There are so many [Authors]1616-authors nowadays that it is difficult to get up even a show of interest in one of them,--everybody " writes"--from[258-miladi] [Miladi]258-miladi in [Belgravia]41-belgravia , who considers the story of [her]258-miladi social experiences , expressed in questionable grammar , quite equal to the finest literature , down to [the stable - boy who essays a " prize "[1620-she] shocker for a penny dreadful . But this latest aspirant to literary fame had two magnetic qualities which seldom fail to arouse the jaded spirit of [the reading public,--novelty and mystery]1618-the reading public,--novelty and mystery , united to that scarce and seldom recognised power called genius]1617-the stable - boy who essays a " prize " shocker for a penny dreadful . but this latest aspirant to literary fame had two magnetic qualities which seldom fail to arouse the jaded spirit of the reading public,--novelty and mystery , united to that scarce and seldom recognised power called genius . [He]1619-he or [she]1620-she had produced a Book . Not an ephemeral piece of fiction,--not a " Wells "[1620-she] effort of imagination under hydraulic pressure -- not an hysterical outburst of sensual desire and disappointment such as moves the souls of [demimondaines]1621-demimondaines and [dressmakers,--not]1622-dressmakers,--not even a " detective "[1620-she] sensation -- but just a Book -- a real Book , likely to live as long as literature itself . It was something in the nature of a marvel , said [those who knew what [they]1623-those who knew what they were talking about , that such a book should have been written at all in these modern days were talking about , that such a book should have been written at all in these modern days]1623-those who knew what they were talking about , that such a book should have been written at all in these modern days . The " style "[1623-those who knew what they were talking about , that such a book should have been written at all in these modern days] of it was exquisite and scholarly -- quaint , expressive , and all - sufficing in its artistic simplicity,--thoughts true for all time were presented afresh with an admirable point and delicacy that made them seem new and singularly imperative,--and the story which , like a silken thread , held all the choice jewels of language together in even and brilliant order , was pure and idyllic,--warm with a penetrating romance , yet most sincerely human . When this extraordinary piece of work was published , it slipped from the press in quite a modest way without much preliminary announcement , and for two or three weeks after its appearance [nobody]2675-nobody knew anything about it . [The publishers]1625-the publishers [themselves]1625-the publishers were evidently in doubt as to its reception , and signified [their]1625-the publishers caution by economy in the way of advertisement -- it was not placarded in the newspaper columns as " A Book of the Century "[1625-the publishers] or " A New Literary Event . "[1625-the publishers] It simply glided into the crowd of books without noise or the notice of [reviewers]1626-reviewers -- [just one of a pushing , scrambling , shouting multitude,--and]1627-just one of a pushing , scrambling , shouting multitude,--and quite suddenly found [itself]1627-just one of a pushing , scrambling , shouting multitude,--and the centre of the throng with all eyes upon it , and all tongues questioning the how , when and where of [its author]1628-its author . [No one]2691-no one could say how it first began to be thus busily talked about,--the [critics]1630-critics had bestowed upon [it]1627-just one of a pushing , scrambling , shouting multitude,--and nothing of either [their]1630-critics praise or blame,--yet somehow the ball had been set rolling , and it gathered size and force as it rolled , till at last [the publishers]1625-the publishers woke up to the fact that [they]1625-the publishers had , by merest chance , hit upon a " paying concern . "[1625-the publishers] [They]1625-the publishers at once assisted in the general chorus of delight and admiration , taking wider space in the advertisement columns of the press for the " work of genius "[1625-the publishers] which had inadvertently fallen into [their]1625-the publishers hands -- but when it came to answering the questions put to [them]1625-the publishers respecting [its writer]1632-its writer [they]1625-the publishers had very little to say , being [themselves]1625-the publishers more or less in the dark .

" The manuscript was sent to [us]1625-the publishers in the usual way , "[1633-the head of the firm] [the head of [the firm]1634-the firm]1633-the head of the firm explained to [John Harrington]241-harrington , [one of the soundest and most influential of [journalists]1636-journalists]1635-one of the soundest and most influential of journalists , " just on [chance,--it]259-chance,--it was neither introduced nor recommended . [One of [[our]1625-the publishers readers]4352-our readers]4351-one of our readers was immensely taken with it and advised [us]1625-the publishers to accept it . [The author]4353-the author gave no name , and merely requested all communications to be made through [[his]4353-the author secretary]4354-his secretary , [a Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage , as [he]4353-the author wished for the time being to remain anonymous . [We]1625-the publishers drew up an Agreement on these lines which was signed for [the author]4353-the author by [Miss Armitage,--she]260-miss armitage,--she also corrected and passed the proofs-- "[1633-the head of the firm]

" Perhaps [she]260-miss armitage,--she also wrote the book , "[241-harrington] interrupted [Harrington]241-harrington , with an amused twinkle in [his]241-harrington eyes--"I suppose such a solution of the mystery has not occurred to [you]241-harrington ? "[241-harrington]

[The publisher]1637-the publisher smiled . " Under different circumstances it might have done so , "[1637-the publisher] [he]1637-the publisher replied , " but [we]1625-the publishers have seen [Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage several times -- [she]252-miss armitage is quite [a young girl]3593-a young girl , not at all of the ' literary ' type , though [she]252-miss armitage is very careful and accurate in [her]252-miss armitage secretarial work -- [I]1637-the publisher mean as regards business letters and attention to detail . But at [her]252-miss armitage age [she]252-miss armitage could not have had the scholarship to produce such a book . [The author]4353-the author shows a close familiarity with sixteenth - century literature such as could only be gained by [a student of the style of that]4358-a student of the style of that period,--Miss [Armitage]252-miss armitage has nothing of the ' book - worm ' about [her]252-miss armitage -- [she]252-miss armitage is quite [a simple young person]4359-a simple young person -- more like [a bright school - girl]4360-a bright school - girl than anything else-- "[1637-the publisher]

" Where does [she]252-miss armitage live ? "[241-harrington] asked [Harrington]241-harrington , abruptly .

[The publisher]1637-the publisher looked up the address and gave it .

Meanwhile [[Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's little house in [Kensington]33-kensington]1654-miss leigh 's little house in kensington was the scene of mingled confusion and triumph . The " paying [guest"--the[0-i] little unobtrusive girl , with all [her]239-miss leigh wardrobe in a satchel and [her]239-miss leigh legacy of four hundred pounds in bank - notes tucked into [her]239-miss leigh bosom]4387-guest"--the little unobtrusive girl , with all her wardrobe in a satchel and her legacy of four hundred pounds in bank - notes tucked into her bosom -- had achieved a success beyond [her]239-miss leigh wildest dreams , and now had only to declare [her]239-miss leigh identity to become [a " celebrity]4388-a " celebrity . "[239-miss leigh] [Miss Lavinia]239-miss leigh had been for some days in a state of nervous excitement , knowing that it was [Innocent]152-innocent 's first literary effort which had created such a sensation . By this time [she]239-miss leigh had learned all [the girl]414-the girl 's history -- [Innocent]152-innocent had told [her]239-miss leigh everything , save and except the one fact of [her]239-miss leigh parentage,--and this [she]239-miss leigh held back , not out of shame for [herself]239-miss leigh , but consideration for the memory of [the handsome man whose portrait stood on the silent harpsichord]1656-the handsome man whose portrait stood on the silent harpsichord . "[239-miss leigh] So by degrees , [Innocent]152-innocent found [herself]152-innocent among a small choice " set "[239-miss leigh] chiefly made up of the fragments of [the real " old "[239-miss leigh] aristocracy]1678-the real " old " aristocracy , to which [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh [herself]239-miss leigh belonged,--and , with [her]239-miss leigh own quick intuition and inborn natural grace , [she]239-miss leigh soon became a favourite with [them]1679-them all . But [no one]2691-no one knew the secret of [her]239-miss leigh literary aspirations save [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , and when [her]239-miss leigh book was published anonymously and the reading world began to talk of it as something unusual and wonderful , [she]239-miss leigh was more terrified than pleased . [Its]1681-its success was greater than [she]239-miss leigh had ever dreamed of , and [her]239-miss leigh one idea was to keep up the mystery of its authorship as long as possible , but every day made this more difficult . And when [John Harrington]241-harrington wrote to [her]239-miss leigh , [she]239-miss leigh felt that disclosure was imminent . [She]239-miss leigh had always kept the visiting - card [he]241-harrington had given [her]239-miss leigh when [they]1682-they had travelled to [London]3-london together , and [she]239-miss leigh knew [he]241-harrington belonged to the staff of [a great and leading newspaper,--he]1683-a great and leading newspaper,--he was [a man not likely to be baffled in any sort of enquiry [he]241-harrington might choose to make]1684-a man not likely to be baffled in any sort of enquiry he might choose to make . [She]239-miss leigh thought about this as [she]239-miss leigh sat in [[her]239-miss leigh quiet little room]1685-her quiet little room , working at the last few chapters of [her]239-miss leigh second book which [the publishers]1625-the publishers were eagerly waiting for . What a magical change had been wrought in [her]239-miss leigh life since [she]239-miss leigh left [Briar Farm]4-briar farm more than a year , [aye,--nearly]264-aye,--nearly eighteen months ago ! For one thing , all fears of financial difficulty were at an end . [Her]239-miss leigh first book had brought [her]239-miss leigh more money than [she]239-miss leigh had ever had in [her]239-miss leigh life , and [the publisher]1637-the publisher 's offer for [her]239-miss leigh second outweighed [her]239-miss leigh most ambitious desires . [She]239-miss leigh was independent -- [she]239-miss leigh could earn sufficient , and more than sufficient to keep [herself]239-miss leigh in positive luxury if [she]239-miss leigh chose,--but for this [she]239-miss leigh had no taste . [[Her]239-miss leigh little rooms in [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's house]1688-her little rooms in miss leigh 's house satisfied all [her]239-miss leigh ideas of rest and comfort , and [she]239-miss leigh stayed on with [the kind old lady]1689-the kind old lady by choice and affection , helping [her]1689-the kind old lady in many ways , and submitting to [her]1689-the kind old lady guidance in every little social matter with the charming humility of a docile and obedient spirit all too rare in these days when youth is more full of effrontery than modesty . [She]239-miss leigh had managed [her]239-miss leigh " literary "[239-miss leigh] business so far well and carefully , representing [herself]239-miss leigh as [the private secretary of [an author who wished to remain anonymous]1691-an author who wished to remain anonymous , and who had gone abroad , entrusting [her]239-miss leigh with [his]1691-an author who wished to remain anonymous manuscript to " place "[239-miss leigh] with any suitable firm that would make a suitable offer]1690-the private secretary of an author who wished to remain anonymous , and who had gone abroad , entrusting her with his manuscript to " place " with any suitable firm that would make a suitable offer . The ruse would hardly have succeeded in the case of any ordinary piece of work , but the book itself was of too exceptional a quality to be passed over , and [the firm to which it was first offered]1692-the firm to which it was first offered recognised this and accepted it without parley , astute enough to see its possibilities and to risk its chances of success . And now [she]239-miss leigh realised that [her]239-miss leigh little plot might be discovered any day , and that [she]239-miss leigh would have to declare [herself]239-miss leigh as [the writer of a strange and brilliant book which was the talk of the moment]1693-the writer of a strange and brilliant book which was the talk of the moment .

" [I]239-miss leigh wonder what [they]4396-they will say when [they]4396-they know it at [Briar Farm]4-briar farm ! "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh thought , with a smile and a half sigh .

[Briar Farm]4-briar farm seemed a long way off in these days . " [You]239-miss leigh have separated [yourself]239-miss leigh from [[your]239-miss leigh old home]4397-your old home by [your]239-miss leigh own choice in more ways than one , "[84-robin] [he]84-robin wrote , " and [I]84-robin see [I]84-robin have no right to criticise [your]239-miss leigh actions . [She]1694-her was both glad and sorry for [this,--she]265-this,--she would have liked to see [him]84-robin again , and [yet!--well!--she]266-yet!--well!--she knew instinctively that if [they]1695-our met , it would only cause [him]84-robin fresh unhappiness . [Her]1694-her new life had bestowed new grace on [her]1694-her personality -- all the interior intellectual phases of [her]1694-her mind had developed in [her]1694-her a beauty of face and form which was rare , subtle and elusive , and though [she]1694-her was not conscious of it [herself]1694-her , [she]1694-her had that compelling attraction about [her]1694-her which few can resist,--a fascination far greater than mere physical perfection . [No one]2691-no one could have called [her]1694-her actually beautiful,--hardly could it have been said [she]1694-her was even " pretty"--but[1694-her] in [her]1694-her slight figure and intelligent face with its large blue - grey eyes half veiled under dreamy , drooping lids and long lashes , there was a magnetic charm which was both sweet and powerful . Moreover , [she]1694-her dressed well,--in quiet taste , with a careful avoidance of anything foolish or eccentric in fashion , and wherever [she]1694-her went [she]1694-her made [her]1694-her effect as [a graceful young presence expressive of repose and harmony]1697-a graceful young presence expressive of repose and harmony . [She]1694-her spoke delightfully,--in a delicious voice , attuned to the most melodious inflections , and [her]1694-her constant study of the finer literature of the past gave [her]1694-her certain ways of expressing [herself]1694-her in a manner so far removed from the abrupt slanginess commonly used to - day by [young people of both sexes]1698-young people of both sexes that [she]1694-her was called " quaint "[1694-her] by some and " weird "[1694-her] by others of [her]1694-her own sex , though by [men young and old]1699-men young and old [she]1694-her was declared " charming . "[1694-her] Guarded and chaperoned by [good old Miss Lavinia Leigh]239-miss leigh , [she]1694-her had no cause to be otherwise than satisfied with [her]1694-her apparently reckless and unguided plunge into the mighty vortex of London,--some beneficent spirit had led [her]1694-her into a haven of safety and brought [her]1694-her straight to the goal of [her]1694-her ambition without difficulty .
