[He]1739-he ruffled [his]1739-he thick crop of hair and looked at [her]1742-her more or less quizzically .

" [You]1739-he have an air of suppressed enquiry , "[1739-he] [he]1739-he said--"There is something on [your]1739-he mind ! [You]1739-he want to ask [me]1739-he a question -- what is it ? "[1739-he]

A soft colour flew over [her]1742-her cheeks -- [she]1742-her was confused to find [him]1739-he reading [her]1742-her thoughts .

" It is really nothing ! "[1742-her] [she]1742-her answered , quickly--"I was only wondering a little about [your]1739-he name -- because it is one [I]1742-her have known all [my]1742-her life . "[1742-her]

[His]1739-he eyebrows went up in surprise .

" Indeed ? This is very interesting ! [I]1739-he thought [I]1739-he was [the only wearer of such a very medieval appellation]4439-the only wearer of such a very medieval appellation ! Is there [another so endowed]4440-another so endowed ? "[1739-he]

" There WAS another -- long , long ago"--and[1742-her] , unconsciously to [herself]1742-her [her]1742-her delicate features softened into a dreamy and rapt expression as [she]1742-her spoke,--while [her]1742-her voice fell into its sweetest and most persuasive tone . " [He]1739-he was [a noble knight of [France]12-france]4441-a noble knight of france , and [he]1739-he came over to [England]9-england with [the Due d ' Anjou]43-the due d ' anjou when [the great Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was [Queen]4442-queen . [He]1739-he fell in love with [a very beautiful Court lady]4443-a very beautiful court lady , who would not care for [him]1739-he at all,--so , as [he]1739-he was unhappy and broken - hearted , [he]1739-he went away from [London]3-london and hid [himself]1739-he from [everybody in [the far country]4445-the far country]4444-everybody in the far country . There [he]1739-he bought [an old manor - house]4446-an old manor - house and called it [Briar Farm]4-briar farm -- and [he]1739-he married [[a farmer]4447-a farmer 's daughter]4448-a farmer 's daughter and settled in [England]9-england for good -- and [he]1739-he had [six sons]4449-six sons and [daughters]4450-daughters . [I]1742-her used to put flowers on it , just where [his]1739-he motto was carved--'Mon coeur [me]1742-her soutien . ' For [I]1742-her -- [I]1742-her was brought up at [Briar Farm]4-briar farm ... and [I]1742-her was quite fond of the [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ! "[1742-her]

[She]1743-her looked up with a serious , sweet luminance in [her]1743-her eyes -- and [he]1744-he was suddenly thrilled by [her]1743-her glance , and moved by a desire to turn [her]1743-her romantic idyll into something of reality . This feeling was merely the physical one of [an amorously minded man,--he]1745-an amorously minded man,--he knew , or thought [he]1744-he knew , [women]718-women well enough to hold [them]718-women at no higher estimate than that of sex - attraction,--yet , with all the cynicism [he]1744-he had attained through long experience of [the world]2693-the world and its ways , [he]1744-he recognised a charm in this fair little creature that was strange and new and singularly fascinating , while the exquisite modulations of [her]1743-her voice as [she]1743-her told the story of [the old French knight]1748-the old french knight , so simply yet so eloquently , gave [her]1743-her words the tenderness of a soft song well sung .

" A pity [you]1743-her should waste fondness on [a man of stone]4453-a man of stone ! "[1744-he] [he]1744-he said , lightly , bending [his]1744-he keen steel - blue eyes on [hers]1743-her . " But what [you]1743-her tell [me]1744-he is most curious , for [your]1743-her ' [Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis ' must be the missing branch of [my]1744-he own ancestral tree . May [I]1744-he explain?--or will it bore [you]1743-her ? "[1744-he]

[She]1743-her gave [him]1744-he a swift , eager glance .

" [Bore]275-bore [me]1743-her ? "[1743-her] [she]1743-her echoed--"How could it ? Oh , do please let [me]1744-he know everything -- quickly ! "[1744-he]

[He]1744-he smiled at [her]1743-her enthusiasm .

" [We]4454-we 'll sit down here out of [the crowd]1227-the crowd , "[1744-he] [he]1744-he said,--and , taking [her]1743-her arm gently , [he]1744-he guided [her]1743-her to a retired corner of [the studio]1718-the studio which was curtained off to make a cosy and softly cushioned recess . " [You]1743-her have told [me]1744-he half a romance ! Perhaps [I]1744-he can supply the other half . "[1744-he] [He]1744-he paused , looking at [her]1743-her , whimsically pleased to see the warm young blood flushing [her]1743-her cheeks as [he]1744-he spoke , and [her]1743-her eyes drooping under [his]1744-he penetrating gaze . " Long , long ago -- as [you]1743-her put it -- in the days of [good Queen Bess]276-good queen bess , there lived a certain [Hugo de Jocelin]277-hugo de jocelin , [a nobleman of [France]12-france , famed for fierce deeds of arms , and for making [himself]277-hugo de jocelin generally disagreeable to [[his]277-hugo de jocelin neighbours with whom [he]277-hugo de jocelin was for ever at cross - purposes]4457-his neighbours with whom he was for ever at cross - purposes]4456-a nobleman of france , famed for fierce deeds of arms , and for making himself generally disagreeable to his neighbours with whom he was for ever at cross - purposes . "[1750-i]

" It is wonderful ! Will [you]1755-you take [me]1752-i ? "[1752-i]

[She]1754-she gave [him]1755-you a little fleeting , reluctant smile .

" [You]1755-you are making fun of it all , "[1754-she] [she]1754-she said . " That is not wise of [you]1755-you ! [You]1755-you should not laugh at grave and noble things . "[1754-she]

" Of course!--I must do so ! "[1754-she] [she]1754-she answered , simply . " [I]1754-she owe [him]1755-you so much-- "[1754-she] then , fearful of betraying [her]1754-she secret of literary authorship , [she]1754-she hesitated--"I mean -- [he]1755-you taught [me]1754-she all [I]1754-she know . [She]1757-their cheery host rose at once , and [they]1758-they moved away together .

CHAPTER II

Chance and coincidence play curious pranks with human affairs , and one of the most obvious facts of daily experience is that the merest trifle , occurring in the most haphazard way , will often suffice to change the whole intention and career of a life for good or for evil . It is as though [a musician in the composition of a symphony]1759-a musician in the composition of a symphony should suddenly bethink [himself]1759-a musician in the composition of a symphony of a new and strange melody , and , pleasing [his]1759-a musician in the composition of a symphony fancy with the innovation , should wilfully introduce it at the last moment , thereby creating more or less of a surprise for [the audience]1760-the audience . Something of this kind happened to [Innocent]152-innocent after [her]152-innocent meeting with [the painter who bore the name of [[her]152-innocent long idealised knight of [France]12-france]1762-her long idealised knight of france]1761-the painter who bore the name of her long idealised knight of france , [Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis . [She]152-innocent soon learned that [he]143-hugo jocelyn was [a somewhat famous personage,--famous]1763-a somewhat famous personage,--famous for [his]143-hugo jocelyn genius , [his]143-hugo jocelyn scorn of accepted rules , and [his]143-hugo jocelyn contempt for all " puffery , "[143-hugo jocelyn] push and patronage , as well as for [his]143-hugo jocelyn brusquerie in society and carelessness of conventions . [She]152-innocent also heard that [his]143-hugo jocelyn works had been rejected twice by the [Royal Academy Council]46-royal academy council , a reason [he]143-hugo jocelyn deemed all - sufficient for never appealing to that exclusive school of favouritism again,--while everything [he]143-hugo jocelyn chose to send was eagerly accepted by the French Salon , and purchased as soon as exhibited . [His]143-hugo jocelyn name had begun to stand very high -- and [his]143-hugo jocelyn original character and personality made [him]143-hugo jocelyn somewhat of a curiosity among [men]397-men -- one more feared than favoured . [He]143-hugo jocelyn took a certain pleasure in analysing [his]143-hugo jocelyn own disposition for the benefit of [any of [[his]143-hugo jocelyn acquaintances]1766-his acquaintances who chose to listen,--and the harsh judgment [he]143-hugo jocelyn passed on [himself]143-hugo jocelyn]1765-any of his acquaintances who chose to listen,--and the harsh judgment he passed on himself was not altogether without justice or truth .

" [I]143-hugo jocelyn am [an essentially selfish man]4505-an essentially selfish man , "[143-hugo jocelyn] [he]143-hugo jocelyn would say--"I have met selfishness everywhere among [[my]143-hugo jocelyn fellow men]4506-my fellow men and [women]718-women , and have imbibed it as a sponge imbibes water . [I]143-hugo jocelyn 've had a fairly hard time , and [I]143-hugo jocelyn 've experienced the rough side of human nature , getting more kicks than halfpence . Now that the kicks have ceased [I]143-hugo jocelyn 'm in no mood for soft soap . [I]143-hugo jocelyn know the humbug of so - called ' friendship'--the rarity of sincerity -- and as for love!--there 's no such thing permanently in [man]567-man , [woman]3519-woman or [child]2801-child . What is called ' love ' is merely a comfortable consciousness that [one particular person]4511-one particular person is agreeable and useful to [you]4512-you for a time -- but it 's only for a time -- and marriage which seeks to bind [two people]4513-two people together till death is the heaviest curse ever imposed on manhood or womanhood ! Devotion and self - sacrifice are merest folly -- [the people [you]4512-you sacrifice [yourself]4512-you for]4514-the people you sacrifice yourself for are never worth it , and devotion is generally , if not always , misplaced . The only thing to do in this life is to look after yourself,--serve [yourself]4512-you -- please [yourself]4512-you ! [No one]2691-no one will do anything for [you]4512-you unless [they]2691-no one can get something out of it for [their]2691-no one own advantage,--you're bound to follow the general example ! "[143-hugo jocelyn]

Notwithstanding this candid confession of cynical egotism , [the man]481-the man had greatness in [him]481-the man , and [those who knew [his]481-the man works]1768-those who knew his works readily recognised [his]481-the man power . The impression [he]481-the man had made on [Innocent]152-innocent 's guileless and romantic nature was beyond analysis,--she did not try to understand it [herself]152-innocent . [His]481-the man name and the connection [he]481-the man had with [the old French knight of [her]152-innocent childhood]1769-the old french knight of her childhood 's dreams and fancies had moved and roused [her]152-innocent to a new interest in life -- and just as [she]152-innocent had hitherto been unwilling to betray the secret of [her]152-innocent literary authorship , [she]152-innocent was now eager to have it declared -- for one reason only,--that [he]481-the man might perhaps think well of [her]152-innocent . Whereby it will be seen that [the poor child , endowed with a singular genius]1770-the poor child , endowed with a singular genius as [she]152-innocent was , knew nothing of [men]397-men and [their]397-men never - failing contempt for the achievements of [gifted women]1772-gifted women . Delicate of taste and sensitive in temperament [she]152-innocent was the very last sort of creature to realise the ugly truth that [men]397-men , taken en masse , consider [women]718-women in one only way -- that of sex,--as [the lower half of man]1775-the lower half of man , necessary to [man]567-man 's continuance , but always the mere vessel of [his]567-man pleasure . To [her]152-innocent , [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was the wonderful realisation of an ideal,--but [she]152-innocent was very silent concerning him,--reserved and almost cold . This rather surprised [good Miss Lavinia Leigh]239-miss leigh , whose romantic tendencies had been greatly stirred by the story of [the knight of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]1777-the knight of briar farm and the discovery of [a descendant of [the same family]740-the same family]1778-a descendant of the same family in [one of [the most admired artists of the day]1781-the most admired artists of the day]1780-one of the most admired artists of the day . [They]1782-they visited [[Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn 's studio]1783-jocelyn 's studio together -- a vast , bare place , wholly unadorned by the tawdry paraphernalia which is sometimes affected by [third - rate men]1784-third - rate men to create an " art "[1785-dealers] impression on the minds of the uninstructed -- and [they]1782-they had stood lost in wonder and admiration before a great picture [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was painting on commission , entitled " [Wild Weather]47-wild weather . "[102-amadis de jocelyn] It was what is called by [dealers]1785-dealers an " important work , "[1785-dealers] and represented night closing in over [a sea lashed into fury by the sweep of a stormy wind]1786-a sea lashed into fury by the sweep of a stormy wind . So faithfully was the scene of terror and elemental confusion rendered that it was like nature itself , and the imaginative eye almost looked for the rising waves to tumble liquidly from the painted canvas and break on the floor in stretches of creamy foam . [Gentle Miss Leigh]279-miss leigh was conscious of a sudden beating of the heart as [she]279-miss leigh looked at this masterpiece of form and colour,--it reminded [her]279-miss leigh of the work of [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage . [She]279-miss leigh ventured to say so , with a little hesitation , and [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn caught at the name .

" [Armitage?--Yes]280-armitage?--yes -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was beginning to be rather famous some five - and - twenty years ago -- [I]102-amadis de jocelyn wonder what became of [him]102-amadis de jocelyn ? [He]102-amadis de jocelyn promised great things . By the way"--and[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn turned to Innocent--"YOUR name is [Armitage]227-armitage ! Any relation to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

The colour rushed to [her]279-miss leigh cheeks and fled again , leaving [her]279-miss leigh very pale .

" No , "[279-miss leigh] [she]279-miss leigh answered .

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn looked at [her]279-miss leigh inquisitively .

" Well , [Armitage]227-armitage is not as outlandish a name as [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn , "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn said--"You will hardly find two of ME!--and [I]102-amadis de jocelyn expect [I]102-amadis de jocelyn shall hardly find two of [YOU]279-miss leigh ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn smiled--"especially if what [I]102-amadis de jocelyn have heard is anything more than rumour ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[Her]279-miss leigh eyes filled with an eager light .

" What do [you]279-miss leigh mean ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn laughed,--yet in [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn was conscious of a certain embarrassment .

" Well!--that [a certain ' Innocent ' young lady]4516-a certain ' innocent ' young lady is [a great author]4517-a great author ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn said--"There ! [You]279-miss leigh have it ! [I]279-miss leigh 'm loth to believe it , and hope the report is n't true , for [I]279-miss leigh 'm afraid of [clever women]4518-clever women ! Indeed [I]279-miss leigh avoid [them]4518-clever women whenever [I]279-miss leigh can ! "[279-miss leigh]

A sudden sense of hopelessness and loss fell over [her]279-miss leigh like a cloud -- [her]279-miss leigh lips quivered .

" Why should [you]102-amadis de jocelyn do so ? "[279-miss leigh] [she]279-miss leigh asked--"We do not avoid [clever men]4519-clever men ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn smiled .

" Ah ! That is different ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[She]279-miss leigh was silent . [Miss Leigh]279-miss leigh looked a little distressed .

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn went on lightly .

" [[My]102-amadis de jocelyn dear]3270-my dear [Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage , do n't be angry with [me]102-amadis de jocelyn ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn said--"You are so delightfully ignorant of the ways of [our]4521-we sex , and [I]102-amadis de jocelyn for one heartily wish [you]3270-my dear might always remain so ! But [[we]4521-we [men]397-men]4522-we men are proverbially selfish - and [we]4521-we like to consider cleverness , or ' genius ' if [you]3270-my dear will , as [our]4521-we own exclusive property . [He]84-robin got [her]121-priscilla first book and read it with astonishment and admiration , utterly confounded by its brilliancy and power . " So [I]84-robin 've had something of a hand in it all ! "[84-robin] [he]84-robin said , cheerily--"I'm glad of that ! "[84-robin] [He]84-robin laughed kindly as [he]84-robin spoke--"And [you]4580-you are still [a little girl!--or]4584-a little girl!--or [you]4580-you look one ! "[84-robin]

CHAPTER III

Some weeks later on , when the [London]3-london season was at its height , and Fashion , [that frilled and furbelowed goddess]1821-that frilled and furbelowed goddess , sat enthroned in state , controlling the moods of the Elect and Select which [she]239-miss leigh chooses to call " society , "[239-miss leigh] [Innocent]152-innocent was invited to [the house of [a well - known Duchess]1823-a well - known duchess]1822-the house of a well - known duchess , renowned for a handsome personality , and also for an unassailable position , notwithstanding certain sinister rumours . [People]2701-people said -- [people]2701-people are always saying something!--that [her]239-miss leigh morals were easy - going , but [everyone]511-everyone agreed that [her]239-miss leigh taste was unimpeachable . [She]152-innocent -- [this great lady whose rank permitted [her]152-innocent to entertain [the King]1828-the king and [Queen]4442-queen]1827-this great lady whose rank permitted her to entertain the king and queen -- heard of " [Ena Armitage]247-ena armitage "[152-innocent] as [the brilliant author whose books were the talk of [the town]2918-the town]1830-the brilliant author whose books were the talk of the town , and forthwith made up [her]152-innocent mind that [she]152-innocent must be seen at [[her]152-innocent house]1832-her house as the " sensation "[152-innocent] of at least one evening . To this end [she]152-innocent glided in [her]152-innocent noiseless , satin - cushioned motor brougham up to the door of [[Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's modest little dwelling]1833-miss leigh 's modest little dwelling and left the necessary slips of pasteboard bearing [her]152-innocent titled name , with similar slips on behalf of [[her]152-innocent husband]1834-her husband [the Duke]4465-the duke , for [Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage and [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh . The slips were followed in due course by a more imposing and formal card of invitation to a " Reception and Small Dance . R.S.V.P. "[239-miss leigh] On receiving this , [good old Miss Lavinia]239-miss leigh was a little fluttered and excited , and turning it over and over in [her]239-miss leigh hand , looked at [Innocent]152-innocent with a kind of nervous anxiety .

" [I]239-miss leigh think [we]4630-we ought to go , [[my]239-miss leigh dear]3270-my dear , "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh said--"or rather -- [I]239-miss leigh do n't know about [myself]239-miss leigh -- but [YOU]152-innocent ought to go certainly . [Innocent]152-innocent lifted [her]152-innocent eyebrows with a slight , almost weary smile . A scarcely perceptible change had come over [her]152-innocent of late -- a change too subtle to be noticed by [anyone who was not as keenly observant as [Miss Lavinia]239-miss leigh]1836-anyone who was not as keenly observant as miss lavinia -- but it was sufficient to give [the old lady who loved [her]152-innocent cause for a suspicion of trouble]1837-the old lady who loved her cause for a suspicion of trouble .

" What is it to be modern ? "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent asked--"In [your]152-innocent sense , [I]239-miss leigh mean ? [I]239-miss leigh know what is called ' modern ' generally -- bad art , bad literature , bad manners and bad taste ! But what do [YOU]152-innocent call modern ? "[239-miss leigh]

[Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh considered -- looking at [the girl with steadfast , kindly eyes]1838-the girl with steadfast , kindly eyes .

" [You]152-innocent speak a trifle bitterly -- for [YOU]152-innocent , [dear child]3016-dear child ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said--"These things [you]152-innocent name as ' modern ' truly are so , but they are ancient as well ! [The world]2693-the world has altered very little , [I]239-miss leigh think . [Innocent]152-innocent laughed -- a soft little laugh of tenderness .

" [Wise godmother]4638-wise godmother ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , playfully--"You talk like a book ! "[152-innocent]

" [Naughty child]4639-naughty child , [you]152-innocent are making fun of [me]152-innocent ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said--"What [I]239-miss leigh meant about [the Duchess--]285-the duchess-- "[239-miss leigh]

" Who would not ! "[414-the girl] murmured [the girl]414-the girl , scarcely audibly .

[Innocent]152-innocent said nothing for a minute or two -- then [she]152-innocent looked up , brightly .

" To go or not to go , godmother mine ! Which is it to be ? The decision rests with [you]414-the girl ! Yes , or no ? "[152-innocent]

"[239-miss leigh]

[The girl]414-the girl gave a slight gesture of indifference and moved away slowly and listlessly , as though fatigued by the mere effort of speech . " [She]414-the girl grows prettier every day , "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl thought--"But not happier , [I]152-innocent fear!--not happier , [poor child]4174-poor child ! "[152-innocent]

[Innocent]152-innocent meanwhile , [upstairs]974-upstairs in [[her]152-innocent own little study]1843-her own little study , was reading and re - reading a brief letter which had come for [her]152-innocent by the same post that had delivered [the Duchess]4640-the duchess 's invitation .

" [I]152-innocent hear [you]414-the girl are among [the guests invited to [the Duchess of [Deanshire]50-deanshire 's party]49-the duchess of deanshire 's party]4647-the guests invited to the duchess of deanshire 's party , "[152-innocent] it ran--"I hope [you]414-the girl will go -- for the purely selfish reason that [I]152-innocent want to meet [you]414-the girl [there]2972-there . [Hers]414-the girl is [a great house with plenty of room]4649-a great house with plenty of room , and [a fine garden]4650-a fine garden -- for [London]3-london . People crowd to [her]414-the girl ' crushes ' , but [one]2752-one can always escape [the mob]4652-the mob . [I]152-innocent have seen so little of [you]414-the girl lately , and [you]414-the girl are now so famous that [I]152-innocent shall think [myself]152-innocent lucky if [I]152-innocent may touch the hem of [your]414-the girl garment . When will [you]414-the girl take [me]152-innocent to [Briar Farm]4-briar farm ? [I]152-innocent should like to see [the tomb of [[my]152-innocent very ancestral uncle]4654-my very ancestral uncle]4653-the tomb of my very ancestral uncle -- could [we]4655-we not arrange a day 's outing in [the country]2876-the country while the weather is fine ? [I]152-innocent throw [myself]152-innocent on [your]1845-your consideration and clemency for this -- and for many other unwritten things ![152-innocent]

[Yours]1845-your ,

[AMADIS DE JOCELYN]286-amadis de jocelyn . "[286-amadis de jocelyn]

There was nothing in this easily worded scrawl to make an ordinarily normal heart beat faster , yet the heart of [this simple child of the gods , gifted with genius and deprived of worldly wisdom as all such divine children]1846-this simple child of the gods , gifted with genius and deprived of worldly wisdom as all such divine children are , throbbed uneasily , and [her]286-amadis de jocelyn eyes were wet . More than this , [she]286-amadis de jocelyn touched the signature,--the long - familiar name -- with [her]286-amadis de jocelyn soft lips,--and as though afraid of what [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had done , hurriedly folded the letter and locked it away .

Then [she]286-amadis de jocelyn sat down and thought . Nearly two years had elapsed since [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had left [Briar Farm]4-briar farm , and in that short time [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had made the name [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had adopted famous . [She]286-amadis de jocelyn could not call [it]1847-it [her]286-amadis de jocelyn own name ; born out of wedlock , [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had no right , by the stupid law , to the name of [[her]286-amadis de jocelyn father]1518-her father . [She]286-amadis de jocelyn could , legally , have worn the maiden name of [[her]286-amadis de jocelyn mother]1849-her mother had [she]286-amadis de jocelyn known it -- but [she]286-amadis de jocelyn did not know it . And what [she]286-amadis de jocelyn was thinking of now , was this : Should [she]286-amadis de jocelyn tell [her]286-amadis de jocelyn lately discovered second " [Amadis de Jocelyn]286-amadis de jocelyn "[286-amadis de jocelyn] the true story of [her]286-amadis de jocelyn birth and parentage at this , the outset of [their]1850-their friendship , before -- well , before it went any further ? [She]286-amadis de jocelyn could not consult [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh on the point , without smirching the reputation of [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage , [the man whose memory was enshrined in that dear lady]1851-the man whose memory was enshrined in that dear lady 's heart as a thing of unsullied honour . [She]286-amadis de jocelyn puzzled [herself]286-amadis de jocelyn over the question for a long time , and then decided to keep [her]286-amadis de jocelyn own counsel .

" After all , why should [I]286-amadis de jocelyn tell [him]227-armitage ? "[286-amadis de jocelyn] [she]286-amadis de jocelyn asked [herself]286-amadis de jocelyn . " It might make trouble -- [he]227-armitage is so proud of [his]227-armitage lineage , and [I]286-amadis de jocelyn too am proud of it for [him]227-armitage ! ... why should [I]286-amadis de jocelyn let [him]227-armitage know that [I]286-amadis de jocelyn inherit nothing but [[my]286-amadis de jocelyn mother]3020-my mother 's shame ! "[286-amadis de jocelyn]

[Her]286-amadis de jocelyn heart grew heavy as [her]286-amadis de jocelyn position was thus forced back upon [her]286-amadis de jocelyn by [her]286-amadis de jocelyn own thoughts . Up to the present [no one]2691-no one had asked who [she]286-amadis de jocelyn was , or where [she]286-amadis de jocelyn came from -- [she]286-amadis de jocelyn was understood to be [an orphan]1853-an orphan , left alone in [the world]2693-the world , who by [her]286-amadis de jocelyn own genius and unaided effort had lifted [herself]286-amadis de jocelyn into the front rank among [the " shining lights "[1855-the " shining lights " of the day] of the day]1855-the " shining lights " of the day . This , so far , had been sufficient information for all with whom [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had come in contact -- but as time went on , would not [people]2701-people ask more about [her?--who]1857-her?--who were [[her]286-amadis de jocelyn [father]1562-father]1518-her father and mother?--where [she]286-amadis de jocelyn was born?--how [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had been educated ? These inquisitorial demands were surely among the penalties of fame ! And , if [she]286-amadis de jocelyn told the truth , would [she]286-amadis de jocelyn not , despite the renown [she]286-amadis de jocelyn had won , be lightly , even scornfully esteemed by [conventional society]1860-conventional society as [a " bastard "[1861-a " bastard " and interloper] and interloper]1861-a " bastard " and interloper , though the manner of [her]286-amadis de jocelyn birth was no fault of [her]286-amadis de jocelyn own , and [she]286-amadis de jocelyn was unjustly punishable for the sins of [[her]286-amadis de jocelyn parents]1862-her parents , such being the wicked law !

The night of [the Duchess]4640-the duchess 's reception was one of those close sultry nights of June in [London]3-london when the atmosphere is well - nigh as suffocating as that of [some foetid prison where [criminals]1865-criminals have been pacing [their]1865-criminals dreary round all day]1864-some foetid prison where criminals have been pacing their dreary round all day . [Royal Ascot]51-royal ascot was just over , and space and opportunity were given for several social entertainments to be conveniently checked off before [Henley]287-henley . Outside [[the Duke]4465-the duke 's great house]1867-the duke 's great house there was a constant stream of [motor - cars]1868-motor - cars and [taxi - cabs]1869-taxi - cabs ; [a passing stranger]1870-a passing stranger might have imagined [all the world]3597-all the world and [[his]1870-a passing stranger wife]706-his wife were going to [[the Duchess]4640-the duchess 's " At [Home]2674-home]4658-the duchess 's " at home . "[4640-the duchess] It was difficult to effect an entrance , but once inside , the scene was one of veritable enchantment . [She]224-lady blythe moved away then , leaving [Innocent]152-innocent fairly bewildered by [her]224-lady blythe entire coolness and self - possession . " [I]229-lord blythe 'm afraid [you]414-the girl 've caught cold ! "[229-lord blythe] said [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe , kindly--"That will never do ! [She]224-lady blythe smiled assent , looking up at [him]229-lord blythe gratefully and thinking what [a handsome old man]1949-a handsome old man [he]229-lord blythe was , with [his]229-lord blythe tall , well - formed figure and fine intellectual face on which the constant progress of good thoughts had marked many a pleasant line . [[Her]224-lady blythe mother]1849-her mother 's husband!--and [she]224-lady blythe wondered how it happened that [such a woman]4049-such a woman had been chosen for [a wife]2917-a wife by [such a man]1953-such a man !

" [They]4722-they 're going to dance in [the ball - room]4723-the ball - room directly , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe continued , as [he]229-lord blythe guided [her]224-lady blythe through [the pressing throng of people]1954-the pressing throng of people . " [You]224-lady blythe will not be without [partners]4724-partners ! Are [you]224-lady blythe fond of dancing ? "[229-lord blythe]

[Her]224-lady blythe face lighted up with the lovely youthful look that gave [her]224-lady blythe such fascination and sweetness of expression .

" Yes , [I]224-lady blythe like it very much , though before [I]224-lady blythe came to [London]3-london [I]224-lady blythe only knew country dances such as they dance at [harvest - homes]4725-harvest - homes ; but of course here , [you]4726-you all dance so differently!--it is only just going round and round ! " [You]224-lady blythe were brought up in [the country]2876-the country then ? "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe said .

" Yes , entirely . [I]224-lady blythe came to [London]3-london about two years ago . "[224-lady blythe]

" But -- [I]224-lady blythe hope [you]229-lord blythe do n't think [me]224-lady blythe too inquisitive!--where did [you]229-lord blythe study literature ? "[224-lady blythe]

[She]224-lady blythe laughed a little .

" [I]224-lady blythe do n't think [I]224-lady blythe studied it at all , "[224-lady blythe] [she]224-lady blythe answered , " [I]224-lady blythe just loved it ! " Like [Byron]290-byron , [you]1955-i awoke one morning to find [yourself]1955-i famous ! "[229-lord blythe] said [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe , smiling . " [You]1955-i have [no parents]4731-no parents living ? "[229-lord blythe]

[Her]1955-i cheeks burned with a hot blush as [she]1955-i replied .

" No . "[224-lady blythe]

" A pity ! [They]4732-they would have been very proud of [you]1955-i . Here is [the Duchess]4640-the duchess ! "[1955-i]

And in another moment [she]1955-i was drawn into the vortex of a brilliant circle surrounding [[her]1955-i hostess]1878-her hostess -- [men]397-men and [women of notable standing in politics , art and letters]1958-women of notable standing in politics , art and letters , to whom [the Duchess]4640-the duchess presented [her]1955-i with the half kindly , half patronising air of one who feels that any genius in [man]567-man or [woman]3519-woman is a kind of disease , and that [the person affected by it]1962-the person affected by it must be soothingly considered as [a sort of " freak "[1964-she] or nondescript creature]1963-a sort of " freak " or nondescript creature , like a white crow or a red starling .

" [These abnormal people]4734-these abnormal people are so interesting ! "[1955-i] [she]1955-i was wo nt to say . " These prodigies and things ! [I]1955-i love [them]4734-these abnormal people ! [They]4734-these abnormal people 're often quite ugly and have rude manners -- [Beethoven]291-beethoven used to eat with [his]291-beethoven fingers [I]1955-i believe ; was n't it wonderful of [him]291-beethoven ! Such a relief from the conventional way ! When [I]1955-i was quite [a girl]403-a girl [I]1955-i used to adore [a man in [Paris]31-paris]4736-a man in paris who played the ' cello divinely -- a perfect marvel!--but [he]4736-a man in paris would n't comb [his]4736-a man in paris hair or blow [his]4736-a man in paris nose properly -- and it was n't very nice!--not that it mattered much , [he]4736-a man in paris was such [a wonderful artist]4610-a wonderful artist ! Oh yes , [I]1955-i know ! it would n't have lessened [his]4736-a man in paris genius to have wiped [his]4736-a man in paris nose with a handkerchief instead of-- ! well!--perhaps [we]4738-we 'd better not mention it ! "[1955-i] And [she]1964-she would laugh charmingly and again murmur , " [These deaf abnormal people]4739-these deaf abnormal people ! "[1964-she]

With Innocent , however , [she]1964-she was somewhat put off [her]1964-she usual line of conduct ; [the girl]414-the girl was too graceful and easy - mannered to be called " abnormal "[414-the girl] or eccentric ; [she]1964-she was perfectly modest , simple and unaffected , and [the Duchess]4640-the duchess was a trifle disappointed that [she]1964-she was not ill - dressed , frowsy , frumpish and blue - spectacled .

" [She]414-the girl 's so young too ! "[1967-her grace] thought [[her]4640-the duchess Grace]1967-her grace , half crossly--"Almost [a child!--and]4740-a child!--and not in the least ' bookish . ' It seems quite absurd that [such a baby - looking creature]4741-such a baby - looking creature should be actually [a genius]4742-a genius , and famous at twenty ! Simply amazing ! "[1967-her grace]

And [she]1964-she watched the little " lion "[1967-her grace] or lioness of the evening with keen interest and curiosity , whimsically vexed that it did not roar , snort , or make itself as noticeable as certain other animals of the literary habitat whom [she]1964-she had occasionally entertained . Just then a mirthful , mellow voice spoke close beside [her]1964-she .

" Where is the new [Corinne]292-corinne ? [The Sappho of [the Leucadian rock of [London]3-london]3-london]4743-the sappho of the leucadian rock of london ? Has [she]414-the girl met [[her]414-the girl Phaon]4744-her phaon ? "[1969-you]

" How late [you]286-amadis de jocelyn are , [Amadis]286-amadis de jocelyn ! " [They]4750-most women laugh at it ! "[4640-the duchess] [she]4640-the duchess answered , calmly . " But [that clever child]4751-that clever child would not laugh -- [she]4751-that clever child would take it au grand serieux . "[4640-the duchess]

" Would [she]4751-that clever child ? [[My]1969-you dear [Duchess]295-duchess]4752-my dear duchess , [nobody]2675-nobody takes anything ' au grand serieux ' nowadays . [We]4754-we grin through every scene of life , and [we]4754-we do n't know and do n't care whether it 's comedy or tragedy [we]4754-we 're grinning at ! It does n't do to be serious . [I]1969-you never am . ' Life is real , life is earnest ' was the line of conduct practised by [[my]1969-you French ancestors]4755-my french ancestors ; [they]4755-my french ancestors cut up all [[their]4755-my french ancestors enemies]4756-their enemies with long swords , and then sat down to wild boar roasted whole for dinner . That was real life , earnest life ! [We]4754-we in [our]4754-we day do n't cut up [[our]4754-we enemies]4757-our enemies with long swords -- [we]4754-we cut [them]4757-our enemies up in the daily press . It 's so much easier ! "[1969-you]

" How [you]1969-you love to hear [yourself]1969-you talk ! "[4640-the duchess] commented [the Duchess]4640-the duchess . " [I]4640-the duchess let [you]1969-you do it -- but [I]4640-the duchess know [you]1969-you do n't mean half [you]1969-you say ! "[4640-the duchess]

" And [you]1969-you want to steal it if [you]1969-you can , of course ! "[4640-the duchess] and [the Duchess]4640-the duchess laughed . " [Men]397-men always long for what [they]397-men have n't got , and tire of what [they]397-men have ! "[4640-the duchess]

[He]1973-he moved away and was soon beside [Innocent]152-innocent , who blushed into a pretty rose at sight of [him]1973-he .

The ball - room doors were just then thrown invitingly open and entrancing strains of rhythmical music came swinging and ringing in sweet cadence on the ears . [He]1977-he passed [his]1977-he arm round [her]4640-the duchess waist .

" [We]4766-we 'll begin the revelry ! "[1977-he] [he]1977-he said , and in another moment [she]4640-the duchess felt [herself]4640-the duchess floating deliciously , as it were , in [his]1977-he arms -- [her]4640-the duchess little feet flying over the polished floor , [his]1977-he hand warmly clasping [her]4640-the duchess slim soft body -- and [her]4640-the duchess heart fluttered wildly like the beating wings of a snared bird as [she]4640-the duchess fell into the mystic web woven by the strange and pitiless loom of destiny . The threads were already tangling about [her]4640-the duchess -- but [she]4640-the duchess made no effort to escape . [She]4640-the duchess was happy in [her]4640-the duchess dream ; [she]4640-the duchess imagined that [her]4640-the duchess Ideal had been found in [the Real]55-the real .

CHAPTER IV

The first waltz over , [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn led [[his]102-amadis de jocelyn partner]1978-his partner out of [the ball - room]4723-the ball - room .

" Come into [the garden]415-the garden , "[1977-he] [he]1977-he said . " [It]415-the garden 's quite [a real garden for [London]3-london]4768-a real garden for london -- and [I]1977-he know every inch of [it]415-the garden . [We]1980-we 'll find a quiet corner and sit down and rest . "[1977-he]

[She]4640-the duchess answered nothing -- [she]4640-the duchess was flushed , and breathing quickly from the excitement of the dance , and [he]1977-he paused on [his]1977-he way to pick up a light wrap [he]1977-he found on one of the sofas , and put it round [her]4640-the duchess shoulders .

" [You]4640-the duchess must n't catch a chill , "[1977-he] [he]1977-he went on . " But it 's not a cold night -- in fact it 's very close and sultry -- almost like thunder . A little air will be good for [us]1980-we . "[1977-he]

[They]1980-we went together , pacing along slowly -- [she]4640-the duchess meanwhile thinking of [her]4640-the duchess previous walk in that same garden!--what would [he]1977-he , [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn , say of it and of [[her]4640-the duchess " mother]4030-her " mother "[4640-the duchess] if [he]1977-he knew ! [He]1977-he looked at [her]4640-the duchess sideways now and then , curiously moved by mingled pity , admiration and desire,--the cruelty latent in [every man]598-every man made [him]1977-he long to awaken the first spark of passion in that maidenly soul,--and with the full consciousness of a powerful personality , [he]1977-he was perfectly aware that [he]1977-he could do so if [he]1977-he chose . But [he]1977-he waited , playing with the fire of [his]1977-he own inclinations , and talking lightly and charmingly of things which [he]1977-he knew would interest [her]4640-the duchess sufficiently to make [her]4640-the duchess , in [her]4640-the duchess turn , talk to [him]1977-he naturally and candidly , thereby displaying more or less of [her]4640-the duchess disposition and temperament . With every word [she]4640-the duchess spoke [he]1977-he found [her]4640-the duchess more and more fascinating -- [she]4640-the duchess had a quaint directness of speech which was extremely refreshing after the half - veiled subtleties conveyed in the often dubious conversation of [the women [he]1977-he was accustomed to meet in society]1982-the women he was accustomed to meet in society -- while there was no doubt [she]4640-the duchess was endowed with extraordinary intellectual grasp and capacity . [Her]4640-the duchess knowledge of things artistic and literary might , perhaps , have been termed archaic , but it was based upon the principles which are good and true for all time -- and as [she]4640-the duchess told [him]1977-he quite simply and unaffectedly of [her]4640-the duchess studies by [herself]4640-the duchess among the old books which had belonged to [the " Sieur Amadis "[4640-the duchess] of [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]1983-the " sieur amadis " of briar farm , [he]1977-he was both touched and interested .

" So [you]4640-the duchess made quite [a friend of [the Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis]4770-a friend of the sieur amadis ! "[1977-he] [he]1977-he said . " [He]138-the sieur amadis was [[your]4640-the duchess teacher]4771-your teacher and guide ! [I]1977-he 'm jealous of [him]138-the sieur amadis ! "[1977-he]

[She]4640-the duchess laughed softly . " [He]138-the sieur amadis was [a spirit]4772-a spirit , "[1983-the " sieur amadis " of briar farm] [she]1983-the " sieur amadis " of briar farm said--"You are [a man]2681-a man . "[1977-he]

" Well , [his]138-the sieur amadis spirit has had a good innings with [you]4640-the duchess ! "[1977-he] and , taking [her]4640-the duchess hand , [he]1977-he drew it within [his]1977-he arm--"I bear [his]138-the sieur amadis name , and it 's time [I]1977-he came in somewhere ! "[1977-he]

[She]4640-the duchess laughed again , a trifle nervously .

" [You]1977-he think so ? But [you]1977-he do come in ! [You]1977-he are here with [me]1977-he now ! "[1977-he]

[He]1977-he bent [his]1977-he eyes upon [her]4640-the duchess with an ardour [he]1977-he did not attempt to conceal , and [her]4640-the duchess heart leaped within [her]4640-the duchess -- a warmth like fire ran swiftly through [her]4640-the duchess veins . [He]1977-he heard [her]4640-the duchess sigh,--he saw [her]4640-the duchess tremble beneath [his]1977-he gaze . There was an elf - like fascination about [her]4640-the duchess child - like face and figure as [she]4640-the duchess moved glidingly beside [him]1977-he -- a " belle dame sans merci "[1977-he] charm which roused the strongly amorous side of [his]1977-he nature . [He]1977-he quickened [his]1977-he steps a little as [he]1977-he led [her]4640-the duchess down [a sloping path]1984-a sloping path , shut in on either side by tall trees , where there was a seat placed invitingly in the deepest shadow and where the dim uplifted moon cast but the faintest glimmer , just sufficiently to make the darkness visible .

" Shall [we]4774-we stay [here]2907-here a little while ? "[1977-he] [he]1977-he said , in a low tone .

[She]4640-the duchess made no reply . Something vaguely sweet and irresistible overpowered [her,--she]4640-the duchess was barely conscious of [herself]4640-the duchess , or of anything , save that " [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn "[1977-he] was beside [her]4640-the duchess . [She]4640-the duchess had lived so long in [her]4640-the duchess dream of [the old French knight , whose written thoughts and confessions had influenced [her]4640-the duchess imagination and swayed [her]4640-the duchess mind since childhood]1985-the old french knight , whose written thoughts and confessions had influenced her imagination and swayed her mind since childhood , that [she]4640-the duchess could not detach [herself]4640-the duchess from the idealistic conception [she]4640-the duchess had formed of [his]1977-he character,--and to [her]4640-the duchess the sixteenth - century " [Amadis]102-amadis de jocelyn "[1986-this modern man of brilliant but erratic genius , who , if the truth were told , had nothing idealistic about him but his art , which in itself was more the outcome of emotionalism than conviction] had become embodied in [this modern man of brilliant but erratic genius , who , if the truth were told , had nothing idealistic about [him]1977-he but [his]1977-he art , which in itself was more the outcome of emotionalism than conviction]1986-this modern man of brilliant but erratic genius , who , if the truth were told , had nothing idealistic about him but his art , which in itself was more the outcome of emotionalism than conviction . [He]1977-he drew [her]4640-the duchess gently down beside [him]1977-he , feeling [her]4640-the duchess quiver like a leaf touched by the wind , and [his]1977-he own heart began to beat with a pleasurable thrill . The silence around [them]1987-them seemed waiting for speech , but none came . It was one of those tense moments on which sometimes hangs the happiness or the misery of a lifetime -- a stray thread from the web of Chance , which may be woven into a smooth pattern or knotted into a cruel tangle,--a freakish circumstance in which [the human beings most concerned]1988-the human beings most concerned are helplessly involved without any conscious premonition of impending fate . Suddenly , yielding to a passionate impulse , [he]1977-he caught [her]4640-the duchess close in [his]1977-he arms and kissed [her]4640-the duchess .

" Forgive [me]1977-he ! "[1977-he] [he]1977-he whispered--"I could not help it ! "[4640-the duchess]

[She]4640-the duchess put [him]1977-he gently back from [her]4640-the duchess with two little hands that caressed rather than repulsed [him]1977-he , and gazed at [him]1977-he with startled , tender eyes in which a new and wonderful radiance shone,--while [he]1977-he in self - confident audacity still held [her]4640-the duchess in [his]1977-he embrace .

" [You]4640-the duchess are not angry ? "[1977-he] [he]1977-he went on , in quick , soft accents . " No ! Why should [you]4640-the duchess be ? Why should not love come to [you]4640-the duchess as to [other women]4776-other women ! Do n't analyse!--don't speak ! There is nothing to be said -- [we]4777-we know all ! "[1977-he]

Silently [she]4640-the duchess clung to [him]1977-he , yielding more and more to the sensation of exquisite joy that poured through [her]4640-the duchess whole being like sunlight -- [her]4640-the duchess heart beat with new and keener life,--the warm kindling blood burned [her]4640-the duchess cheeks like the breath of a hot wind -- and [her]4640-the duchess whole soul rose to meet and greet what [she]4640-the duchess in [her]4640-the duchess poor credulousness welcomed as the crown and glory of existence -- love ! Love was [hers]4640-the duchess , [she]4640-the duchess thought -- at [last!--she]1989-last!--she knew the great secret,--the long delight that death itself could not destroy,--her ideal of romance was realised , and [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn , the brave , the true , the chivalrous , the strong , was [her]4640-the duchess very own ! Enchanted with the ease of [his]1977-he conquest , [he]1977-he played with [her]4640-the duchess pretty hair as with a bird 's wing , and held [her]4640-the duchess against [his]1977-he heart , sensuously gratified to feel [her]4640-the duchess soft breast heaving with its pent - up emotion , and to hear [her]4640-the duchess murmured words of love confessed .

" How [I]4640-the duchess have wished and prayed that [you]1977-he might love [me]4640-the duchess ! " That [you]4640-the duchess -- well ? Go on ! [I]1977-he must not tell [anybody]3114-anybody -- what ? "[1977-he]

" That [I]4640-the duchess love [you]1977-he ! "[4640-the duchess] [she]4640-the duchess said , in a tone so grave and sweet and angelically tender , that for a second [he]1977-he was smitten with a sudden sense of shame .

Was it right to steal all this unspoilt treasure of love from a heart so warm and susceptible ? Was it fair to enter such an ivory castle of dreams and break open all the " magic casements opening on the foam , Of perilous seas in [fairy lands forlorn "]4801-fairy lands forlorn "[4640-the duchess] ? [He]1977-he was silent , having no response to give to the simple ardour of [her]4640-the duchess utterance . What [he]1977-he felt for [her]4640-the duchess was what [all men]2784-all men feel for [each woman who in turn attracts [their]2784-all men wandering fancies]1996-each woman who in turn attracts their wandering fancies -- the desire of conquest and possession . [He]1977-he was moved to this desire by the irritating fact that [this girl]643-this girl had startled [an apathetic public on both sides of [the Atlantic]56-the atlantic]1998-an apathetic public on both sides of the atlantic by the display of [her]4640-the duchess genius in the short space of two years -- whereas [he]1977-he had been more than fifteen years intermittently at work without securing any such fame . To throw the lasso of Love round [the flying Pegasus]1999-the flying pegasus on which [she]4640-the duchess rode so lightly and securely , would be an excitement and amusement which [he]1977-he was not inclined to forgo -- a triumph worth attaining . But love such as [she]4640-the duchess imagined love to be , was not in [his]1977-he nature -- [he]1977-he conceived of it merely as a powerful physical attraction which exerted its influence between [two persons of opposite sexes and lasted for a certain time]2000-two persons of opposite sexes and lasted for a certain time -- then waned and wore off -- and [he]1977-he recognised marriage as a legal device to safeguard [a woman]2688-a woman when the inevitable indifference and coldness of [[her]2688-a woman mate]2002-her mate set in , making [him]1977-he no longer [a lover]1808-a lover , but [a household companion of habit and circumstance]2004-a household companion of habit and circumstance , lawfully bound to pay for the education of [children]3319-children and the necessary expenses of living . In [his]1977-he inmost consciousness [he]1977-he knew very well that [Innocent]152-innocent was not of the ordinary feminine mould -- [she]4640-the duchess had visions of the high and unattainable , and [her]4640-the duchess ideals of life were of that pure and transcendental quality which belongs to finer elements unseen . The carnal mind can never comprehend spirituality,--nevertheless , [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was a man cultured and clever enough to feel that though [he]1977-he [himself]1977-he could not enter , and did not even care to enter the uplifted spheres of thought , [this strange child with a gift of the gods]2006-this strange child with a gift of the gods in [her]4640-the duchess brain , already dwelt in [them]2007-them , serenely unconscious of any lower plane . And [she]4640-the duchess loved him!--and [he]1977-he would , on that ground of love , teach [her]4640-the duchess many things [she]4640-the duchess had never known -- [he]1977-he would widen [her]4640-the duchess outlook,--warm [her]4640-the duchess senses -- increase [her]4640-the duchess perceptions -- train [her]4640-the duchess like a wild rose on the iron trellis of [his]1977-he experience -- while thus to instruct [an unworldly soul]2008-an unworldly soul in worldliness would be for [him]1977-he an interesting and pleasurable pastime .

" And [I]1977-he can make [her]4640-the duchess happy"--was[1977-he] [his]1977-he additional thought--"in the only way [a woman]2688-a woman is ever happy -- for a little while ! "[1977-he]

All this ran through [his]1977-he mind as [he]1977-he held [her]4640-the duchess hand a moment longer , till the convincing music of [the band]2009-the band and the brilliant lights of [the house]2762-the house warned [them]2011-them to break away from [each other]654-each other .

But , [[my]2041-i child]3006-my child , it 's a hard lot to be alone all one 's days , with only the remembrance of a past love to keep [one]2752-one 's heart from growing cold ! "[2041-i]

"[1525-the old lady]

[She]1525-the old lady turned off the lights , and [they]2043-they went [upstairs]974-upstairs together to [[their]2043-they several rooms]2045-their several rooms .

Once alone , [Innocent]152-innocent flung off [her]152-innocent dainty ball attire,--released [her]152-innocent bright hair from the pins that held it bound in rippling waves about [her]152-innocent shapely head , and slipping on a loose white wrapper sat down to think . [She]152-innocent had to realise the unpleasing fact that against [her]152-innocent own wish and will [she]152-innocent had become involved in mysteries,--secrets which [she]152-innocent dared not , for the sake of [others]2689-others , betray . [Her]152-innocent parentage could not be divulged , because [[her]152-innocent father]1518-her father was [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage , the worshipped memory of [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's heart,--while [[her]152-innocent mother]1849-her mother , [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe , occupied a high social position which must not be assailed . And now -- now , [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was [her]152-innocent lover!--yet [no one]2691-no one must know , because [he]102-amadis de jocelyn did not wish it . For some cause or other which [she]152-innocent could not determine , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn insisted on secrecy . So [she]152-innocent was meshed in nets of [others]2689-others ' weaving , and could not take a step to disentangle [herself]152-innocent and stand clear . Of [her]152-innocent own accord [she]152-innocent would have been frank and open as the daylight,--but from the first , a forward fate appeared to have taken delight in surrounding [her]152-innocent with deceptions enforced by the sins of [others]2689-others . [Her]152-innocent face burned as [she]152-innocent thought of [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn 's passionate kisses -- [she]152-innocent must hide all that joy!--it had already become almost a guilty secret . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn was [the first man that had ever kissed [her]152-innocent since [[her]152-innocent " Dad]4842-her " dad "[102-amadis de jocelyn] died,--the first that had ever kissed [her]152-innocent as [a lover]1808-a lover]2052-the first man that had ever kissed her since her " dad " died,--the first that had ever kissed her as a lover . [Her]152-innocent mind flew suddenly and capriciously back to [Briar Farm]4-briar farm -- to [Robin Clifford]84-robin who had longed to kiss [her]152-innocent , and yet had refused to do so unless [she]152-innocent could have loved [him]84-robin . [She]152-innocent had never loved [him]84-robin -- no!--and yet the thought of [him]84-robin just now gave [her]152-innocent a thrill of remorseful tenderness . [She]152-innocent knew in [herself]152-innocent at last what love could mean,--and with that knowledge [she]152-innocent realised what [Robin]84-robin must have suffered .

" To love without return -- without hope ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent mused--"Oh , it would be torture!--to [me]152-innocent , death ! [Poor Robin]84-robin ! "[152-innocent]

[Poor Robin]300-poor robin , indeed ! [He]84-robin would not have dared to caress [her]152-innocent with the wild and tender audacity of [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn !

" [My]152-innocent love ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent whispered to the silence.--"My love ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent repeated , as [she]152-innocent knelt down to say [her]152-innocent prayers , sending the adored and idealised name up on vibrations of light to the throne of the Most High,--and " [My]152-innocent love ! "[152-innocent] were the last words [she]152-innocent murmured as [she]152-innocent nestled into [her]152-innocent little bed , [her]152-innocent fair head on its white pillow looking like the head of one of [Botticelli 's angels]2054-botticelli 's angels . [Her]152-innocent own success,--her celebrity as [a genius in literature,--her dreams of fame]2055-a genius in literature,--her dreams of fame -- these now were all as naught!--less than the clouds of a night or the mists of a morning -- there was nothing for [her]152-innocent in [earth]2738-earth or heaven save " [My]152-innocent love ! "[152-innocent]

CHAPTER V

[Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe was sitting alone in [[his]229-lord blythe library]691-his library . [He]229-lord blythe was accustomed to sit alone , and rather liked it . It was the evening after that of [the Duchess of [Deanshire]50-deanshire]2058-the duchess of deanshire 's reception ; [[his]229-lord blythe wife]706-his wife had gone to another similar " crush , "[706-his wife] but had graciously excused [his]229-lord blythe attendance , for which [he]229-lord blythe was honestly grateful . [He]229-lord blythe was old enough , at sixty - eight , to appreciate the luxury of peace and quietness,--he had put on an old lounge coat and an easy pair of slippers , and was thoroughly enjoying [himself]229-lord blythe in a comfortable arm - chair with a book and a cigar . The book was by " Ena Armitage"--the[2060-fastidious connoisseurs of tobacco] cigar , one of a choice brand known chiefly to [fastidious connoisseurs of tobacco]2060-fastidious connoisseurs of tobacco . The book , however , was a powerful rival to the charm of the fragrant [Havana]57-havana -- for every now and again [he]229-lord blythe allowed the cigar to die out and had to re - light it , owing to [his]229-lord blythe fascinated absorption in the volume [he]229-lord blythe held . [He]229-lord blythe was [an exceedingly clever man]2061-an exceedingly clever man -- deeply versed in literature and languages , and in [his]229-lord blythe younger days had been [a great student,--he]2062-a great student,--he had read nearly every book of note , and was as familiar with [the greatest authors]2063-the greatest authors as with [[his]229-lord blythe greatest friends]2064-his greatest friends , so that [he]229-lord blythe was well fitted to judge without prejudice the merits of any new aspirant to literary fame . But [he]229-lord blythe was wholly unprepared for the power and the daring genius which stamped itself on every page of [the new writer]2065-the new writer 's work,--he almost forgot , while reading , whether it was [man]567-man or [woman]3519-woman who had given such a production to [the world]2693-the world , so impressed was [he]229-lord blythe by the masterly treatment of a simple subject made beautiful by a scholarly and incisive style . It was literature of the highest kind,--and realising this with every sentence [he]229-lord blythe perused , it was with a shock of surprise that [he]229-lord blythe remembered the personality of [the author]4353-the author -- [the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal "[2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance] at [Her]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance Grace of [Deanshire]50-deanshire 's reception and dance]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance .

" Positively , [I]229-lord blythe can scarcely believe it ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe exclaimed sotto - voce--"That [child]2801-child [I]229-lord blythe met last night actually wrote this amazing piece of work ! It 's almost incredible ! [A nice child]4844-a nice child too,--simple and perfectly natural,--nothing of the blue - stocking about [her]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance . Well , well ! What a career [she]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance 'll make!--what a name!--that is , if [she]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance takes care of [herself]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance and does n't fall in love , which [she]2070-the unobtrusive girl who had been the " show animal " at her grace of deanshire 's reception and dance 's sure to do ! That 's the worst of [women]718-women -- [God]80-god occasionally gives [them]718-women brains , but [they]718-women 've scarcely begun to use them when heart and sentiment step in and overthrow all reason . Now , [we]4846-we men-- "[229-lord blythe]

[He]229-lord blythe paused,--thinking . There had been a time in [his]229-lord blythe life -- long ago , when [he]229-lord blythe was very young -- when heart and sentiment had very nearly overthrown reason in [his]229-lord blythe own case -- and sometimes [he]229-lord blythe was inclined to regret that such overthrow had been averted .

" For the moment it is perhaps worth everything else ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe mused--"But -- for the moment only ! The ecstasy does not last . "[229-lord blythe]

[His]229-lord blythe cigar had gone out again , and [he]229-lord blythe re - lit it . The clock on the mantelpiece struck twelve with a silvery clang , and almost at the same instant [he]229-lord blythe heard the rustle of a silk gown and a light footstep,--the door opened , and [[his]229-lord blythe wife]706-his wife appeared .

" Are [you]229-lord blythe busy ? "[706-his wife] [she]706-his wife enquired--"May [I]229-lord blythe come in ? "[229-lord blythe]

[He]229-lord blythe rose , with the stately old - fashioned courtesy habitual to [him]229-lord blythe .

" By all means come in ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe said--"You have returned early ? "[229-lord blythe]

" Yes . "[706-his wife] [She]706-his wife loosened [her]706-his wife rich evening cloak , lined with ermine , and let it fall on the back of the chair in which [she]706-his wife seated herself--"It was a boresome affair,--there were recitations and music which [I]229-lord blythe hate -- so [I]229-lord blythe came away . [You]229-lord blythe are reading ? "[229-lord blythe]

" Not now"--and[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe closed the volume on the table beside him--"But [I]229-lord blythe HAVE been reading -- that amazing book by [the young girl [we]4848-we met at [the Deanshires]302-the deanshires ' last night]4847-the young girl we met at the deanshires ' last night -- [Ena Armitage]247-ena armitage . It 's really a fine piece of work . "[229-lord blythe]

[She]706-his wife was silent .

" [You]229-lord blythe did n't take to [her]247-ena armitage , [I]229-lord blythe 'm afraid ? "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe went on--"Yet [she]247-ena armitage seemed [a charming , modest little person]4849-a charming , modest little person . Perhaps [she]247-ena armitage was not quite what [you]229-lord blythe expected ? "[229-lord blythe]

[Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe gave a sudden harsh laugh .

" [You]229-lord blythe are right ! [She]247-ena armitage certainly was not what [I]224-lady blythe expected ! Is the door well shut ? "[224-lady blythe]

" The door is quite closed , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe said , rather stiffly . " [One]2752-one would think [we]4851-we were talking secrets -- and [we]4851-we never do ! "[229-lord blythe]

" No ! "[706-his wife] [she]706-his wife rejoined , looking at [him]229-lord blythe curiously--"We never do . [We]4851-we are [model husband]4852-model husband and [wife]1438-wife , having nothing to conceal ! "[706-his wife]

" [You]706-his wife have something to tell [me]229-lord blythe , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe remarked , quietly--"Pray go on , and do n't let [me]229-lord blythe interrupt [you]706-his wife . Do [you]706-his wife object to [my]229-lord blythe smoking ? "[229-lord blythe]

" Not in the least . "[229-lord blythe]

[He]229-lord blythe stood with [his]229-lord blythe back to the fireplace , [a tall , stately figure of [a man]2681-a man]2072-a tall , stately figure of a man , and looked at [her]706-his wife expectantly,--she meanwhile reclined in a cushioned chair with the folds of [her]706-his wife ermine falling about [her]706-his wife , like [a queen of languorous luxury]2074-a queen of languorous luxury .

" [I]706-his wife suppose , "[706-his wife] [she]706-his wife began--"hardly anything in the social life of [our]4854-our day would very much surprise or shock [you--]229-lord blythe ? "[229-lord blythe]

" Very little , certainly ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe answered , smiling coldly--"I have lived a long time , and am not easily surprised ! "[229-lord blythe]

" Not even if it concerned [some one]3392-some one [you]229-lord blythe know ? "[229-lord blythe]

" Some one [I]229-lord blythe know ? "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe repeated--"Well , [I]229-lord blythe should certainly be very sorry to hear anything of a scandalous nature connected with [the girl [we]4854-our saw last night]4856-the girl we saw last night -- [she]4856-the girl we saw last night looked too young and too innocent-- "[229-lord blythe]

" Innocent -- oh yes ! "[224-lady blythe] and [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe again laughed that harsh laugh of suppressed hysterical excitement--"She is innocent enough ! "[229-lord blythe]

" Yes . [I]2075-i went quite willingly -- [I]2075-i took [a maid whom [we]4874-we bribed,--we]4873-a maid whom we bribed,--we pretended [we]4874-we were married , and [we]4874-we had a charming time together -- a time of real romance , till [he]2681-a man began to get tired and want change -- [all men]2784-all men are like that ! " [I]2078-i knew nothing of it ! [Armitage]227-armitage is not an uncommon name , and [I]2078-i did not connect it with [her]4895-the old farmer who had taken care of the child . [She]4895-the old farmer who had taken care of the child has no right to wear it . "[2078-i]

"[2078-i]

" It must have been ! "[2078-i] and a thin ironic smile hovered on [his]229-lord blythe lips--"And [you]4901-you carried it off well ! But -- [the poor]4905-the poor child!--what an ordeal for [her]4895-the old farmer who had taken care of the child ! [You]4901-you can hardly have felt it so keenly , being seasoned to hypocrisy for so many years ! "[2078-i] [Her]2080-her eyes flashed up at [him]229-lord blythe indignantly . [He]229-lord blythe raised [his]229-lord blythe hand with a warning gesture .

" Permit [me]229-lord blythe to speak , [Maude]224-lady blythe ! [You]224-lady blythe can scarcely wonder that [I]229-lord blythe am -- [well!--a]4906-well!--a little shaken and bewildered by the confession [you]224-lady blythe have made,--the secret [you]224-lady blythe have -- after years of marriage -- suddenly divulged . [You]224-lady blythe suggested -- at the beginning of this interview -- that perhaps there was nothing in the social life of [our]4904-our day that would very much shock or surprise [me]229-lord blythe -- and [I]229-lord blythe answered [you]224-lady blythe that [I]229-lord blythe was not easily surprised -- but -- [I]229-lord blythe was thinking of others.--it did not occur to [me]229-lord blythe that -- that [my]229-lord blythe own wife-- "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe paused , steadying [his]229-lord blythe voice,--then continued--"that [[my]229-lord blythe own wife]4907-my own wife 's honour was involved in the matter-- "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe paused again . " Sentiment is of course out of place -- [nobody]2675-nobody is supposed to feel anything nowadays -- or to suffer -- or to break [one]2752-one 's heart , as the phrase goes,--that would be considered abnormal , or bad form,--but [I]229-lord blythe had the idea -- [a foolish one]4910-a foolish one , no doubt!--that though [you]224-lady blythe may not have married [me]229-lord blythe for love on [your]224-lady blythe own part , [you]224-lady blythe did so because [you]224-lady blythe recognised the love,--the truth -- the admiration and respect -- on [mine]229-lord blythe . [I]229-lord blythe was at any rate happy in believing [you]224-lady blythe did!--I never dreamed [you]224-lady blythe married [me]229-lord blythe for the sake of convenience!--to kill the memory of a scandal , and establish a safe position-- "[229-lord blythe]

[She]2081-i moved restlessly and gathered [her]2081-i ermine cloak about [her]2081-i as though to rise and go .

" One moment ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe went on--"After what [you]224-lady blythe have told [me]2081-i [I]2081-i hope [you]224-lady blythe see clearly that it is impossible [we]4911-we can live together under the same roof again . If [YOU]224-lady blythe could endure it , _ [I]2081-i _ could not ! "[2081-i]

[She]2081-i sprang up , pale and excited .

" What ? [You]229-lord blythe mean to make trouble ? [I]2081-i , who have kept [my]2081-i own counsel all these years , am to be disgraced because [I]2081-i have at last confided in [you]224-lady blythe ? [You]224-lady blythe will scandalise society -- [you]224-lady blythe will separate from [me--]2081-i "[2081-i]

[She]2081-i stopped , half choked by a rising paroxysm of rage .

[He]229-lord blythe looked at [her]2081-i as [he]229-lord blythe might have looked at some small angry animal .

" [I]229-lord blythe shall make no trouble , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe answered , quietly--"and [I]229-lord blythe shall not scandalise society . But [I]229-lord blythe can not live with [you]2081-i . [I]229-lord blythe will go away at once on some convenient excuse -- abroad -- anywhere -- and [you]2081-i can say whatever [you]2081-i please of [my]229-lord blythe prolonged absence . If [I]229-lord blythe could be of any use or protection to [the girl [I]229-lord blythe saw last night]4912-the girl i saw last night -- [the daughter of [[my]229-lord blythe friend]3176-my friend [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage]4913-the daughter of my friend pierce armitage -- [I]229-lord blythe would stay , but circumstances render any such service from [me]229-lord blythe impossible . [You]2083-you have that to think about by way of -- consolation?--or reproach ? "[229-lord blythe]

[She]2082-she stood drawn up to [her]2082-she full height , looking at [him]2083-you .

" [You]2083-you can not forgive [me]2082-she , then ? "[2082-she] [she]2082-she said .

[He]2083-you shuddered .

" Forgive [you]2083-you ! Is there [a man who could forgive twenty years of deliberate deception from [the wife [he]2083-you thought the soul of honour]4917-the wife he thought the soul of honour]4916-a man who could forgive twenty years of deliberate deception from the wife he thought the soul of honour ? [Maude]224-lady blythe , [Maude]224-lady blythe ! [We]4918-we live in lax times truly , when [men]397-men and [women]718-women laugh at principle and good faith , and deal with each other less honestly than the beasts of the field,--but for [me]2085-i there is a limit!--a limit [you]2083-you have passed ! [I]2085-i think [I]2085-i could pardon [your]2083-you wrong to [me]2085-i more readily than [I]2085-i can pardon [your]2083-you callous desertion of [the child [you]2083-you brought into [the world]2693-the world]4921-the child you brought into the world -- [your]2083-you lack of womanliness -- motherliness!--your deliberate refusal to give [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage the chance of righting the wrong [he]227-armitage had committed in a headstrong , heart - strong rush of thoughtless passion!--he WOULD have righted it , [I]2085-i know , and been [a loyal husband to [you]2083-you]4923-a loyal husband to you , and [a good father to [[his]227-armitage child]4103-his child]4924-a good father to his child . For whatever [his]227-armitage faults were [he]227-armitage was neither callous nor brutal . [You]2083-you prevented [him]227-armitage from doing this,--you were tired of [him]227-armitage -- [your]2083-you so - called ' love ' for [him]227-armitage was a mere selfish caprice of the moment -- and [you]2083-you preferred deceit and a rich marriage to the simple duty of [a woman]2688-a woman ! [Well!--you]2083-you may find excuses for yourself,--I can not find them for [you]2083-you ! [I]2085-i could not remain by [your]2083-you side as [a husband]3372-a husband and run the risk of coming constantly in contact , as [we]4928-we did last night , with [that innocent girl]4929-that innocent girl , placed as [she]4929-that innocent girl is , in a situation of so much difficulty , by the sins of [[her]4929-that innocent girl parents]1862-her parents -- [[her]4929-that innocent girl mother]1849-her mother , [[my]2085-i wife!--her father]4932-my wife!--her father , [[my]2085-i dead friend]4933-my dead friend ! The position is , and would be untenable ! "[2085-i]

Still [she]2084-she stood , looking at [him]2085-i .

" Have [you]2085-i done ? "[2084-she] [she]2084-she asked .

[He]2085-i met [her]2084-she fixed gaze , coldly .

" Good - night -- and farewell ! "[2084-she] [she]2084-she repeated , with a mocking drawl,--then [she]2084-she suddenly burst into a fit of shrill laughter . " Oh dear , oh dear ! "[2084-she] [she]2084-she cried , between little screams of hysterical mirth--"You are so very funny , [you]2085-i know ! Like -- what's - [his]2085-i - name?--Marius in the ruins of Carthage!--or one of those antique classical bores with [their]4934-their household gods broken around [them]4934-their ! [You]2085-i -- [you]2085-i ought to have lived in [their]4934-their days!--you are so terribly behind the times ! "[2084-she] [She]2084-she laughed recklessly again . " [We]4935-we do n't do the Marius and [Carthage]59-carthage business now -- life 's too full and too short ! Really , [Richard]303-richard , [I]2084-she 'm afraid [you]303-richard 're getting very old!--poor dear!--past sixty [I]2084-she know!--and [you]303-richard 're quite prehistoric in some of [your]303-richard fancies!--'Good - night!'--er--'and farewell ! ' Sounds so stagey , does n't it ! "[2084-she] [She]2084-she wiped the spasmodic tears of mirth from [her]2084-she eyes , and still shaking with laughter gathered up [her]2084-she rich ermine wrap on one white , jewelled arm . " Womanliness -- motherliness!--good Lord , deliver us!--I never thought [you]303-richard likely to preach at [me]2084-she -- if [I]2084-she had [I]2084-she would n't have told [you]303-richard anything !
