Good - night!--and farewell ! "[2084-she]

[She]2084-she performed the taunting travesty of an elaborate Court curtsey and passed [him]2086-he -- a handsome , gleaming vision of satins , laces and glittering jewels -- and opening the door with some noise and emphasis , [she]2084-she turned [her]2084-she head gracefully over [her]2084-she shoulder . Unkind laughter still lit up [her]2084-she face and hard , brilliant eyes .

" Good - night!--farewell ! "[2084-she] [she]2084-she said again , and was gone .

For a moment [he]2086-he stood inert where [she]2084-she left [him]2086-he -- then sinking into a chair [he]2086-he covered [his]2086-he face with [his]2086-he hands . So [he]2086-he remained for some time -- silently wrestling with [himself]2086-he and [his]2086-he own emotions . [He]2086-he had to realise that at an age when [he]2086-he might naturally have looked for a tranquil home life -- a life tended and soothed into its natural decline by the care and devotion of [the wife [he]2086-he had undemonstratively but most tenderly loved]2087-the wife he had undemonstratively but most tenderly loved , [he]2086-he was suddenly cast adrift like the hulk of [an old battleship]2088-an old battleship broken from its moorings , with nothing but solitude and darkness closing in upon [his]2086-he latter days . Then [he]2086-he thought of [the girl,--his wife 's child]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child -- [the child too of [[his]2086-he college chum]2091-his college chum and dearest friend,--he]2090-the child too of his college chum and dearest friend,--he saw , impressed like a picture on the cells of [his]2086-he brain , [her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child fair young face , pathetic eyes and sweet intelligence of expression,--he remembered how modestly [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child wore [her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child sudden fame , as [a child]634-a child might wear a wild flower,--and , placed by [[her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child parentage]2093-her parentage in a difficulty for which [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child was not responsible , [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child must have suffered considerable pain and sorrow .

" [I]2086-he will go and see [her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child to - morrow , "[2086-he] [he]2086-he said to himself--"It will be better for [her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child to know that [I]2086-he have heard all [her]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child sad little history -- then -- if [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child ever wants [a friend]4235-a friend [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child can come to [me]2086-he without fear . Ah!--if only [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child were [[MY]2086-he daughter]4861-my daughter ! "[2086-he]

[He]2086-he sighed,--his handsome old head drooped,--he had longed for [children]3319-children and the boon had been denied .

" If [she]2089-the girl,--his wife 's child were [[my]2086-he daughter]4861-my daughter , "[2086-he] [he]2086-he repeated , slowly--"I should be [a proud man]4941-a proud man instead of [a sorrowful one]4942-a sorrowful one ! "[2086-he]

[He]2086-he turned off the lights in [the library]2095-the library and went [upstairs]974-upstairs to [[his]2086-he bedroom]1059-his bedroom . Outside [[his]2086-he wife]706-his wife 's door [he]2086-he paused a moment , thinking [he]2086-he heard a sound,--but all was silent . Imagining that [he]2086-he probably would not sleep [he]2086-he placed a book near [his]2086-he bedside -- but nature was kind to [his]2086-he age and temperament , and after about an hour of wakefulness and sad perplexity , all ruffling care was gradually smoothed away from [his]2086-he mind , and [he]2086-he fell into a deep and dreamless slumber .

Meanwhile [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe had been disrobed by [a drowsy maid whom [she]224-lady blythe sharply reproached for being sleepy when [she]224-lady blythe ought to have been wide awake]2099-a drowsy maid whom she sharply reproached for being sleepy when she ought to have been wide awake , though it was long past midnight,--and dismissing [the girl]414-the girl at last , [she]224-lady blythe sat alone before [her]224-lady blythe mirror , thinking with some pettishness of the interview [she]224-lady blythe had just had with [[her]224-lady blythe husband]1834-her husband .

" [Old fool]4943-old fool ! "[224-lady blythe] [she]224-lady blythe soliloquised--"He ought to know better than to play the tragic - sentimental with [me]2103-i at [his]1834-her husband time of life ! [I]2103-i thought [he]1834-her husband would accept the situation reasonably and help [me]2103-i to tackle it . Of course it will be simply abominable if [I]2103-i am to meet [that girl]4944-that girl at every big society function -- [I]2103-i do n't know what [I]2103-i shall do about it ! Why did n't [she]4944-that girl stay in [[her]4944-that girl old farm]4945-her old farm - house!--who could ever have imagined [her]4944-that girl becoming famous ! [I]2103-i shall go abroad , [I]2103-i think -- that will be the best thing to do . If [Blythe]224-lady blythe leaves [me]2103-i as [he]1834-her husband threatens , [I]2103-i shall certainly not stay here by [myself]2103-i to face the music ! Besides , who [knows?--the girl [herself]4946-knows?--the girl herself]4946-knows?--the girl herself may ' round ' on [me]2103-i when [her]4946-knows?--the girl herself head gets a little more swelled with success . Such a horrid bore!--I wish [I]2103-i had never seen [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage ! "[2103-i]

Even as [she]2102-her thought of [him]2103-i the vision came back to [her]2102-her of the handsome face and passionate eyes of [her]2102-her former lover,--again [she]2102-her saw [the romantic little village by [the sea]4126-the sea where [they]2106-they had dwelt together as in another [Eden,--she]306-eden,--she]2104-the romantic little village by the sea where they had dwelt together as in another eden,--she remembered how [he]2103-i would hurry up from [the shore]2107-the shore bringing with [him]2103-i the sketch [he]2103-i had been working at , eager for [her]2102-her eyes to look at it , thrilling at [her]2102-her praise , and pouring out upon [her]2102-her such tender words and caresses such as [she]2102-her had never known since those wild and ardent days ! A slight shiver ran through [her]2102-her -- something like a pang of remorse stung [her]2102-her hardened spirit .

" And [the child]2985-the child , "[2102-her] [she]2102-her murmured--"The [child]2801-child -- it clung to [me]2102-her and [I]2102-her kissed it!--it was a dear little thing ! "[2102-her]

[She]2102-her glanced about [her]2102-her nervously -- [the room]531-the room seemed full of wandering shadows .

" [I]2102-her must sleep ! "[2102-her] [she]2102-her thought--"I am worried and out of sorts -- [I]2102-her must sleep and forget-- "[2102-her]

[She]2102-her took out of a drawer in [her]2102-her dressing - table a case of medicinal cachets marked " Veronal . "[2102-her]

" One or two more or less will not hurt [me]2102-her , "[2102-her] [she]2102-her said , with a pale , forced smile at [herself]2102-her in the mirror--"I am accustomed to it -- and [I]2102-her must have a good long sleep ! "[2102-her]

* * * * * * * *

* * * * * *

* * * *

[She]2102-her had [her]2102-her way . Morning came,--and [she]2102-her was still sleeping . Noon -- and nothing could waken [her]2102-her . [Doctors]2793-doctors , hastily summoned , did [their]2793-doctors best to rouse [her]2102-her to that life which with all its pains and possibilities still throbbed in the world around [her]2102-her -- but [their]2793-doctors efforts were vain .

" Suicide ? "[2793-doctors] whispered one .

" Oh no ! Mere accident!--an overdose of veronal -- some carelessness -- quite a common occurrence . Nothing to be done ! "[2793-doctors]

No!--nothing to be done ! [Her]2102-her slumber had deepened into that strange stillness which [we]2110-we call death,--and [[her]2102-her husband]1834-her husband , a statuesque and rigid figure , gazed on [her]2102-her quiet body with tearless eyes .

" Good - night ! "[1834-her husband] [he]1834-her husband whispered to the heavy silence--"Good - night ! Farewell ! "[1834-her husband]

CHAPTER VI

One of the advantages or disadvantages of the way in which [we]2110-we live in these modern days is that [we]2110-we are ceasing to feel . That is to say [we]2110-we do not permit [ourselves]2110-we to be affected by either death or misfortune , provided these natural calamities leave [[our]2110-we own persons]2112-our own persons unscathed . [We]2110-we are beginning not to understand emotion except as a phase of bad manners , and [we]2110-we cultivate an apathetic , soulless indifference to events of great moment whether triumphant or tragic , whenever they do not involve [our]2110-we own well - being and creature comforts . [Whole boatloads of fishermen]2113-whole boatloads of fishermen may go forth to [their]2113-whole boatloads of fishermen doom in the teeth of a gale without moving [us]2110-we to pity so long as [we]2110-we have [our]2110-we well - fried sole or grilled cod for breakfast,--and even such appalling disasters as the wicked assassination of [hapless monarchs]2114-hapless monarchs , or the wrecks of palatial ocean - liners with more than [a thousand human beings]2115-a thousand human beings all whelmed at once in [the pitiless depths of [the sea]4126-the sea]2116-the pitiless depths of the sea , leave [us]2110-we cold , save for the uplifting of [our]2110-we eyes and shoulders during an hour or so,--an expression of slight shock , followed by forgetfulness . [Air - men , recklessly braving the spaces of the sky]2118-air - men , recklessly braving the spaces of the sky , fall headlong , and are smashed to mutilated atoms every month or so , without rousing [us]2110-we to more than a passing comment , and a chorus of " How dreadful ! "[171-shakespeare] from simpering women,--and [the greatest and best man alive]2119-the greatest and best man alive can not hope for long remembrance by [the world]2693-the world at large when [he]2119-the greatest and best man alive dies . [Shakespeare]171-shakespeare recognised this tendency in callous human nature when [he]171-shakespeare made [his]171-shakespeare Hamlet say--

" O heavens ! Die two months ago and not forgotten yet ? Then there 's hope [a great man]4949-a great man 's memory may outlive [his]4949-a great man life half a year , but by ' r [lady]4297-lady , [he]4949-a great man must build [churches]4951-churches then , or else shall [he]4949-a great man suffer not thinking on . "[171-shakespeare]

[Wives]2121-wives recover the loss of [[their]2121-wives husbands]2122-their husbands with amazing rapidity,--husbands " get over "[2118-air - men , recklessly braving the spaces of the sky] the demise of [[their]2118-air - men , recklessly braving the spaces of the sky wives]2123-their wives with the galloping ease of [trained hunters]2124-trained hunters leaping an accustomed fence -- [families]2125-families forget [their]2125-families dead as resolutely as [some debtors]2126-some debtors forget [their]2126-some debtors bills,--and to express sorrow , pity , tenderness , affection , or any sort of " sentiment "[2752-one] whatever is to expose [one]2752-one 's self to derision and contempt from [the " normal "[2128-the " normal " modernist who cultivates cynicism as a fine art] modernist who cultivates cynicism as a fine art]2128-the " normal " modernist who cultivates cynicism as a fine art . [Many of [us]2130-us]2129-many of us elect to live , each one , in [a little back - yard garden of selfish interests]2131-a little back - yard garden of selfish interests -- walled round carefully , and guarded against possible intrusion by uplifted spikes of conventionalism,--the door is kept jealously closed -- and only now and then does some impulsive spirit bolder than the rest , venture to put up a ladder and peep over the wall . Shut in with various favourite forms of hypocrisy and cowardice , [each little unit]2132-each little unit passes [its]2132-each little unit short life in mistrusting [[its]2132-each little unit neighbour unit]2133-its neighbour unit , and death finds none of [them]2134-them wiser , better or nearer the utmost good than when [they]2134-them were first uselessly born .

Among such vain and unprofitable atoms of life [Lady Maude Blythe]224-lady blythe had been [one of the vainest and most unprofitable,--though of such " social "[2135-one of the vainest and most unprofitable,--though of such " social " importance as to be] importance as to be]2135-one of the vainest and most unprofitable,--though of such " social " importance as to be held in respectful awe by [tuft - hunters and parasites , who feed on the rich]2136-tuft - hunters and parasites , who feed on the rich as the green - fly feeds on the rose . The news of [her]224-lady blythe sudden death briefly chronicled by the fashionable intelligence columns of the press with the usual--"We deeply regret"--created[2137-a few vapid people] no very sorrowful sensation -- [a few vapid people]2137-a few vapid people idly remarked to one another--"Then [her]224-lady blythe great ball wo n't come off!"--somewhat[2137-a few vapid people] as if [she]224-lady blythe had retired into the grave to avoid the trouble and expense of the function . Cards inscribed--"Sympathy and kind enquiries"--were[2137-a few vapid people] left for [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe in the care of [[his]229-lord blythe dignified butler , who received [them]2134-them with the impassiveness of a Buddhist idol and deposited [them]2134-them all on the orthodox salver in [the hall]517-the hall]2138-his dignified butler , who received them with the impassiveness of a buddhist idol and deposited them all on the orthodox salver in the hall -- and a few messages of " Deeply shocked and grieved . Condolences"--by[2138-his dignified butler , who received them with the impassiveness of a buddhist idol and deposited them all on the orthodox salver in the hall] wires , not exceeding sixpence each , were despatched to [the lonely widower,--but]2140-the lonely widower,--but beyond these purely formal observances , [the handsome brilliant society woman]2141-the handsome brilliant society woman dropped out of thought and remembrance as swiftly as a dead leaf drops from a tree . [She]224-lady blythe had never been loved , save by [her]224-lady blythe two deluded dupes -- [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage and [[her]224-lady blythe husband,--no one in the whole wide range of [her]224-lady blythe social acquaintance]2142-her husband,--no one in the whole wide range of her social acquaintance would have ever thought of feeling the slightest affection for [her]224-lady blythe . The first announcement of [her]224-lady blythe death appeared in an evening paper , stating the cause to be an accidental overdose of veronal taken to procure sleep , and [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , seeing the paragraph by merest chance , gave a shocked exclamation--

" Innocent ! [My]239-miss leigh dear!--how dreadful ! That poor [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe [we]4952-we saw the other night is dead ! "[239-miss leigh]

[The girl]414-the girl was standing by the tea - table just pouring out a cup of tea for [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh -- [she]414-the girl started so nervously that the cup almost fell from [her]414-the girl hand .

" Dead ! "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl repeated , in a low , stifled voice . " [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe ? Dead ? "[414-the girl]

" Yes!--it is awful ! [That horrid veronal]4953-that horrid veronal ! Such a dangerous drug ! It appears [she]224-lady blythe was accustomed to take it for sleep -- and unfortunately [she]224-lady blythe took an over - dose . How terrible for [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe ! "[414-the girl]

[Innocent]152-innocent sat down , trembling . [Her]152-innocent gaze involuntarily wandered to the portrait of [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage -- [the lover of [the dead woman]2145-the dead woman]2144-the lover of the dead woman , and [[her]224-lady blythe father]1518-her father ! The handsome face with [its]2147-its dreamy yet proud eyes appeared conscious of [her]152-innocent intense regard -- [she]152-innocent looked and looked , and longed to speak -- to tell [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh all -- but something held [her]152-innocent silent . [She]152-innocent had [her]152-innocent own secret now -- and it restrained [her]152-innocent from disclosing the secrets of [others]2689-others . Nor could [she]152-innocent realise that it was [[her]152-innocent mother]1849-her mother -- actually [[her]152-innocent own mother]2150-her own mother -- who had been taken so suddenly and tragically from [the world]2693-the world . The news barely affected [her]152-innocent -- nor was this surprising , seeing that [she]152-innocent had never entirely grasped the fact of [[her]152-innocent mother]1849-her mother 's personality or existence at all . [She]152-innocent had felt no emotion concerning [her]1849-her mother , save of repulsion and dislike . [Her]1849-her mother unexpected figure had appeared on the scene like a strange vision , and now had vanished from it as strangely . [Innocent]152-innocent was in very truth " motherless"--but[152-innocent] so [she]152-innocent had always been -- for [a mother who deserts [her]2153-a mother who deserts her child child]2153-a mother who deserts her child is worse than [a mother]4099-a mother dead . Yet it was some few minutes before [she]152-innocent could control [herself]152-innocent sufficiently to speak or look calmly -- and [her]152-innocent eyes were downcast as [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh came up to the tea - table , newspaper in hand , to discuss the tragic incident .

" [She]1849-her mother was [a very brilliant woman in society]4954-a very brilliant woman in society , "[1553-the gentle old lady] said [the gentle old lady]1553-the gentle old lady , then--"You did not know [her]1849-her mother , of course , and [you]4955-you could not judge of [her]1849-her mother by seeing [her]1849-her mother just one evening . But [I]1553-the gentle old lady remember the time when [she]1849-her mother was much talked of as ' the beautiful [Maude Osborne'--she]307-maude osborne'--she was [a very lively , wilful girl]4956-a very lively , wilful girl , and [she]1849-her mother had been rather neglected by [[her]1849-her mother parents]1862-her parents , who left [her]1849-her mother in [England]9-england in charge of [some friends]4958-some friends while [they]1862-her parents were in [India]58-india . [I]1553-the gentle old lady think [she]1849-her mother ran rather wild at that time . There was some talk of [her]1849-her mother having gone off secretly somewhere with [a lover]1808-a lover -- but [I]1553-the gentle old lady never believed the story . It was a silly scandal -- and of course it stopped directly [she]1849-her mother married [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe . [He]229-lord blythe gave [her]1849-her mother a splendid position,--and [he]229-lord blythe was devoted to [her]1849-her mother -- [poor man]4960-poor man ! "[1553-the gentle old lady]

" Yes ? "[152-innocent] murmured [Innocent]152-innocent , mechanically . [She]152-innocent did not know what to say .

" If [she]1849-her mother had been blessed with [children]3319-children -- or even [one child]4962-one child , "[308-miss leigh--"i] went on [Miss Leigh--"I]308-miss leigh--"i think it would have been better for [her]1849-her mother . [I]1553-the gentle old lady am sure [she]1849-her mother would have been happier ! [He]229-lord blythe would , [I]1553-the gentle old lady feel certain ! "[1553-the gentle old lady]

" No doubt ! "[414-the girl] [the girl]414-the girl answered in the same quiet tone .

" [[My]239-miss leigh dear]3270-my dear , [you]3270-my dear look very pale ! "[239-miss leigh] said [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , with some anxiety--"Have [you]3270-my dear been working too hard ? "[239-miss leigh]

[She]239-miss leigh smiled .

" That would be impossible ! "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh answered . " [I]239-miss leigh could not work too hard -- it is such happiness to work -- [one forgets!--yes]4964-one forgets!--yes -- [one]2752-one forgets all that [one]2752-one does not wish to remember ! "[239-miss leigh]

The anxious expression still remained on [Miss Lavinia]239-miss leigh 's face,--but , true to the instincts of [an old - fashioned gentlewoman]2157-an old - fashioned gentlewoman , [she]239-miss leigh did not press enquiries where [she]239-miss leigh saw they might be embarrassing or unwelcome . And though [she]239-miss leigh now loved [Innocent]152-innocent as much as if [she]152-innocent had been [[her]239-miss leigh own child]1481-her own child , [she]239-miss leigh never failed to remember that after all , [the girl]414-the girl had earned [her]414-the girl own almost wealthy independence , and was free to do as [she]414-the girl liked without [anybody]3114-anybody 's control or interference , and that though [she]414-the girl was so young [she]414-the girl was bound to be in all respects untrammelled in [her]414-the girl life and actions . [She]414-the girl went where [she]414-the girl pleased -- [she]414-the girl had [[her]414-the girl own little hired motor]2161-her own little hired motor - brougham -- [she]414-the girl also had [many friends who invited [her]414-the girl]2162-many friends who invited her out without including [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh in the invitations , and [she]414-the girl was still [the " paying guest "[414-the girl] at the little [Kensington]33-kensington house,--a guest who was never tired of doing kindly and helpful deeds for the benefit of [the sweet old woman who was [her]414-the girl hostess]2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess]2163-the " paying guest " at the little kensington house,--a guest who was never tired of doing kindly and helpful deeds for the benefit of the sweet old woman who was her hostess . Once or twice [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh had made a faint half - hearted protest against [her]239-miss leigh constant and lavish generosity .

" [[My]2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess dear]3270-my dear , "[2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess] [she]2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess had said--"With all the money [you]3270-my dear earn now [you]3270-my dear could live in [a much larger house]4968-a much larger house -- [you]3270-my dear could indeed have [a house of [your]3270-my dear own]4969-a house of your own , with many more luxuries -- why do [you]3270-my dear stay [here]2907-here , showering advantages on [me]2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess , who am nothing but [a prosy old body?--you]4971-a prosy old body?--you could do much better ! "[2164-the sweet old woman who was her hostess]

" Could [I]152-innocent really ? "[152-innocent] [And Innocent]152-innocent had laughed and kissed [her]239-miss leigh . " [Well!--I]152-innocent do n't want to do any better -- [I'm]152-innocent quite happy as [I]152-innocent am . One thing is--(and [you]3270-my dear seem to forget it!)--that [I]152-innocent 'm very fond of [you!--and]4972-you!--and when [I]152-innocent 'm very fond of [a person]4825-a person it 's difficult to shake [me]152-innocent off ! "[152-innocent]

So [she]239-miss leigh stayed on -- and lived [her]239-miss leigh life with a nun - like simplicity and economy -- spending [her]239-miss leigh money on [others]2689-others rather than [herself]239-miss leigh , and helping those in need,--and never even in [her]239-miss leigh dress , which was always exquisite , running into vagaries of extravagance and follies of fashion . [She]239-miss leigh had discovered [a little French dressmaker , whose husband]2166-a little french dressmaker , whose husband had deserted [her]239-miss leigh , leaving [her]239-miss leigh with [two small children to feed and educate]2167-two small children to feed and educate , and to [this humble , un - famous plier of the needle [she]239-miss leigh entrusted [her]239-miss leigh wardrobe]2168-this humble , un - famous plier of the needle she entrusted her wardrobe with entirely successful results . [Worth]309-worth , [Paquin]310-paquin , [Doucet]311-doucet and [other loudly advertised personages]2169-other loudly advertised personages were all quoted as " creators "[311-doucet] of [her]239-miss leigh gowns , whereat [she]239-miss leigh was amused .

" A little personal taste and thought go so much further in dress than money , "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh was wo nt to say to [some of [[her]239-miss leigh rather envious women friends]2171-her rather envious women friends]2170-some of her rather envious women friends . " [I]239-miss leigh would rather copy the clothes in an old picture than the clothes in a fashion book . "[239-miss leigh]

Odd fancies about [[her]239-miss leigh dead mother]2172-her dead mother came to [her]239-miss leigh when [she]239-miss leigh was alone in [[her]239-miss leigh own room]865-her own room -- particularly at night when [she]239-miss leigh said [her]239-miss leigh prayers . Some mysterious force seemed compelling [her]239-miss leigh to offer up a petition for the peace of [[her]239-miss leigh mother]1849-her mother 's soul,--she knew from the old books written by [the " Sieur Amadis]138-the sieur amadis "[138-the sieur amadis] that to do this was a custom of [his]2175-his creed . [She]239-miss leigh missed it out of the [Church of]60-church of [England]9-england Prayer - book , though [she]239-miss leigh dutifully followed the tenets of the faith in which [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh had had [her]239-miss leigh baptised and confirmed -- but in [her]239-miss leigh heart of hearts [she]239-miss leigh thought it good and right to pray for the peace of departed souls--

" For who can [tell"--she]312-tell"--she[239-miss leigh] would say to herself--"what strange confusion and sorrow [they]3674-the dead may be suffering!--away from all that [they]3674-the dead once knew and cared for ! Even if prayers can not help [them]3674-the dead it is kind to pray ! "[239-miss leigh]

And for [[her]239-miss leigh mother]1849-her mother 's soul [she]239-miss leigh felt a dim and far - off sense of pity -- almost a fear , lest that unsatisfied spirit might be lost and wandering in a chaos of dark experience without any clue to guide or any light to shine upon its dreadful solitude . So may [the dead]3674-the dead come nearer to the living than when [they]3674-the dead also lived !

Some three or four weeks after [Lady Blythe]224-lady blythe 's sudden exit from [a world]2178-a world too callous to care whether [she]224-lady blythe stayed in [it]2178-a world or went from [it]2178-a world , [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe called at [[Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's house]2179-miss leigh 's house and asked to see [her]1849-her mother . [He]229-lord blythe was admitted at once , and [the pretty old lady]2180-the pretty old lady came down in a great flutter to [the drawing - room]1548-the drawing - room to receive [him]229-lord blythe . [She]2180-the pretty old lady found [him]229-lord blythe standing in front of the harpsichord , looking at the portrait upon it . [He]229-lord blythe turned quickly round as [she]2180-the pretty old lady entered and spoke with some abruptness .

" [I]229-lord blythe must apologise for calling rather late in the afternoon , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe said--"But [I]229-lord blythe could not wait another day . " Yes"--and[239-miss leigh] [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's eyes opened in a little surprise and bewilderment--"He was [a great friend of mine]4665-a great friend of mine -- and of [yours]2180-the pretty old lady ? "[239-miss leigh] " [He]229-lord blythe was [my]229-lord blythe college chum"--and[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe walked closer to the picture and looked at it steadfastly--"That must have been taken when [he]229-lord blythe was quite [a young man]4977-a young man -- before-- "[229-lord blythe] [He]229-lord blythe paused again,--then said with a forced smile--"Talking of [Armitage]227-armitage -- is [Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage in ? "[229-lord blythe]

"[2183-his]

CHAPTER VII

Startled and completely taken aback , [she]239-miss leigh let [her]239-miss leigh hands remain passively in [his]229-lord blythe for a moment,--then quietly withdrew them . A hot colour rushed swiftly into [her]239-miss leigh cheeks and as swiftly receded , leaving [her]239-miss leigh very pale .

" How can [you]229-lord blythe know ? "[2192-she] [she]2192-she faltered--"Who has told [you]229-lord blythe ? "[229-lord blythe]

" [[Your]239-miss leigh mother]3861-your mother [herself]3861-your mother told [me]2192-she on the night [she]3861-your mother died , "[2192-she] [he]229-lord blythe answered--"She gave [me]229-lord blythe all the truth of [herself,--at]3861-your mother last -- after long years ! "[229-lord blythe]

[She]239-miss leigh was silent -- standing inert as though [she]239-miss leigh had received a numbing blow . [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh rose and came tremblingly towards [her]239-miss leigh .

" [[My]2192-she dear]3270-my dear , [[my]2192-she dear]3270-my dear ! "[2192-she] [she]2192-she exclaimed--"I wish [I]239-miss leigh had known it all before!--I might have done more -- [I]239-miss leigh might have tried to be kinder-- "[239-miss leigh]

[The girl]414-the girl sprang to [her]239-miss leigh side and impulsively embraced [her]239-miss leigh .

" [You]229-lord blythe would have tried in vain ! "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl said , fondly , " [No one on earth]5005-no one on earth could have been kinder than [[my]414-the girl beloved little godmother]5006-my beloved little godmother ! [You]229-lord blythe have been the dearest and best of [friends]3027-friends ! "[414-the girl]

Then [she]414-the girl turned towards [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe .

" It is very good of [you]229-lord blythe to come here and say what [you]229-lord blythe have said"--and[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl spoke in soft , almost pathetic accents--"But [I]414-the girl am sorry that [anyone]2832-anyone knows [my]414-the girl story -- it is no use to know it , really ! [I]414-the girl should have always kept it a secret -- for it chiefly concerns [me]414-the girl , after all,--and why should [my]414-the girl existence cast a shadow on the memory of [[my]414-the girl father]2856-my father ? Perhaps [you]229-lord blythe may have known [him--]2856-my father "[414-the girl]

" [I]229-lord blythe knew [him]2856-my father and loved [him]2856-my father ! "[229-lord blythe] said [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe , quickly .

[She]414-the girl looked at [him]229-lord blythe with wistful , tear - wet eyes .

" Well then , how hard it must be for [you]229-lord blythe to think that [he]2856-my father ever did anything unworthy of [himself]2856-my father ! "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl said--"And for [this dear lady]5010-this dear lady it is cruel!--for [she]5010-this dear lady loved [him]2856-my father too . And what am [I]229-lord blythe that [I]229-lord blythe should cause all this trouble ! [I]229-lord blythe am [a nameless creature]5011-a nameless creature -- [I]229-lord blythe took [his]2856-my father name because [I]229-lord blythe wanted to kindle a little light of [my]229-lord blythe own round it -- [I]229-lord blythe have done that ! And then [I]229-lord blythe wanted to guard [his]2856-my father memory from any whisper of scandal -- will [you]229-lord blythe help [me]229-lord blythe in this ? The secret must still be kept -- and [no one]2691-no one must ever know [I]229-lord blythe am [[his]2856-my father daughter]3716-his daughter . For though [[your]229-lord blythe wife]3364-your wife is dead [her]3364-your wife name must not be shamed for the long ago sin of [her]3364-your wife youth -- nor must [I]229-lord blythe be branded as what [I]229-lord blythe am -- [base - born]5015-base - born . "[229-lord blythe]

Profoundly touched by the simple straightforward eloquence of [her]2194-her appeal , [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe went up to [her]2194-her where [she]2194-her stood with one arm round [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh .

" [[My]229-lord blythe dear child]5016-my dear child , "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe said , earnestly--"believe [me]229-lord blythe , [I]229-lord blythe shall never speak of [your]5016-my dear child parentage or give the slightest hint to [anyone]2832-anyone of the true facts of [your]5016-my dear child history -- still less would [I]229-lord blythe allow [you]5016-my dear child to be lightly esteemed for what is no fault of [your]5016-my dear child own . [You]5016-my dear child have made a brilliant name and fame for [yourself]5016-my dear child -- [you]5016-my dear child have the right to that name and fame . [I]229-lord blythe came here to - day for two reasons -- one to tell [you]5016-my dear child that [I]229-lord blythe was fully acquainted with all [you]5016-my dear child had endured and suffered -- the other to ask if [you]5016-my dear child will let [me]229-lord blythe be [[your]5016-my dear child guardian]5018-your guardian -- [[your]5016-my dear child other father]5019-your other father -- and give [me]229-lord blythe some right to shelter [you]5016-my dear child from the rough ways of [the world]2693-the world . [I]229-lord blythe may perhaps in this way make some amends to [you]5016-my dear child for the loss of [mother]3083-mother - love and [father]1562-father - love -- [I]229-lord blythe would do [my]229-lord blythe best-- "[229-lord blythe]

[He]2195-you stopped -- a little troubled by unusual emotion . [Innocent]152-innocent , drawing [her]152-innocent embracing arm away from [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , looked at [him]2195-you with wondering , grateful eyes .

" How good [you]2195-you are ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said , softly--"You would take care of [me]152-innocent -- [you]2195-you with [your]2195-you proud name and place!--and [I]152-innocent -- [the poor , unfortunately born child of [[your]2195-you dead friend]5024-your dead friend]5023-the poor , unfortunately born child of your dead friend ! Ah , [you]2195-you kind , gentle heart!--I thank [you!--but]2195-you no!--I must not accept such a sacrifice on [your]2195-you part-- "[152-innocent]

" It would be no [sacrifice"--he]2195-you[152-innocent] interrupted [her]152-innocent , eagerly--"No , [child!--it]315-child!--it would be pure selfishness!--for [I]152-innocent 'm getting old and am lonely -- and -- and [I]152-innocent want [someone]3115-someone to look after [me]152-innocent ! "[152-innocent] [He]2195-you laughed a little awkwardly . " Why not come to [me]2195-you and be [[my]2195-you daughter]4861-my daughter ? "[2195-you]

[She]152-innocent smiled -- caught [his]2195-you hand and kissed it .

" [I]152-innocent will be [a daughter]5027-a daughter to [you]2195-you in affection and respect , "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent said--"But [I]152-innocent will not take any benefits from [you]2195-you -- no , none ! CHAPTER VIII

Fame , or notoriety , whichever that special noise may be called when [the world]2693-the world like a hound " gives tongue "[152-innocent] and announces that the quarry in some form of genius is at bay , is apt to increase its clamour in proportion to the aloofness of the pursued animal,--and Innocent , who saw nothing remarkable in remaining somewhat secluded and apart from the ordinary routine of social life so feverishly followed by more than half [her]152-innocent sex , was very soon classified as " proud"--"eccentric"--"difficult[152-innocent] " and "[152-innocent] vain , " by [idle and ignorant persons who knew nothing about [her]152-innocent , and only judged [her]152-innocent by [their]5105-idle and ignorant persons who knew nothing about her , and only judged her by their own limited conceptions of what a successful author might or could possibly be like own limited conceptions of what [a successful author]5106-a successful author might or could possibly be like]5105-idle and ignorant persons who knew nothing about her , and only judged her by their own limited conceptions of what a successful author might or could possibly be like . Some of these , more foolish than the rest , expressed [themselves]2209-themselves as afraid or unwilling to meet her--"lest[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent should put [them]2209-themselves into [her]152-innocent books"--this being a common form of conceit with [many individuals too utterly dull and uninteresting to "[152-innocent] make copy " for so much as the humblest paragraphist]5107-many individuals too utterly dull and uninteresting to " make copy " for so much as the humblest paragraphist . It was quite true that [she]152-innocent showed [herself]152-innocent sadly deficient in the appreciation of society functions and [society]5108-society people,--to [her]152-innocent [they]5105-idle and ignorant persons who knew nothing about her , and only judged her by their own limited conceptions of what a successful author might or could possibly be like seemed stupid and boresome , involving much waste of precious time,--but notwithstanding this , [she]152-innocent was invited everywhere , and the accumulation of "[152-innocent] R.S.V.P. " cards on [her]152-innocent table and desk made such a formidable heap that it was quite a business to clear them , as [she]152-innocent did once a week , with the assistance of the useful waste - paper basket . As [a writer]5109-a writer [her]152-innocent popularity was unquestionable , and so great and insistent was the public demand for anything from [her]152-innocent pen that [she]152-innocent could command [her]152-innocent own terms from any publishing quarter . [Her]152-innocent good fortune made very little effect upon her,--sometimes it seemed as if [she]152-innocent hardly realised or cared to realise it . [She]152-innocent had odd , almost child - like ways of spending some of [her]152-innocent money in dainty "[152-innocent] surprise " gifts to [[her]152-innocent friends]5110-her friends -- that is to say , [such friends]5111-such friends as had shown [her]152-innocent kindness,--beautiful flowers and fruit for [invalids]5112-invalids -- choice wines for those who needed yet could not afford them,--a new drawing - room carpet for [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , which was , in [the old lady]1525-the old lady 's opinion , a most important and amazing affair!--costly furs , also for [Miss Leigh,--and]321-miss leigh,--and devices and adornments of all sorts for the pleasure , beauty or comfort of [the house]2762-the house -- but on [herself]152-innocent personally [she]152-innocent spent nothing save what was necessary for such dress and appearance as best accorded with [her]152-innocent now acknowledged position . Dearly as [she]152-innocent would have loved to shower gifts and benefits on [the inhabitants of never - forgotten [Briar Farm]4-briar farm]5115-the inhabitants of never - forgotten briar farm , [she]152-innocent knew that if [she]152-innocent did anything of the kind [poor lonely old Priscilla Friday]103-priscilla and patiently enduring [Robin Clifford]84-robin were more likely to be hurt than gratified . For a silence had fallen between that past life , which had been like a wild rose blossoming in [a country lane]5116-a country lane , and the present one , which resembled a wonderful orchid flower , flaming in heat under glass,--and though [she]152-innocent wrote to [Robin]84-robin now and again , and [he]84-robin replied , [his]84-robin letters were restrained and formal -- almost cold . [He]84-robin knew too well how far [she]2210-her was removed from [him]84-robin by more than distance , and bravely contented [himself]84-robin with merely giving [her]2210-her such news of [the farm]2744-the farm and [[her]2210-her former home surroundings]5118-her former home surroundings as might awaken [her]2210-her momentary interest without recalling too many old memories to [her]2210-her mind .[152-innocent]

[She]2210-her seemed , and to a very great extent [she]2210-her was , unconscious of the interest and curiosity both [her]2210-her work and [her]2210-her personality excited -- the more so now as the glamour and delight of [her]2210-her creative imagination had been obscured by what [she]2210-her considered a far greater and more lasting glory -- that of love!--the golden mirage of a fancied sun , which for a time had quenched the steadier shining of eternal stars . Since that ever memorable night when [he]2211-his had suddenly stormed [the fortress of [her]2210-her soul]2212-the fortress of her soul , and by the mastery of [a lover]1808-a lover 's kiss had taken full possession , [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn had pursued [his]2211-his " amour "[2211-his] with admirable tact , cleverness and secrecy . [He]2211-his found a new and stimulating charm in making love to [a tender - hearted , credulous little creature who seemed truly " of such stuff as dreams are made of"--and[1808-a lover] to [a man of [his]2211-his particular type and temperament]2215-a man of his particular type and temperament]2214-a tender - hearted , credulous little creature who seemed truly " of such stuff as dreams are made of"--and to a man of his particular type and temperament there was an irresistible provocation to [his]2211-his vanity in the possibility of being able to lure [her]2210-her gradually and insidiously down from the high ground of intellectual ambition and power to the low level of that pitiful sex - submission which is responsible for so much more misery than happiness in [this world]3261-this world . Little by little , under [his]2211-his apparently brusque and playful , but really studied training , [she]2210-her began to think less and less of [her]2210-her work,--the books [she]2210-her had loved to read and refer to , insensibly lost their charm,--she went reluctantly to [her]2210-her desk , and as reluctantly took up [her]2210-her pen,--what [she]2210-her had written already , appeared to [her]2210-her utterly worthless,--and what [she]2210-her attempted to write now was to [her]2210-her mind poor and unsatisfying . [She]2210-her was not moved by the knowledge , constantly pressed upon [her]2210-her , that [she]2210-her was steadily rising , despite [herself]2210-her , to the zenith of [her]2210-her career in such an incredibly swift and brilliant way as to be the envy of all [[her]2210-her contemporaries,--she]2217-her contemporaries,--she was hardly as grateful for [her]2210-her honours as weary of [them]2218-them and a little contemptuous . What did it all matter to [her]2210-her when half of [her]2210-her once busy working mornings were now often passed in [the studio of [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn]2219-the studio of amadis de jocelyn ! [He]102-amadis de jocelyn was painting a full - length portrait of [her]2210-her -- a mere excuse to give [her]2210-her facilities for visiting [him]102-amadis de jocelyn , and ensure [his]102-amadis de jocelyn own privacy and convenience in receiving [her]2210-her -- and every day [she]2210-her went to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn , sometimes late in the afternoons as well as the mornings , slipping in and out familiarly and quite unnoticed , for [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had given [her]2210-her a key to the private door of [[his]102-amadis de jocelyn studio]1716-his studio , which was reached through a small , deeply shaded garden , abutting on [an old - fashioned street near [Holland Park]63-holland park]2221-an old - fashioned street near holland park . [She]2210-her could enter at any time , and thought it was the customary privilege accorded by [an artist]3998-an artist to [[his]3998-an artist sitter]2223-his sitter , while it saved the time and trouble of [the rheumatic " odd man "[2224-the rheumatic " odd man " or servant whose failing limbs were slow to respond to a summons at the orthodox front entrance] or [servant whose failing limbs were slow to respond to a summons at the orthodox front entrance]2225-servant whose failing limbs were slow to respond to a summons at the orthodox front entrance]2224-the rheumatic " odd man " or servant whose failing limbs were slow to respond to a summons at the orthodox front entrance . [She]2210-her would come in , dressed in [her]2210-her simple navy blue serge walking costume , and then in [a little room just off [the studio]1718-the studio]2226-a little room just off the studio would change and put on the white dress which [[her]2210-her lover]892-her lover had chosen as the most suitable for [his]102-amadis de jocelyn purpose , and which [he]102-amadis de jocelyn called the " portrait gown . "[102-amadis de jocelyn] It was simple , and severely Greek , made of the softest and filmiest material which fell gracefully away in enchanting folds from [her]2210-her childishly rounded neck and arms,--it gave [her]2210-her the appearance of [a Psyche]2229-a psyche or [an Ariadne,--and]2230-an ariadne,--and at the first sitting , when [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had posed [her]2210-her in several attitudes before attempting to draw a line , [she]2210-her had so much sweet attractiveness about [her]2210-her that [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was hardly to be blamed for throwing aside all work and devoting [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn to such ardent delight in [woman]3519-woman 's fairness as may sometimes fall to the lot of [man]567-man . While moving from one position to another as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn suggested or commanded , [she]2210-her had playfully broken off one flower from a large plant of " marguerite "[2210-her] daisies growing in a quaint Japanese pot , close at hand , and had begun pulling off the petals according to the old fanciful charm--"Il m'aime!--un peu!--beaucoup!--passionement!--pas du tout ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [He]102-amadis de jocelyn stopped [her]2210-her at the word " passionement , "[102-amadis de jocelyn] and caught [her]2210-her in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn arms .

" Not another petal must be plucked ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn whispered , kissing [her]2210-her soft warm neck--"I will not have [you]2210-her say ' Pas du tout ! ' "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[She]2210-her laughed delightedly , nestling against [him]102-amadis de jocelyn .

" Very well ! "[2210-her] [she]2210-her said--"But suppose-- "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Suppose what ? "[2210-her]

" Suppose it ever came to that?"--and[2210-her] [she]2210-her sighed as [she]2210-her spoke--"Then the last petal must fall ! "[2210-her]

" Do [you]2210-her think it ever will or can come to that ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn asked , pressing a kiss on the sweet upturned lips--"Does it seem like it ? "[2210-her]

[She]2210-her was too happy to answer [him]102-amadis de jocelyn , and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was too amorous just then to think of anything but [her]2210-her soft eyes , dewy with tenderness -- [her]2210-her white , ivory - smooth skin -- [her]2210-her small caressing hands , and the fine bright tendrils of [her]2210-her waving hair -- all these were [his]102-amadis de jocelyn to play with as [a child]634-a child plays with beautiful toys unconscious of or indifferent to their value .

Many such passages of love occupied [their]2234-their time -- though [he]102-amadis de jocelyn managed to make a good show of progressive work after the first rough outline drawing of the picture was completed . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn was undeniably a genius in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn way , uncertain and erratic of impulse , but [his]102-amadis de jocelyn art was strong because its effects were broad and simple . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had begun [Innocent]152-innocent 's portrait out of the mere desire to have [her]152-innocent with [him]102-amadis de jocelyn constantly,--but as day after day went on and the subject developed under [his]102-amadis de jocelyn skilled hand and brush [he]102-amadis de jocelyn realised that it would probably be " the "[102-amadis de jocelyn] picture of [the Salon]2235-the salon in the following year . As this conviction dawned upon [him]102-amadis de jocelyn , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn took greater pains , and worked more carefully and conscientiously with the happiest results , feeling a thrill of true artistic satisfaction as the picture began to live and smile in response to [his]102-amadis de jocelyn masterly touch and treatment . [Its]2236-its composition was simple -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had drawn [the girl]414-the girl as though [she]414-the girl were slowly advancing towards [the spectator]2238-the spectator , giving [her]414-the girl figure all the aerial grace habitual to it by nature,--one little daintily shaped hand held a dove lightly against [her]414-the girl breast , as though the bird had just flown there for protection from [its]2239-its own alarm,--her face was slightly uplifted,--the lips smiled , and the eyes looked straight out at [the world]2693-the world with a beautiful , clear candour which was all [their]2241-their own . Yet despite the charm and sweetness of the likeness there was a strange pathos about it,--a sadness which [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn had never set there by [his]102-amadis de jocelyn own will or intention .

" [You]414-the girl are a puzzling subject , "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn said to [her]414-the girl one day--"I wanted to give [you]414-the girl a happy expression -- and yet [your]414-the girl portrait is actually growing sad!--almost reproachful ! ... do [you]414-the girl look at [me]102-amadis de jocelyn like that ? " Nor reproachful ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" [You]2243-you are not very wise , "[2242-he] [he]2242-he then said--"It 's a great thing for [a young girl like [you]2243-you who are all alone in [the world]2693-the world]5134-a young girl like you who are all alone in the world , to be taken in hand by [such a man as [Blythe]229-lord blythe]5136-such a man as blythe . [He]2246-he laughed .

"[2245-her]

" Does failure constitute greatness ? "[2245-her] [she]2245-her asked , with a faintly satirical inflection in [her]2245-her sweet voice which [he]2246-he had never heard before .

' But [he]171-shakespeare was not a ' failure'--and [the whole world]4313-the whole world acknowledges [his]171-shakespeare greatness now , though in [his]171-shakespeare life - time [he]171-shakespeare was unconscious of it . "[2245-her]

"[2246-he]

[Her]2245-her lips quivered : despite [her]2245-her efforts , tears started to [her]2245-her eyes . [He]2246-he saw , and throwing down [his]2246-he brush came and knelt beside [her]2245-her , passing [his]2246-he arm round [her]2245-her waist .

" What have [I]2246-he said ? "[2246-he] [he]2246-he murmured , coaxingly--"Innocent -- sweet little love ! Forgive [me]2246-he if [I]2246-he have -- what?"--and[2246-he] [he]2246-he laughed softly--"rubbed [you]2245-her up the wrong way ! "[2246-he]

[She]2245-her forced a smile , and [her]2245-her delicate white hands wandered caressingly through [his]2246-he hair as [he]2246-he laid [his]2246-he head against [her]2245-her bosom .

" [I]2245-her am sorry ! "[2245-her] [she]2245-her said , at last--"I thought -- [I]2245-her hoped -- [you]2246-he might be proud of [my]2245-her work , [Amadis]102-amadis de jocelyn !
