[You]2246-he see"--she[2245-her] hesitated--"I learned so much from [the Sieur Amadis de Jocelin]138-the sieur amadis -- the brother of [your]2246-he ancestor!--that [I]2245-her have been thinking all the time how [I]2245-her could best show [you]2246-he that [I]2245-her was worthy of [his]138-the sieur amadis teaching . [The world]2693-the world -- or [the public]1471-the public -- [you]2246-he know the things [they]1471-the public say of [me]2245-her -- but [I]2245-her do not want [their]1471-the public praise . [I]2245-her believe [I]2245-her could do something really great if [YOU]2246-he cared!--for now it is only to please [you]2246-he that [I]2245-her live . "[2245-her]

A sense of shame stung [him]2247-he at this simple avowal .

" Nonsense ! "[2247-he] [he]2247-he said , almost brusquely--"You have a thousand other things to live for -- [you]2246-he must not think of pleasing [me]2247-he only . Besides [I]2247-he 'm not very -- keen on literature,--I'm [a painter]4495-a painter . "[2247-he]

" Surely painting owes something to literature ? "[2248-she] [she]2248-she queried--"We should not have had all the wonderful Madonnas and Christs of [the old masters]5151-the old masters if there had been no Bible ! "[2247-he]

" True!--but perhaps [we]5152-we could have done without [them]1471-the public ! "[2247-he] [he]2247-he said , lightly--"I'm not at all sure that painting would not have got on just as well without literature at all . There is always nature to study -- sky , [sea]5153-sea , landscape and the faces of [lovely women]5154-lovely women and [children,--quite]5155-children,--quite enough for [any man]2694-any man . Where is [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe now ? "[2247-he]

" In [Italy]62-italy , "[2248-she] [she]2248-she replied--"He will be away some months . "[2247-he]

[She]2248-she spoke with constraint . [Her]2248-she heart was heavy -- the hopes and ambitions [she]2248-she had cherished of adding lustre to [her]2248-she fame for the joy and pride of [[her]2248-she lover]892-her lover , seemed all crushed at one blow . [She]2248-she was too young and inexperienced to realise the fact that [few men]2250-few men are proud of [any woman]4350-any woman 's success , especially in the arts . [Their]2250-few men attitude is one of amused tolerance when it is not of actual sex - jealousy or contempt . Least of all can [any man]2694-any man endure that [the woman for whom [he]2694-any man has a short spell of passionate fancy]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy should be considered notable , or in an intellectual sense superior to [himself]2694-any man . [He]2694-any man likes [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy to be dependent on [him]2694-any man alone for [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy happiness,--for such poor crumbs of comfort [he]2694-any man is pleased to give [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy when the heat of [his]2694-any man first passion has cooled,--but [he]2694-any man is not altogether pleased when [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy has sufficient intelligent perception to see through [his]2694-any man web of subterfuge and break away clear of the entangling threads , standing free as [a goddess]2254-a goddess on the height of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy own independent attainment . [Innocent]152-innocent 's idea of love was the angelic dream of truth and everlastingness set forth by [poets]3427-poets , whose sweet singing deludes [themselves]3427-poets and [others,--she]326-others,--she was ready to devote all the unique powers of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy mind and brain to the perfecting of [herself]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy for [[her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy lover]892-her lover 's delight . [She]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy wished to be beautiful , brilliant , renowned and admired , simply that [he]2694-any man might take joy in knowing that [this beautiful , brilliant , renowned and admired creature]2257-this beautiful , brilliant , renowned and admired creature was [HIS]2694-any man , body and soul -- existing solely for [him]2694-any man and content to live only so long as [he]2694-any man lived , to work only so long as [he]2694-any man worked,--to be nothing apart from [his]2694-any man love , but to be everything [he]2694-any man could desire or command while [his]2694-any man love environed [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy . [She]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy thought of the eternal union of souls,--while [he]2694-any man had no belief in the soul at all , [his]2694-any man half French materialism persuading [him]2694-any man that there was nothing eternal . And like [all men of [his]2694-any man type]2258-all men of his type [he]2694-any man estimated [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy tenderness for [him]2694-any man , [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy clinging arms , and the lingering passion of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy caresses , to be chiefly the outflow of pleased vanity -- the kittenish satisfaction of being stroked and fondled -- the sense of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy own sex - attractiveness,--but of anything deep and closely rooted in the centre of a more than usually sensitive nature [he]2694-any man had not the faintest conception , taking it for granted that [all women]5145-all women , even [clever ones]2260-clever ones , were more or less alike , easily consoled by new millinery when [lovers]2705-lovers failed .

Sometimes , during the progress of [their]2262-their secret amour , a thrill of uneasiness and fear ran coldly through [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy veins -- a wondering doubt which [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy repelled with indignation whenever it suggested itself . [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was and must be the very embodiment of loyalty and honour to [the woman [he]2694-any man loved!--it]2263-the woman he loved!--it could not be otherwise . [His]2694-any man tenderness was ardent,--his passion fiery and eager,--yet [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy wondered -- timidly and with deep humiliation in [herself]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy for daring to think so far -- why , if [he]2694-any man loved [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy so much as [he]2694-any man declared , did [he]2694-any man not ask [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy to be [[his]2694-any man wife]706-his wife ? [She]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy supposed [he]2694-any man would do so,--though [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy had heard [him]2694-any man depreciate marriage as a necessary evil . Evidently [he]2694-any man had [his]2694-any man own good reasons for deferring the fateful question . Meanwhile [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy made a little picture - gallery of ideal joys in [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy brain,--and one of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy fancies was that when [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy married [[her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy Amadis]2265-her amadis [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy would ask [Robin Clifford]84-robin to let [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy buy [Briar Farm]4-briar farm .

" [He]2694-any man could paint well [there]2972-there ! "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy] [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy thought , happily , already seeing in [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy mind 's eye the " [Great Hall]5158-great hall "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy] transformed into an artist 's studio--"and [I]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy almost think _ [I]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy _ could carry on [the farm]2744-the farm -- [Priscilla]103-priscilla would help me,--and [we]5160-we know just how [Dad]85-dad liked things to be done -- if -- if [Robin]84-robin went away . And [the master of [the house]2762-the house]5161-the master of the house would again be a true [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn ! "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy]

The whole plan seemed perfectly natural and feasible . Only one obstacle presented itself like a dark shadow on the brightness of [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy dream -- and that was [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy own " base "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy] birth . The brand of illegitimacy was upon [her,--and]2266-her,--and whereas once [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy alone had known what [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy judged to be a shameful secret , now [two others]2267-two others shared it with [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy -- [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh and [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe . [They]2267-two others would never betray it -- no!--but [they]2267-two others could not alter what unkind fate had done for [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy . This was one reason why [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy was glad that [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn had not as yet spoken of [their]2268-their marriage .

" For [I]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy should have to tell [him]102-amadis de jocelyn ! "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy] [she]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy thought , woefully--"I should have to say that [I]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy am [the illegitimate daughter of [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage]5163-the illegitimate daughter of pierce armitage -- and then -- perhaps [he]102-amadis de jocelyn would not marry [me]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn might change -- ah [no!--he]102-amadis de jocelyn could [not!--he]102-amadis de jocelyn would not!--he loves [me]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy too dearly ! [He]102-amadis de jocelyn would never let [me]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy go -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn wants [me]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy always ! [We]5164-we are all [the world]2693-the world to each other!--nothing could part [us]5164-we now ! "[2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy]

And so the time drifted on -- and with its drifting [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy work drifted too , and only one all - absorbing passion possessed [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy life with its close and consuming fire . [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was an expert in the seduction of a soul -- little by little [he]102-amadis de jocelyn taught [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy to judge [all men]2784-all men as worthless save [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn , and all opinions unwarrantable and ill - founded unless [he]102-amadis de jocelyn confirmed [them]2270-them . And , leading [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy away from the contemplation of high visions , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn made [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy [the blind worshipper of [a very inadequate idol]2272-a very inadequate idol]2271-the blind worshipper of a very inadequate idol . [She]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy was happy in [her]2253-the woman for whom he has a short spell of passionate fancy faith , and yet not altogether sure of happiness . For there are two kinds of love -- one with strong wings which lift the soul to a dazzling perfection of immortal destiny,--the other with gross and heavy chains which fetter every hope and aspiration and drag the finest intelligence down to dark waste and nothingness .

CHAPTER IX

In affairs of love [a woman]2688-a woman is perhaps most easily ensnared by [a man who can combine passion with pleasantry and hot pursuit with social tact and diplomacy]2274-a man who can combine passion with pleasantry and hot pursuit with social tact and diplomacy . [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was [an adept at this kind of thing]2275-an adept at this kind of thing -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was , if it may be so expressed , [a refined libertine]2276-a refined libertine , loving women from a purely physical sense of attraction and pleasure conveyed to [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn , and obtusely ignorant of the needs or demands of [their]2784-all men higher natures . From a mental or intellectual standpoint [all women]5145-all women to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn were alike , made to be " managed "[2276-a refined libertine] alike , used alike , and alike set aside when [their]2784-all men use was done with . The leaven of [the Jew]327-the jew or [the Turk]328-the turk was in the temperament of [this descendant of [a long line of French nobles]2279-a long line of french nobles , who had gained [their]2279-a long line of french nobles chief honours by killing [men]397-men , ravishing [women]718-women and plundering [[their]2279-a long line of french nobles neighbours]3306-their neighbours ' lands]2278-this descendant of a long line of french nobles , who had gained their chief honours by killing men , ravishing women and plundering their neighbours ' lands -- though occasional flashes of bravery and chivalry had glanced over [their]2279-a long line of french nobles annals in history like the light from a wandering will o ' the wisp flickering over a morass . Gifted in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn art , but wholly undisciplined in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn nature , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had lived a life of selfish aims to selfish ends , and in the course of it had made love to many women,--one especially , on whose devoted affections [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had preyed like an insect that ungratefully poisons the flower from which it has sucked the honey . [This woman]2283-this woman , driven to bay at last by [his]102-amadis de jocelyn neglect and effrontery , had roused the scattered forces of [her]2283-this woman pride and had given [him]102-amadis de jocelyn [his]102-amadis de jocelyn conge -- and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had been looking about for a fresh victim when [he]102-amadis de jocelyn met [Innocent]152-innocent . [She]2283-this woman was a complete novelty to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn , and stimulated [his]102-amadis de jocelyn more or less jaded emotions,--he found [her]2283-this woman quaint and charming as [a poet]978-a poet 's dream of [some nymph of the woodlands,--her manner of looking at life and the things of life]2285-some nymph of the woodlands,--her manner of looking at life and the things of life was so deliciously simple -- almost mediaeval,--for [she]2283-this woman believed that [a man]2681-a man should die rather than break [his]2681-a man word or imperil [his]2681-a man honour , which to [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was such a primitive state of things as to seem prehistoric . Then there was [her]2283-this woman fixed and absurd " fancy "[2283-this woman] about the noble qualities and manifold virtues of [the French knight who had served [the Duc d'Anjou,--and who had been to [her]2283-this woman from childhood a kind of lover in the spirit,--a being whom [she]2283-this woman had instinctively tried to serve and to please]2288-the duc d'anjou,--and who had been to her from childhood a kind of lover in the spirit,--a being whom she had instinctively tried to serve and to please]2287-the french knight who had served the duc d'anjou,--and who had been to her from childhood a kind of lover in the spirit,--a being whom she had instinctively tried to serve and to please ; and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had sufficient imagination to understand and take advantage of the feeling aroused in [her]2283-this woman when [she]2283-this woman had met [one of the same descent]2289-one of the same descent , and bearing the same name , in [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had run through the gamut of many emotions and sentiments,--he had joined one or two of the new schools of atheism and modernism started by [certain self - opinionated [young University men]2291-young university men]2290-certain self - opinionated young university men , and in the earlier stages of [his]102-amadis de jocelyn career had in the cock - sure impulse of youth designed schemes for the regeneration of [the world]2693-the world , till the usual difficulties presented [themselves]2293-themselves as opposed to such vast business,--he had associated [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn with [men who followed what is called the " fleshly school "[2294-men who followed what is called the " fleshly school " of poetry and art generally] of poetry and art generally]2294-men who followed what is called the " fleshly school " of poetry and art generally , and had evolved from [his]102-amadis de jocelyn own mentality a comfortable faith of which the chief tenet was " Self for Self"--a[2294-men who followed what is called the " fleshly school " of poetry and art generally] religion which lifts the mind no higher than the purely animal plane;--and in its environment of physical consciousness and agreeable physical sensations , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was content to live .

With such a temperament and disposition as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn possessed , which swayed [him]102-amadis de jocelyn hither and thither on the caprice or impulse of the moment , [his]102-amadis de jocelyn intentions toward [Innocent]152-innocent were not very clear even to [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn . When [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had begun [his]102-amadis de jocelyn " amour "[102-amadis de jocelyn] with [her]152-innocent [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had meant it to go just as far as should satisfy [his]102-amadis de jocelyn own whim and desire,--but as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn came to know [her]152-innocent better , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn put a check on [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn and hesitated as one may hesitate before pulling up a rose - bush from its happy growing place and flinging it out on the dust - heap to die . [She]152-innocent was so utterly unsuspicious and unaware of evil , and [she]152-innocent had placed [him]102-amadis de jocelyn on so high a pedestal of honour , trusting [him]102-amadis de jocelyn with such perfect and unquestioning faith , that for very manhood 's sake [he]102-amadis de jocelyn could not bring [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn to tear the veil from [her]152-innocent eyes . Moreover [he]102-amadis de jocelyn really loved [her]152-innocent in a curious , haphazard way of love,--more than [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had ever loved any one of [her]152-innocent sex,--and , when in [her]152-innocent presence and under [her]152-innocent influence , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn gained a glimmering of consciousness of what love might mean in its best and purest sense .

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn laughed at [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn however for this very thought . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had always pooh - pooh'd the idea of love as having anything divine or uplifting in its action,--nevertheless in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn more sincere moments [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was bound to confess that since [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had known [Innocent]152-innocent [his]102-amadis de jocelyn very art had gained a certain breadth and subtlety which it had lacked before . It was a pleasure to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn to see [her]152-innocent eyes shine with pride in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn work , to hear [her]152-innocent voice murmur dulcet praises of [his]102-amadis de jocelyn skill , and for a time [he]102-amadis de jocelyn took infinite pains with all [[his]102-amadis de jocelyn subjects]2295-his subjects , putting the very best of [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn into [his]102-amadis de jocelyn drawing and colouring with results that were brilliant and convincing enough to ensure success for all [his]102-amadis de jocelyn efforts . Sometimes -- lost in a sudden fit of musing -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn wondered how [his]102-amadis de jocelyn life would shape itself if [he]102-amadis de jocelyn married [her]152-innocent ? [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had avoided marriage as [a man]2681-a man might avoid hanging,--considering it , not without reason , the possible ruin of [an artist]3998-an artist 's greater career . Among [many men [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had known]2298-many men he had known , [men of undoubted promise]2299-men of undoubted promise , it had proved the fatal step downward from the high to the low . [One particular " chum "[2301-a gifted painter] of [his]102-amadis de jocelyn own]2300-one particular " chum " of his own , [a gifted painter]2301-a gifted painter , had married [a plump rosy young woman with " a bit o ' money]5166-a plump rosy young woman with " a bit o ' money , "[2302-the country folks] as [the country folks]2302-the country folks say,--and from that day had been steadily dragged down to the domestic level of sad and sordid commonplace . Instead of studying form and colour , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn was called upon to examine drains and superintend [the plumber]2303-the plumber , mark house linen and take care of [the children]2817-the children -- [[his]102-amadis de jocelyn wife]706-his wife believing in " making [a husband]3372-a husband useful . "[706-his wife] Of regard for [his]102-amadis de jocelyn art or possible fame [she]152-innocent had none,--while [[his]102-amadis de jocelyn children]3965-his children were taught to regard [his]102-amadis de jocelyn work in that line as less important than if [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had been [a bricklayer]2307-a bricklayer at so much pence the hour .

" [Children]3319-children ! "[706-his wife] thought [Jocelyn--"Do]329-jocelyn--"do [I]706-his wife want [them]3319-children ? ... No -- [I]706-his wife think not ! [They]3319-children 're all very well when [they]3319-children 're young -- really young!--two to five years old is the enchanting age,--but , most unfortunately , [they]3319-children grow ! Yes!--they grow,--often into [hideous men]5169-hideous men and [women]718-women -- a sort of human vultures sitting on [[their]3319-children fathers]5171-their fathers ' pockets and screaming ' Give ! Give ! ' The prospect does not attract [me]706-his wife ! And she?--Innocent ? [I]706-his wife do n't think [I]706-his wife could bear to watch [that little flower - like face gradually enlarging into matronly lines and spreading into a double chin]5172-that little flower - like face gradually enlarging into matronly lines and spreading into a double chin ! Those pretty eyes peering into the larder and considering the appearance of uncooked bacon ! Perish the thought ! One might as well think of [Shakespeare]171-shakespeare 's Juliet paying the butcher 's bill , or worse still , selecting [the butcher]5173-the butcher 's meat ! Forbid it , O ye heavens ! Of course if ideals could be realised , which [they]3319-children never are , [I]706-his wife can see [myself]706-his wife wedded for pure love , without a care , painting [my]706-his wife pictures at ease , with [a sweet woman worshipping [me]706-his wife , ever at [my]706-his wife beck and call]5174-a sweet woman worshipping me , ever at my beck and call , and shielding [me]706-his wife from trouble with all the tender force of [her]5174-a sweet woman worshipping me , ever at my beck and call passionate little soul!--but commonplace life will net fit itself into these sort of beatific visions ! [Babies]5175-babies , and the necessary provision of food and clothes and [servants]1104-servants -- this is what marriage means -- love having sobered down to a matter - of - fact conclusion . No -- no ! [I]706-his wife will not marry [her]5174-a sweet woman worshipping me , ever at my beck and call ! It would be like catching a fairy in [the woods]2789-the woods , cutting off its sunbeam wings and setting it to scrub the kitchen floor ! "[706-his wife]

It was curious that while [he]2308-he pleased [himself]2308-he with this fanciful soliloquy it did not occur to [him]2308-he that [he]2308-he had already caught the " fairy in [the woods]2789-the woods , "[2308-he] and ever since the capture had been engaged in cutting off its " sunbeam wings "[2308-he] with all a vivisector 's scientific satisfaction . And in [his]2308-he imaginary pictures of what might have been if " ideals "[2308-he] were realised , [he]2308-he did not for a moment conceive [HIMSELF]2308-he as " worshipping "[2308-he] [the woman who was to worship [HIM]2308-he , or as being at [HER]2309-her " beck and call]5179-the woman who was to worship him , or as being at her " beck and call , "[2308-he] or as shielding [HER]2309-her from trouble -- oh no ! [He]2308-he merely considered [himself]2308-he , and how [she]2309-her would care for [HIM,--never]330-him,--never once did [he]2308-he consider how [he]2308-he would care for [HER]2309-her .

Meanwhile things went on in an outwardly even and uneventful course . [Innocent]152-innocent worked steadily to fulfil certain contracts into which [she]152-innocent had entered with [the publishers who were eager to obtain as much of [her]152-innocent work]2310-the publishers who were eager to obtain as much of her work as [she]152-innocent could give them,--but [she]152-innocent had lost heart , and [her]152-innocent once soaring ambition was like a poor bird that had [been clumsily shot at , and had fallen to the ground with a broken wing]2311-been clumsily shot at , and had fallen to the ground with a broken wing . What [she]152-innocent had dreamed of as greatness , now seemed vain and futile . The " Amadis de Jocelin "[2312-the amadis de jocelyn of the twentieth] of the sixteenth century had taught [her]152-innocent to love literature -- to believe in it as the refiner of thought and expression , and to use it as a charm to inspire the mind and uplift the soul,--but [the Amadis de Jocelyn of the twentieth]2312-the amadis de jocelyn of the twentieth had no such lessons to teach . Utterly lacking in reverence for [great thinkers]2313-great thinkers , [he]2308-he dismissed the finest passages of poetry or prose from [his]2308-he consideration with light scorn as " purple patches , "[2308-he] borrowing that hackneyed phrase from the lower walks of [the press,--the most inspired writers , both of ancient and modern times]2314-the press,--the most inspired writers , both of ancient and modern times , came equally under the careless lash of [his]2308-he derision,--so that [Innocent]152-innocent , utterly bewildered by [his]2308-he sweeping denunciation of [many brilliant and famous authors]2315-many brilliant and famous authors , shrank into [her]152-innocent wounded self with pain , humiliation and keen disappointment , feeling that there was certainly no chance for [her]152-innocent to appeal to [him]2308-he in any way through the thoughts [she]152-innocent cherished and expressed with truth and fervour to [a listening world]2316-a listening world . [That world]2317-that world listened -- but [HE]2308-he did not!--therefore [the world]2693-the world seemed worthless and its praise mere mockery . [She]152-innocent had no vanity to support [her,--she]2319-her,--she was not " strong - minded "[2319-her,--she] enough to oppose [her]152-innocent own individuality to that of [the man [she]152-innocent loved]2320-the man she loved . And so [she]152-innocent began to droop a little,--her bright and ardent spirit sank like a sinking flame,--much to the concern of [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , who watched [her]152-innocent with a jealous tenderness of love beyond all expression . [The child of [Pierce Armitage]227-armitage]2321-the child of pierce armitage , lawfully or unlawfully begotten , was now to [her]152-innocent the one joy of existence,--the link that fastened [her]152-innocent more closely to life,--and [she]152-innocent worried [herself]152-innocent secretly over the evident listlessness , fatigue and depression of [the girl who had so lately been the very embodiment of happiness]2322-the girl who had so lately been the very embodiment of happiness . But [she]152-innocent did not like to ask questions,--she knew that [Innocent]152-innocent had a very resolute mind of [her]152-innocent own , and that if [she]152-innocent elected to remain silent on any subject whatsoever , nothing , not even the most affectionate appeal , would induce [her]152-innocent to speak .

" [You]227-armitage will not let [her]2321-the child of pierce armitage come to any harm , [Pierce]227-armitage ! "[1525-the old lady] murmured [the old lady]1525-the old lady prayerfully one day , standing before the portrait of [her]1525-the old lady former and faithless lover--"You will step in if danger threatens [her!--yes]227-armitage , [I]2324-her am sure [you]227-armitage will ! [You]227-armitage will guide and help [her]2321-the child of pierce armitage again as [you]227-armitage have guided and helped [her]2321-the child of pierce armitage before . For [I]2324-her believe [you]227-armitage brought [her]2321-the child of pierce armitage to [me]2324-her , [Pierce!--yes]331-pierce!--yes , [I]2324-her am sure [you]227-armitage did ! In [that other world]5180-that other world where [you]227-armitage are , [you]227-armitage have learned how much [I]2324-her loved [you]227-armitage long ago!--how much [I]2324-her love [you]227-armitage now!--and how [I]2324-her love [[your]227-armitage child]3758-your child for [your]227-armitage sake as well as for [her]3758-your child own ! All wrongs and mistakes are forgiven and forgotten , [Pierce]227-armitage ! and when [we]5182-we meet again [we]5182-we shall understand ! "[2324-her]

And with [her]2324-her little trembling worn hands [she]2324-her set a rose , just opening its deep red heart - bud into flower , in a crystal vase beside the portrait as a kind of votive offering , with something of the same superstitious feeling that induces [a devout Roman Catholic]2325-a devout roman catholic to burn a candle before [a favourite saint]2326-a favourite saint , in the belief that [the spirit of [the dead man]1095-the dead man]2327-the spirit of the dead man heard [her]2324-her words and would respond to them .

Just at this time , [Innocent]152-innocent went about a good deal among [the few friends who had learned to know [her]2324-her well and to love [her]2324-her accordingly]2329-the few friends who had learned to know her well and to love her accordingly . [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe was still away , having prolonged [his]229-lord blythe tour in order to enjoy the beauty of [the Italian lakes]2330-the italian lakes in autumn . Summer in [England]9-england was practically over , but the weather was fine and warm still , and country - house parties , especially in [Scotland]64-scotland , were the order of the day . The " social swim "[152-innocent] was subsiding , and what are called " [notable "[152-innocent] people]5183-notable " people were beginning to leave [town]2781-town . Once or twice , infected by the general exodus , [Innocent]152-innocent thought of going down to [Briar Farm]4-briar farm just for a few days as a surprise to [Priscilla]103-priscilla -- but a feeling for [Robin]84-robin held [her]2324-her back . It would be needless unkindness to again vex [his]84-robin mind with the pain of a hopeless passion . So [she]2324-her paid a few casual visits here and there , chiefly at [houses where [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn]2332-houses where amadis de jocelyn was also [one of [the invited guests]2334-the invited guests]2333-one of the invited guests . [She]2324-her was made the centre of a considerable amount of adulation , which did not move [her]2324-her to any sort of self - satisfaction , because in the background of [her]2324-her thoughts there was always the light jest and smile of [[her]2324-her lover]892-her lover , who laughed at praise , except , be it here said , when it was awarded to [himself]892-her lover . Then [he]892-her lover did not laugh -- [he]892-her lover assumed a playful humility which , being admirably acted , almost passed for modesty . But if by chance [he]892-her lover had to listen to any praise of " [Ena Armitage]247-ena armitage "[892-her lover] as [author]2336-author or [woman]3519-woman , [he]892-her lover changed the subject as soon as [he]892-her lover could conveniently do so without brusquerie . And very gradually it dawned upon [her]2324-her that [he]892-her lover took no pride in [her]2324-her work or in the position [she]2324-her had won , and that [he]892-her lover was more reluctant than glad to hear [her]2324-her praised . [He]892-her lover seemed to prefer [she]2324-her should be unnoticed , save by [himself]892-her lover , and more or less submissive to [his]892-her lover will . Had [she]2324-her been worldly - wise , [she]2324-her would by every action have moved a silent protest against this , [his]892-her lover particular form of sex - dominance , but [she]2324-her was of too loving a nature to dispute any right of command [he]892-her lover chose to assume . [Other men , younger and far higher in place and position than [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn]2338-other men , younger and far higher in place and position than jocelyn , admired [her]2324-her , and made such advances as [they]2338-other men , younger and far higher in place and position than jocelyn dared , finding [her]2324-her very coldness attractive , united as it was to such sweetness of manner as [few]2339-few could resist , but [they]2338-other men , younger and far higher in place and position than jocelyn had no chance with [her]2324-her . Once or twice [some of [[her]2324-her women friends]2341-her women friends]2340-some of her women friends had sounded [her]2324-her on the subject of love and [lovers]2705-lovers , and [she]2324-her had put aside all [their]2340-some of her women friends questions with a smile . " Love is not to be talked about , "[2324-her] [she]2324-her had said--"It is like [God]80-god , served best in silence . "[2324-her]

But by scarcely perceptible degrees , busy rumour got hold of a thread or two of the clue leading to the labyrinth of [her]2324-her mystery,--people nodded mysteriously at each other and began to whisper suggestions -- suggestions which certainly did not go very far , but just floated in the air like bits of thistledown .

" [She]2324-her is having [her]2324-her portrait painted , is n't [she]2324-her ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Yes -- by [that man with the queer name]5184-that man with the queer name -- [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn . "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Has [she]2324-her given [him]5184-that man with the queer name the commission ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Oh no ! [I]102-amadis de jocelyn believe not . [He]5184-that man with the queer name 's painting it for the French Salon . "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Oh ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

Then there would follow a silence , with an exchange of smiles all round . And presently the talk would begin again .

" Will it be a ' case , ' do [you]102-amadis de jocelyn think ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" A ' case ' ? [You]102-amadis de jocelyn mean a marriage ? Oh dear no ! [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn is n't [a marrying man]5185-a marrying man . "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Is n't [she]2324-her a little -- er -- well!--a little taken with [him]5184-that man with the queer name ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Perhaps ! Very likely ! [Clever women]4518-clever women are always [fools]5187-fools on one point -- if not on several ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" And [he]5184-that man with the queer name ? Is n't [he]5184-that man with the queer name very attentive ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" Not more so than [he]5184-that man with the queer name has been and is to [dozens of [other women]4776-other women]5188-dozens of other women . [He]5184-that man with the queer name 's too clever to show [her]2324-her any special attention -- it might compromise [him]5184-that man with the queer name . [He]5184-that man with the queer name 's [a man that takes care of [Number One]332-number one]5190-a man that takes care of number one ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

So the gossip ran,--and only [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn caught wind of it sufficiently to set [him]102-amadis de jocelyn thinking . [His]102-amadis de jocelyn " affaire de coeur "[102-amadis de jocelyn] had gone far enough,--and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn realised that the time had come for [him]102-amadis de jocelyn to beat a retreat . But how to do it ? The position was delicate and difficult . If [Innocent]152-innocent had been [an ordinary type of woman , vain and selfish , fond of frivolities and delighting in new conquests]2343-an ordinary type of woman , vain and selfish , fond of frivolities and delighting in new conquests , [his]102-amadis de jocelyn task would have been easy,--but with [a girl who believed in love as the ultimatum of all good]2344-a girl who believed in love as the ultimatum of all good , and who trusted [[her]2344-a girl who believed in love as the ultimatum of all good lover]892-her lover with implicit faith as next in order of worship to [God]80-god , what was to be done ?

" [We]5191-we talk a vast amount of sentimental rubbish about [women]718-women being pure and faithful ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn soliloquised--"But when [they]718-women ARE pure and faithful [we]5191-we are more bored with [them]718-women than if [they]718-women were [the worst women in [town]2781-town]5193-the worst women in town ! "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn had however one subject of congratulation for which [he]102-amadis de jocelyn metaphorically patted [himself]102-amadis de jocelyn on the back as being " [a good boy"--he]5195-a good boy"--he[102-amadis de jocelyn] had not gone to such extremes in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn love - affair as could result in what is usually called " trouble "[102-amadis de jocelyn] for [the girl]414-the girl . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had left [her]414-the girl unscathed , save in a moral and spiritual sense . The sweet body , with its delicate wavering tints of white and rose was as the unspoilt sheath of a lily - bud,--no one could guess that within the sheath the lily itself was blighted and slowly withering . [One]2347-one may question whether it is not a more cruel thing to seduce the soul than the body,--to crush all the fine faiths and happy illusions of a fair mind and leave them scorched by a devastating fire whose traces shall never be obliterated . [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn would have laughed [his]102-amadis de jocelyn gayest and most ironical laugh at the bare possibility of such havoc being wrought by the passion of love alone .

" What 's the use of loving or remembering anything ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn would exclaim--"One loves -- one tires of love!--and by - and - by one forgets that love ever existed . [I]102-amadis de jocelyn look forward to the time when [my]102-amadis de jocelyn memory shall dwell chiefly on the agreeable entremets of life -- a good dinner -- a choice cigar ! These things never bother [you]5196-you afterwards,--unless [you]5196-you eat too much or smoke too much,--then [you]5196-you have headache and indigestion -- distinctly [your]5196-you own fault ! But if [you]5196-you love [a woman]2688-a woman for a time and tire of [her]2688-a woman afterwards [she]2688-a woman always bothers you!--reminding [you]5196-you of the days when [you]5196-you ' once ' loved [her]2688-a woman with persistent and dreadful monotony ! [I]102-amadis de jocelyn believe in forgetting,--and ' letting go . ' "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

With these sentiments , which were the true outcome of [his]102-amadis de jocelyn real self , it was not and never would be possible for [him]102-amadis de jocelyn to conceive that with certain high and ultra - sensitive natures love is a greater necessity than life itself , and that if [they]2348-they are deprived of the glory [they]2348-they have been led to imagine [they]2348-they possessed , nothing can make compensation for what to [them]2348-they is eternal loss , coupled with eternal sorrow .

Meanwhile [Innocent]152-innocent 's portrait on which [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had worked for a considerable time was nearly completed . It was one of the best things [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had ever done , and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn contemplated it with a pleasant thrill of artistic triumph , forgetting [the " woman]5198-the " woman "[5198-the " woman] entirely in satisfied consideration of the " subject . "[5198-the " woman] As a portrait [he]102-amadis de jocelyn realised that it would be the crown of the next year 's Salon , bearing comparison with any work of [the greater modern masters]2349-the greater modern masters . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn was however a trifle perplexed , and not altogether pleased at the expression , which , entirely away from [his]102-amadis de jocelyn will and intention , had insensibly thrown a shadow of sadness on the face,--it had come there apparently of itself , unbidden . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn had been particularly proud of [his]102-amadis de jocelyn success in the drawing of [the girl]414-the girl 's extremely sensitive mouth , for [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had , as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn thought , caught the fleeting sweetness of the smile which was one of [her]414-the girl greatest charms,--but now , despite [his]102-amadis de jocelyn pains , that smile seemed to lose itself in the sorrow and pathos of an unspoken reproach , which , though enthralling and appealing to [the beholder]2351-the beholder as the look of the famous " [Mona Lisa]333-mona lisa , "[414-the girl] had fastened itself as it were on the canvas without [the painter]4223-the painter 's act or consent . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn was annoyed at this , yet dared not touch it in any attempt to alter what asserted itself as convincingly finished,--for the picture was a fine work of art and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn realised that it would add to [his]102-amadis de jocelyn renown .

" [I]102-amadis de jocelyn shall not name it as the portrait of [a living woman]5199-a living woman , "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn said to himself--"I shall call it simply--'Innocent . ' "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

As [he]102-amadis de jocelyn thought this , [the subject of the painting]2353-the subject of the painting [herself]414-the girl entered [the studio]1718-the studio . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn turned at the sound of the door opening , and caught a strange new impression of her,--an impression that moved [him]102-amadis de jocelyn to a touch of something like fear . Was [she]414-the girl going to be tiresome , [he]102-amadis de jocelyn wondered?--would [she]414-the girl make [him]102-amadis de jocelyn a " scene"--or[414-the girl] do something odd as [women]718-women generally did when [their]718-women feelings escaped control ? [Her]414-the girl face was very pale -- [her]414-the girl eyes startlingly bright,--and the graceful white summer frock [she]414-the girl wore , with soft old lace falling about it , a costume completed in perfection by a picturesque Leghorn hat bound with black velvet and adorned with a cluster of pale roses , made [her]414-the girl a study worthy the brush of many a greater artist than [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn . [His]102-amadis de jocelyn quick eye noted every detail of [her]414-the girl dainty dress and fair looks as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn went to meet [her]414-the girl and took [her]414-the girl in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn arms . [She]414-the girl clung to [him]102-amadis de jocelyn for a moment -- and [he]102-amadis de jocelyn felt [her]414-the girl tremble .

" What 's the matter ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn asked , with unconscious sharpness--"Is anything wrong ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[She]414-the girl put [him]102-amadis de jocelyn away from [her]414-the girl tenderly and looked up smiling -- but there was a sparkling dew in [her]414-the girl eyes .

" No , [[my]414-the girl [Amadis]102-amadis de jocelyn]4471-my amadis ! Nothing wrong ! "[414-the girl]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn heaved a quick sigh of relief .

" Thank heaven ! [You]414-the girl looked at [me]102-amadis de jocelyn as if [you]414-the girl had a grievance -- [all women]5145-all women have grievances -- but [they]5145-all women should keep them to [themselves]5145-all women . "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[She]414-the girl gave the slightest little shrug of [her]414-the girl shoulders ; then went and sat on the highest step of the familiar dais where [she]414-the girl had posed for [her]414-the girl picture , and waited a moment . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn did not at once come to sit beside [her]414-the girl as [he]102-amadis de jocelyn had so often done -- [he]102-amadis de jocelyn stood opposite [his]102-amadis de jocelyn easel , looking at [her]414-the girl portrait but not at [her]414-the girl .

" [I]414-the girl have no grievance , "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl said then , making an effort to steady [her]414-the girl voice , which trembled despite herself--"And if [I]102-amadis de jocelyn had [I]102-amadis de jocelyn should not vex [you]102-amadis de jocelyn with it . [He]102-amadis de jocelyn looked round at [her]414-the girl with a kind smile .

" Just what [I]102-amadis de jocelyn want to have with [you]414-the girl ! ' Les beaux esprits se rencontrent'--and [we]5202-we both want exactly the same thing ! [Dear little girl]3702-dear little girl , how sensible [you]414-the girl are ! Of course [we]5202-we must talk -- about the future . "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

A lovely radiance lit up [her]414-the girl face .

[Her]414-the girl eyes opened in sudden terrified wonderment .

" Before [you]102-amadis de jocelyn go -- where ? "[414-the girl]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn laughed a little awkwardly .

" Oh -- only a short journey -- on business -- [I]102-amadis de jocelyn will explain when [we]5205-we have [our]5205-we talk out -- not now -- in a day or two-- "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn left the easel , and coming to where [she]414-the girl sat , lifted [her]414-the girl in [his]102-amadis de jocelyn arms and folded [her]414-the girl close to [his]102-amadis de jocelyn breast .

" Am [I]102-amadis de jocelyn not proving it ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn answered--"Does [a man]2681-a man behave like this if [he]2681-a man does not love ? "[414-the girl]

" Ah , yes ! "[414-the girl] And [she]414-the girl looked up with a wild piteousness in [her]414-the girl sweet eyes--"A [man]567-man will behave like this to [any woman]4350-any woman ! "[414-the girl]

" No one!"--and[102-amadis de jocelyn] [her]414-the girl caressing arms fell away from him--"My [Amadis]102-amadis de jocelyn , [you]102-amadis de jocelyn find it pleasant to kiss and to embrace [me]102-amadis de jocelyn for the moment -- but perhaps not always will [you]102-amadis de jocelyn care ! [Love]91-love -- real love is different-- "[102-amadis de jocelyn]

" What do [YOU]414-the girl mean by love ? "[102-amadis de jocelyn] [he]102-amadis de jocelyn asked still smiling .

[She]414-the girl sighed .

" [I]414-the girl can hardly tell [you]102-amadis de jocelyn , "[414-the girl] [she]414-the girl said--"But one thing [I]414-the girl DO know -- love would never hurt or wrong the thing [it]91-love loved ! Words , kisses , embraces -- they are just the sweet outflow of a great deep!--but love is above and beyond all these , like [an angel]3694-an angel living with [God]80-god ! "[414-the girl]

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn was silent .

[He]102-amadis de jocelyn smiled , curiously .

CHAPTER X

[Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe stood at the open window of [his]229-lord blythe sitting - room in [the Grand Hotel at [Bellaggio]65-bellaggio]2356-the grand hotel at bellaggio -- a window opening out to [a broad balcony]2357-a broad balcony and commanding one of the most enchanting views of [the lake]2358-the lake and mountains ever created by Divine Beneficence for the delight of [man]567-man . The heavenly scene , warm with rich tints of morning in [Italy]62-italy , glowed like a jewel in the sun : [picturesque boats with little red and blue awnings rocked at the edge of [the calm lake]2361-the calm lake]2360-picturesque boats with little red and blue awnings rocked at the edge of the calm lake , in charge of [their]2360-picturesque boats with little red and blue awnings rocked at the edge of the calm lake bronzed and red - capped boatmen , waiting for hire,--the air was full of fragrance , and every visible thing appealed to beauty - loving eyes with exquisite and irresistible charm . [His]229-lord blythe attention , however , had wandered far from the enjoyable prospect,--he was reading and re - reading a letter [he]229-lord blythe had just received from [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh , in which certain passages occurred which caused [him]229-lord blythe some uneasiness . On leaving [England]9-england [he]229-lord blythe had asked [her]239-miss leigh to write regularly , giving [him]229-lord blythe all the news of [Innocent]152-innocent , and [she]239-miss leigh had readily undertaken what to [her]239-miss leigh was a pleasing duty . [His]229-lord blythe thoughts were constantly with [the little house in [Kensington]33-kensington]2362-the little house in kensington , where [the young daughter of [[his]229-lord blythe dead friend]2364-his dead friend]2363-the young daughter of his dead friend worked so patiently to bring forth the fruits of [her]239-miss leigh genius and live independently by [their]2360-picturesque boats with little red and blue awnings rocked at the edge of the calm lake results , and [his]229-lord blythe intense sympathy for the difficult position in which [she]239-miss leigh had been placed through no fault of [her]239-miss leigh own and the courage with which [she]239-miss leigh had surmounted it , was fast deepening into affection . [He]229-lord blythe rather encouraged this sentiment in [himself]229-lord blythe with the latent hope that possibly when [he]229-lord blythe returned to [England]9-england [she]239-miss leigh might still be persuaded to accept the position [he]229-lord blythe was so ready to offer [her]239-miss leigh -- that of [daughter]3568-daughter to [him]229-lord blythe and [heiress,--and]334-heiress,--and just now [he]229-lord blythe was troubled by an evident anxiety which betrayed itself in [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's letter -- anxiety which [she]239-miss leigh plainly did [her]239-miss leigh best to conceal , but which nevertheless made itself apparent .

" [The dear child]5216-the dear child works incessantly , "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh wrote , " but [she]239-miss leigh is very quiet and seems easily tired . [She]239-miss leigh is not as bright as [she]239-miss leigh used to be , and looks very pale , so that [I]239-miss leigh fear [she]239-miss leigh is doing too much , though [she]239-miss leigh says [she]239-miss leigh is perfectly well and happy . [We]5217-we had a call from [Mr. John Harrington]335-mr. john harrington the other afternoon -- [I]239-miss leigh think [you]5218-you know [him]335-mr. john harrington -- and [he]335-mr. john harrington seemed quite to think with [me]239-miss leigh that [she]239-miss leigh is over - working [herself]239-miss leigh . [He]335-mr. john harrington suggested that [I]239-miss leigh should persuade [her]239-miss leigh to go for a change somewhere , either with [me]239-miss leigh or with [other friends]5219-other friends . [I]239-miss leigh wonder if [you]5218-you would care for [us]5217-we to join [you]5218-you at [the Italian Lakes]2330-the italian lakes ? If [you]5218-you would [I]239-miss leigh might be able to manage it . [I]239-miss leigh have not mentioned the idea to [her]239-miss leigh yet , as [I]239-miss leigh know [she]239-miss leigh is finishing some work -- but [she]239-miss leigh tells [me]239-miss leigh it will all be done in a few days , and that then [she]239-miss leigh will take a rest . [I]239-miss leigh hope [she]239-miss leigh will , for [I]239-miss leigh 'm sure [she]239-miss leigh needs it . "[239-miss leigh]

Another part of the letter ran as follows:--

" [I]239-miss leigh rather hesitate to mention it , but [I]239-miss leigh think so many prolonged sittings for [her]239-miss leigh portrait to [that painter with the strange name]5221-that painter with the strange name , [Amadis de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn , have rather tired [her]239-miss leigh out . The picture is finished now , and [I]239-miss leigh and [a few friends]5222-a few friends went to see it the other day . It is a most beautiful portrait , but very sad!--and it is wonderful how the likeness of [[her]239-miss leigh father]1518-her father as [he]1518-her father was in [his]1518-her father young days comes out in [her]239-miss leigh face ! [She]239-miss leigh and [Mr. de Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn are [very intimate friends]5224-very intimate friends -- and [some people]4024-some people say [he]1518-her father is in love with [her]239-miss leigh ! Perhaps [he]1518-her father may be!--but [I]239-miss leigh do hope [she]239-miss leigh is not in love with [HIM]1518-her father ! "[239-miss leigh]

[Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe took off [his]229-lord blythe spectacles , folded up the letter and put it in [his]229-lord blythe pocket . Then [he]229-lord blythe looked out towards [the lake]2358-the lake and the charming picture it presented . How delightful it would be to see [Innocent]152-innocent in [one of those dainty boats scattered about near [the water 's edge]2368-the water 's edge]2367-one of those dainty boats scattered about near the water 's edge , revelling with all the keenness of a bright , imaginative temperament in the natural loveliness around [her]152-innocent ! What was [he]229-lord blythe that [he]229-lord blythe should creep into the unspoiled sphere of [a woman]2688-a woman 's opening life ? [A painter]4495-a painter , something of a genius in [his]229-lord blythe line , but erratic and unstable in [his]229-lord blythe character,--known more or less for several " affairs of gallantry "[229-lord blythe] which had slipped off [his]229-lord blythe easy conscience like water off a duck 's back,--not [a highly cultured man]2374-a highly cultured man by any means , because ignorant of many of the finer things in art and letters , and without any positively assured position . " Yes -- of course [she]152-innocent must come out here , "[229-lord blythe] [Blythe]229-lord blythe decided , after a few minutes ' cogitation . [Poor little girl]2953-poor little girl ! [She]152-innocent shall not have [her]152-innocent spirit broken if [I]229-lord blythe can help it . "[229-lord blythe]

[He]229-lord blythe stayed yet another few minutes at the open window , and taking out a cigar from [his]229-lord blythe case began to light it . While doing this [his]229-lord blythe eye was suddenly caught by the picturesque , well - knit figure of [a man sitting easily on a step near the clustering boats gathered close to [[the hotel]2379-the hotel 's special landing place]2380-the hotel 's special landing place]2378-a man sitting easily on a step near the clustering boats gathered close to the hotel 's special landing place . [He]229-lord blythe was apparently one of [the many road - side artists one meets everywhere about [the Italian Lakes]2330-the italian lakes]2381-the many road - side artists one meets everywhere about the italian lakes , ready to paint a sunset or moonlight on [Como]66-como or [Maggiore]67-maggiore on commission at short notice for a few francs . [He]229-lord blythe was not young -- [his]229-lord blythe white hair and grizzled moustache marked the unpleasing passage of resistless time,--yet there was something lissom and graceful about [him]229-lord blythe that suggested a kind of youth in age . [His]229-lord blythe attire consisted of much worn brown trousers and a loose white shirt kept in place by a red belt,--his shirt sleeves were rolled up to the elbow , displaying thin brown muscular arms , expressive of energy , and [he]229-lord blythe wore a battered brown hat which might once have been of the so - called " Homburg "[229-lord blythe] shape , but which now resembled nothing ever seen in the way of ordinary head - gear . [He]229-lord blythe was busily engaged in sketching a view of [the lake]2358-the lake and [the opposite mountains]2384-the opposite mountains , evidently to the order of [some fashionably dressed women who stood near [him]229-lord blythe watching the rapid and sure movements of [his]229-lord blythe brush]2385-some fashionably dressed women who stood near him watching the rapid and sure movements of his brush -- [he]229-lord blythe had [his]229-lord blythe box of water - colours beside [him]229-lord blythe , and smiled and talked as [he]229-lord blythe worked . [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe watched [him]229-lord blythe with lively interest , while enjoying the first whiffs of [his]229-lord blythe lately lit cigar .

" [A clever chap]5229-a clever chap , evidently ! "[229-lord blythe] [he]229-lord blythe thought . " [These Italians]5230-these italians are all [artists]4822-artists and [poets]3427-poets at heart . "[229-lord blythe]

" [You]2386-the artist are [an admirable painter]5238-an admirable painter , [[my]2386-the artist friend]3176-my friend ! And [he]2386-the artist turned round , pushing [his]2386-the artist cap off [his]2386-the artist brows , and showing a wonderfully handsome face , worn with years and privation , but fine and noble - featured and full of the unquenchable light which is given by an indomitable and enduring spirit .

[Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe staggered back and caught at the handrail of the landing steps to save [himself]2386-the artist from falling .

"[227-armitage]

[He]2413-i laughed rather bitterly .

" [I]2413-i think [I]2413-i lost a good deal more than [myself]2413-i and [my]2413-i name ! "[2413-i] [he]2413-i went on . " But did [you]2413-i ever think of [the child]2985-the child ? "[229-lord blythe] interrupted [Blythe]229-lord blythe , suddenly .

[Armitage]227-armitage looked up .

" Think of it ? Of course [I]2413-i did ! The place where [I]2413-i left [it]2985-the child was called [[Briar Farm,--a]45-briar wonderful old sixteenth - century house]5281-briar farm,--a wonderful old sixteenth - century house -- [I]2413-i made a drawing of it once when the apple - blossom was out -- and [the owner of [it]2985-the child , known as [Farmer Jocelyn]120-farmer jocelyn]5282-the owner of it , known as farmer jocelyn , had a wonderful reputation in [the neighbourhood]3728-the neighbourhood for integrity and kindness . [I]2413-i left [the child]2985-the child with [him]2413-i -- one stormy night in autumn -- saying [I]2413-i would come back for it -- of course [I]2413-i never did -- but for twelve years [I]2413-i sent money for it from [different places in [Europe]72-europe]5285-different places in europe -- and before [I]2413-i left [England]9-england [I]2413-i told [Maude]313-maude where it was , in case [she]313-maude ever wanted to see it -- not that such an idea would ever occur to [her]313-maude ! [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe held up [his]229-lord blythe hand .

CHAPTER XI

It was a gusty September afternoon in [London]3-london , and autumn had given some unpleasing signs of its early presence in the yellow leaves that flew whirling over the grass in [Kensington Gardens]74-kensington gardens and [other open spaces where trees spread [their]2429-their kind boughs to the rough and chilly wind]2428-other open spaces where trees spread their kind boughs to the rough and chilly wind . A pretty little elm in [[Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh 's tiny garden]2430-miss leigh 's tiny garden was clothed in gold instead of green , and shook [its]2431-its glittering foliage down with every breath of air like fairy coins minted from the sky . [Innocent]152-innocent , leaning from [her]152-innocent study window , watched the falling brightness with an unwilling sense of pain and foreboding .

" Summer is over , [I]152-innocent 'm afraid ! "[152-innocent] [she]152-innocent sighed--"Such a wonderful summer it has been for [me!--the]5328-me!--the summer of [my]152-innocent life -- the summer of [my]152-innocent love ! Oh , dear summer , stay just a little longer ! "[152-innocent]

And the verse of a song , sung so often as to have become hackneyed , rang in [her]152-innocent ears--

" Falling leaf and fading tree , Lines of white in a sullen sea , Shadows rising on [you]152-innocent and [me]152-innocent -- The swallows are making [them]5329-them ready to fly , Wheeling out on a windy sky : Good - bye , Summer ! Good - bye , good - bye ! "[152-innocent]

[She]152-innocent shivered , and closed the window . [She]152-innocent was dressed for going out , and [her]152-innocent little motor - brougham waited for [her]152-innocent below . [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh had gone to lunch and to spend the afternoon with [some old friends residing out of town,--an]2432-some old friends residing out of town,--an unusual and wonderful thing for [her]239-miss leigh to do , as [she]239-miss leigh seldom accepted invitations now where [Innocent]152-innocent was not concerned,--but [the people who had asked [her]239-miss leigh]2433-the people who had asked her were [venerable folk who could not by the laws of nature]2434-venerable folk who could not by the laws of nature be expected to live very much longer , and as [they]2433-the people who had asked her had known [Lavinia Leigh]239-miss leigh from girlhood [she]239-miss leigh considered it somewhat of a duty to go and see [them]2433-the people who had asked her when , as in this instance , [they]2433-the people who had asked her earnestly desired it . Moreover [she]239-miss leigh knew [Innocent]152-innocent had [her]152-innocent own numerous engagements and was never concerned at being left alone -- especially on this particular afternoon when [she]152-innocent had an appointment with [her]152-innocent publishers,--and another appointment afterwards , of which [she]152-innocent said nothing , even to [herself]152-innocent . [She]152-innocent had taken more than usual pains with [her]152-innocent attire , and looked [her]152-innocent sweetest in a soft dove - coloured silk gown gathered about [her]152-innocent slight figure in cunning folds of exquisite line and drapery , while the tender gold of [her]152-innocent hair shone like ripening corn from under the curved brim of a graceful " picture "[152-innocent] hat of black velvet , adorned with one drooping pale grey plume . A small knot of roses nestled among the delicate lace on [her]152-innocent bodice , and the diamond dove - pendant [Lord Blythe]229-lord blythe had given [her]152-innocent sparkled like a frozen sunbeam against the ivory whiteness of [her]152-innocent throat . [She]239-miss leigh glanced at [herself]239-miss leigh in the mirror with a smile,--wondering if " [he]2435-he "[239-miss leigh] would be pleased with [her]239-miss leigh appearance,--"he "[239-miss leigh] had been what is called " difficult "[239-miss leigh] of late , finding fault with some of the very points of [her]239-miss leigh special way of dress which [he]2435-he had once eagerly admired . But [she]239-miss leigh attributed [his]2435-he capricious humour to fatigue and irritability from " over - strain"--that[239-miss leigh] convenient ailment which is now - a - days brought in as a disguise for mere want of control and bad temper . " [He]2435-he has been working so hard to finish [his]2435-he portrait of [me]239-miss leigh ! "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh thought , tenderly--"Poor [fellow!--he]5330-fellow!--he must have got quite tired of looking at [my]239-miss leigh face ! "[239-miss leigh]

[She]239-miss leigh glanced round [[her]239-miss leigh study]801-her study to see that everything was in order -- and then took up a neatly tied parcel of manuscript -- [her]239-miss leigh third book -- completed . [She]239-miss leigh had a fancy -- one of many , equally harmless,--that [she]239-miss leigh would like to deliver it [herself]239-miss leigh to [the publishers]1625-the publishers rather than send it by post , on this day of all days , when plans for the future were to be discussed with [[her]239-miss leigh lover]892-her lover and everything settled for [their]2439-their mutual happiness . [Her]239-miss leigh heart grew light with joyous anticipation as [she]239-miss leigh ran [downstairs]994-downstairs and nodded smilingly at [the maid [Rachel]251-rachel , who stood ready at the door to open it for [her]239-miss leigh passing]2441-the maid rachel , who stood ready at the door to open it for her passing .

" If [Miss Leigh]239-miss leigh comes [home]2674-home before [I]239-miss leigh do , tell [her]239-miss leigh [I]239-miss leigh will not be long , "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh said , as [she]239-miss leigh stepped into [her]239-miss leigh brougham and was whirled away . At [the office of [[her]239-miss leigh publishers]1792-her publishers]2442-the office of her publishers [she]239-miss leigh was expected and received with eager homage . [The head of the firm]1633-the head of the firm took the precious packet of manuscript from [her]239-miss leigh hand with a smile of entire satisfaction .

" [You]239-miss leigh are up to [your]239-miss leigh promised time , [Miss Armitage]252-miss armitage ! "[1633-the head of the firm] [he]1633-the head of the firm said , kindly--"And [you]239-miss leigh must have worked very hard . [She]239-miss leigh laughed , lightly .

" Oh , well!--perhaps ! "[239-miss leigh] [she]239-miss leigh answered--"If [I]1637-the publisher feel [I]1637-the publisher can afford it ! [The publisher]1637-the publisher looked at [her]239-miss leigh sweet , thoughtful face curiously .

"[239-miss leigh]

[He]1637-the publisher smiled,--and when [she]239-miss leigh left , escorted [her]239-miss leigh [himself]1637-the publisher out of [[his]1637-the publisher office]1431-his office to [[her]239-miss leigh brougham]2447-her brougham with a kind friendliness that touched [her]239-miss leigh .

" [You]239-miss leigh wo n't let [me]1637-the publisher call [you]239-miss leigh [a brilliant author]5334-a brilliant author , "[1637-the publisher] [he]1637-the publisher said , as [he]1637-the publisher shook hands with her--"Perhaps it will please [you]239-miss leigh better if [I]1637-the publisher say [you]239-miss leigh are [a true woman]5335-a true woman ! "[1637-the publisher]

[Her]239-miss leigh eyes flashed up a bright gratitude,--she waved [her]239-miss leigh hand in parting -- as [the brougham]2448-the brougham glided off . And never to [his]1637-the publisher dying day did [that publisher and man of hard business detail]2449-that publisher and man of hard business detail forget the radiance of the face that smiled at [him]1637-the publisher that afternoon,--a face of light and youth and loveliness , as full of hope and faith as the face of [a pictured angel kneeling at the feet of the Madonna with heaven]2450-a pictured angel kneeling at the feet of the madonna with heaven 's own glory encircling it in gold .

The quick little motor - brougham seemed unusually slow - going that afternoon . [Innocent]152-innocent , with [her]152-innocent full happy heart and young pulsing blood , grew impatient with its tardy progress , yet , as a matter of fact , [it]2448-the brougham travelled along at its most rapid speed . [The well - known by - street near [Holland Park]63-holland park]2451-the well - known by - street near holland park was reached at last , and while [the brougham]2448-the brougham went off to [an accustomed retired corner chosen by [the chauffeur]2454-the chauffeur to await [her]152-innocent pleasure]2453-an accustomed retired corner chosen by the chauffeur to await her pleasure , [she]152-innocent pushed open the gate of the small garden leading to the back entrance of [[Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn 's studio]1783-jocelyn 's studio -- [a garden]2456-a garden now looking rather damp and dreary , strewn as [it]2456-a garden was with wet masses of fallen leaves . It was beginning to rain -- and [she]152-innocent ran swiftly along the path to the familiar door which [she]152-innocent opened with [her]152-innocent private key . [Jocelyn]102-amadis de jocelyn was working at [his]1637-the publisher easel -- [he]1637-the publisher heard the turn of the lock and looked round . [She]152-innocent entered , smiling -- but [he]1637-the publisher did not at once go and meet [her]152-innocent . [He]1637-the publisher was finishing off some special touch of colour over which [he]1637-the publisher bent with assiduous care,--and [she]152-innocent was far too unselfishly interested in [his]1637-the publisher work to disturb [him]1637-the publisher at what seemed to be an anxious moment . So [she]152-innocent waited .

Presently [he]1637-the publisher spoke , with a certain irritability in [his]1637-the publisher tone .

" Are [you]152-innocent there ? [I]1637-the publisher wish [you]152-innocent would come forward where [I]1637-the publisher can see [you]152-innocent ! "[1637-the publisher]

[She]152-innocent laughed -- a pretty rippling laugh of kindly amusement .

" [Amadis]102-amadis de jocelyn ! If [you]152-innocent are [a true Knight]5336-a true knight , it is [you]152-innocent who should turn round and look at [me]152-innocent for [yourself]152-innocent ! "[152-innocent]

" But [I]1637-the publisher am busy , "[1637-the publisher] [he]1637-the publisher said , with the same sharpness of voice--"Surely [you]152-innocent see that ? "[1637-the publisher]

[She]152-innocent made no answer , but moved quietly to a position where [she]152-innocent stood facing [him]1637-the publisher at about an arm 's length . Never had [she]152-innocent made a prettier picture than in that attitude of charming hesitation , with a tender little smile on [her]152-innocent pretty mouth and a wistful light in [her]152-innocent eyes . [He]1637-the publisher laid down [his]1637-the publisher palette and brushes .

" [I]1637-the publisher must give up work for to - day , "[1637-the publisher] [he]1637-the publisher said -- and going to [her]152-innocent [he]1637-the publisher took [her]152-innocent in [his]1637-the publisher arms--"You are too great an attraction for [me]1637-the publisher to resist !
